PETITION.TITLE: States Grants (Schools Assistance) Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:
The petition of the undersigned shows:

that the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act, 1988 includes legislation, Part III-Changes to Non-Government Schools and New Non-Government Schools, designed to inhibit the establishment, growth and development of these schools in Australia by the imposition of restrictive provisions in the areas of funding, enrolments and approval criteria.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:

reconsider the application and implications of this legislation in the light of justice, equity and freedom of choice for parents and have the unfair sections (Section 8 (2), 8 (15) and (11) ) repealed.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from 14 citizens), Peter Baume (from 11 citizens), Bishop (from 17 citizens), Brownhill (from 12 citizens), Childs (from 34 citizens), Dunn (from 12 citizens), Faulkner (from eight citizens), McLean (from eight citizens), and Puplick (from 11 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That in 1987-88 the Federal Government paid $6.4 million from taxpayers funds for 61,879 abortions under Medicare Items 6469 and 274/275 alone.
That in the same year Federal Government grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies and abolish Government funding of abortion.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Calvert (from 96 citizens) and Newman (from 228 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Capital Gains Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Western Australia respectfully showeth:
That increasing numbers of Australians with modest incomes are becoming subject to the Capital Gains Tax upon the sale of assets never acquired for speculative intent;

That the continuation of this Tax in its present form threatens to deprive Australians engaged in small business of adequate returns for the sale of enterprises developed through effort and risk taking;
That this increasingly unjust and burdensome tax be replaced by measures of taxation upon short term and speculative capital gains only.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitution: Proposed Changes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. the right of the people of a country to make law independent of politicians should be a basic and independent right;
2. consequently there is an urgent need for constitutional reforms.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:

support both the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1989 to provide a method of altering the Constitution on the initiative of electors, and the Legislative Initiative Bill 1989 to provide for the holding of referenda on bills proposed by members of the public;
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament.
The petition of citizens of Australia points out:

that all State governments, States Attorneys-General, most women's groups and the majority of men in Australia, including significant numbers of Members of Parliament, are totally opposed to the importation and distribution of `X'- and excessively violent `R'-rated video pornography in Australia;
that most `X'-rated material available in Australia is imported;
that the Federal Government, by its Customs power under the Constitution, and not the ACT Government, is solely responsible for controlling the importation of this pornographic material;
that by continuing to allow the importation of such pornographic material, the Federal Government is neglecting its responsibility to the women, children and families of Australia.
Your petitioners, therefore, request the Senate to:
1. Ban `X'-rated pornographic material at the point of entry into Australia.
2. Exclude from the `R'-rating all gratuitously violent material.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Watson, at the request of Senator Walters (from 2,730 citizens).,

PETITION.TITLE: Myanmar
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

(1) The Australian Government strongly urge the military Junta in Myanmar (Burma) to immediately release all political prisoners and relax restrictions on political activities of the opposition to bring about free and fair election.

(2) The Australian Government impress upon the Junta to invite international observers to Myanmar prior to and during the election period. This way, Myanmar shall regain the confidence and assistance of the world economic community to rebuild her own economy.
(3) The Australian Government use all its political and economic powers to achieve the above objectives.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: SARAWAK: IMPRISONMENT OF MEMBERS OF INDIGENOUS POPULATION

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, TRADE AND DEFENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) expresses concern that the Government reponse to the report by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Visits to Australia by Nuclear Powered or Armed Vessels: Contingency Planning for Accidental Release of Ionizing Radiation was not presented to the House of Representatives while that Chamber was sitting;
(b) regrets the confusion which stemmed from:
(i) the response being buried in a long list of Government papers, 83 out of 87, making it unlikely that it would be discussed in the Senate, and
(ii) the wording of the document which resulted in journalists and the Chairman of the Committee reaching conclusions other than those the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) intended;

(c) deplores the fact that the Minister showed little respect for either the Committee or its findings when he said that Senator Maguire would `lose at least an ear for this' because he had quite understandably concluded that the Government's response, if taken literally, would mean a ban on nuclear-powered warship visits until recommendations agreed to had been implemented;

(d) deplores the fact that the Government's response, written in true Sir Humphrey fashion, with the Committee's 39 recommendations being either noted (12 of them, meaning no, nothing would be done), endorsed (12 of them, meaning that the Federal Government would pass the buck to States and Territories), and agreed (15 of them, meaning that the Government would consider favourably the recommendation, which may or may not mean action), is an attempt to reassure the US Navy that it is business as usual, an attempt which badly back-fired;

Senator Tate-Mr President, I take a point of order. This is an attempt to use the notice of motion as a platform for a debate on this issue. Even if it is within Standing Orders, Senator Vallentine ought to be encouraged to observe the decencies and proprieties of the notices of motion period in the Business of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is no point of order but I remind all honourable senators that there is a recommendation before the Senate Standing Committee on Procedure to do something about this.
—The notice of motion continues:

SPEECH.PARA: (e) regrets the fact that Senators are effectively prohibited from debating the Government's confusing response being buried as it was amongst papers, which would only result in 5 minutes per Senator to speak, should there be an opportunity to speak to it all;

(f) also regrets the fact that the Government's response to the very long and important Senate report was eagerly awaited by thousands of concerned Australians who are angry at the Government's deliberate prevention of discussion of the response in the Parliament, further reinforcing the view that the Minister for Defence cares more about the US Navy's visits than he does about the people and environment of Australia and gives more weight to not upsetting the Americans than to processes of democracy in his own country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave, Mr President, to have the motion standing in my name moved formally.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to Senator Chaney's contingent notice of motion, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Crichton-Browne moving forthwith the motion of which he gave notice.

I will be brief. I can think of no more appropriate occasion than today for a motion of this nature to be moved formally, and no more appropriate occasion or circumstance for the suspension of standing orders so as to allow for the debate and resolution of the motion that stands in my name. I do not propose-and it would not be proper to do so-to canvass the events that have led up to the present situation. However, as matters stand, a team of 85 young athletes have been selected to represent their country at the forthcoming Commonwealth Games. Perhaps I ought to read the motion so we all understand that which I am debating. Yesterday I gave notice that, on the next day of sitting, I would move:
That the Senate-
(a) notes:
(i) The decision by the Australian Commonwealth Games Association (ACGA) to refuse to allow Athletics Australia to increase the size of the Australian track and field team from 70 to 85 members.
(ii) that the maximum allowable size under the Commonwealth Games rules of the Australian athletic team is 118,
(iii) that each of the 85 athletes selected has performed to a level which, based on the last Commonwealth Games, would qualify them for the finals at the Auckland Games,

(iv) that the ACGA has acknowledged that there is no financial impediment to a team of 85 athletes competing, that adequate accommodation within the Commonwealth Village at Auckland is available and that uniforms and competition uniforms are available for 85 athletes,
(v) that, notwithstanding the great travel distances involved, the Canadians and English are each sending track and field teams with in excess of 110 members,
(vi) that the decision not to increase the team size to 85 athletes is a procedural matter, and
(vii) that there is no practical reason why these 15 young Australian athletes should not be given an opportunity to represent their country; and
(b) calls upon:
(i) the ACGA to reverse its decision and allow these athletes an opportunity to represent Australia, and
(ii) the Government to convey to the ACGA the view that the 85 qualifying Australian track and field athletes be allowed to compete in the Auckland Commonwealth Games.

Eighty-five young people have made enormous personal sacrifices. They have given years of dedication and commitment and have now been given the honour of representing their country. Few of us, perhaps, understand the agony and ecstasy of their dilemma. Few of us, I imagine, could begin to understand the hours, days, months and years of personal sacrifice and commitment that they have given in the pursuit of excellence in their chosen sport. The level of dedication and commitment is something that I imagine very few people understand. Their finest reward is the opportunity to compete and to represent Australia at the Auckland Commonwealth Games.

Each of these athletes has experienced the joy and exhilaration of being officially informed that he or she is a member of the Australian Commonwealth Games team to compete in Auckland in January and February of 1990, only to have that joy, that ecstasy, dashed upon the rocks of official incompetence, confusion and stupidity because of what is described as a procedural matter. Athletics Australia has been instructed by the Australian Commonwealth Games Association to cull 15 of these 85 athletes from the team. These 85 young athletes are now not basking in the joy or the pleasure, not getting satisfaction or reward for their dedication and commitment, but living daily the agony of waiting for a phone call to be told that they are no longer in the team, that they will have to hand their blazer back in, so to speak. These young athletes are suffering the pain and indecision of not knowing whether they are still part of the team.

Surely this Senate is capable of arriving at a resolution, capable of making a determination and capable of making a decision in this matter. I do not believe it is necessary for this Senate to wait upon the deliberations, negotiations and discussions of Senator Richardson with the various officials. This Senate is capable of arriving at a conclusion of its own. It is aware of the facts and the circumstances. We all know-no view has been put to the contrary-that there is no practical impediment or reason why 85 young track and field athletes cannot compete, as selected, representing Australia in the Commonwealth Games. There is no financial impediment, and there are no problems with accommodation, aircraft seats or competition uniforms. There is no impediment whatsoever. It is simply a bureaucratic procedural matter, because originally Athletics Australia made a bid for 70 places and not 85. That bid was based on their best guess judgment as to how many of their athletes would qualify. But given additional funding from the Drug Offensive and Mobil Oil, which allowed for further meets and further grand prix competitions, the quality and the standard of performance of our athletes increased to the point where 85 of them are now capable of winning a place in the finals of the Auckland Commonwealth Games. There is not one of the 85 athletes selected that on his or her best performance so far could not compete in the finals. What do they have to do to get in? Guarantee a gold medal? I would have thought that it is not unreasonable that this Senate conveys the resolution that I have proposed thus far.

I have no doubt that when any one of these 85 athletes wins gold, silver or bronze, we will all be cheering in front of our television sets and that those who are visiting Auckland will be there cheering with pride and with tears in their eyes. We will be watching on television or clapping as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) presents their medals to them-thinking to himself, `This is a few more votes for me in the ballot box'. But everybody else will live in the reflected glory of their endeavours, their efforts, their joy, their ecstasy and their success. I would have thought that in those circumstances this Senate would be capable of moving and carrying a resolution that it convey to the officials of the Australian Commonwealth Games Association the view that we believe 85 athletes ought to compete.

I understand that Senator Richardson is finally meeting the officials this morning, as some sort of honest broker. I am sure we have all read what he has said so far. He was adamant that it was not his place to make judgments; he did not want to get involved. I am not suggesting for a moment that it is his right to instruct anybody, but he has a reputation for gentle persuasion. Under the circumstances, I would have thought it is not inappropriate that this Senate carry the motion I present.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support Senator Crichton-Browne's motion for the suspension of Standing Orders and have chosen not to call a point of order on Senator Crichton-Browne for debating the issue and not the suspension motion, and thus being guilty of using bureaucratic procedures, which he has so passionately disclaimed. In short, Senator Crichton-Browne's motion is supported by the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to oppose the motion. As we speak, a number of people have gathered in my office to try to settle this argument, which is causing a great deal of anguish to some young Australians who do not deserve it. If I thought that a motion in the Senate would do any good, I would be the first person to move it. The reality is that the Government does not run sport in Australia and should not. Mr President, you have heard one side of the story in this chamber; there is another side. The Senate should never make decisions based on ignorance. If it makes this decision today, it makes it on the basis of total ignorance when there is no need. All that this resolution can do is to hinder the process that goes on this morning, which I am very confident will result in a settlement. I am interested in a settlement for the future of Australian athletics and the Australian Commonwealth Games effort much more than I am in Senator Crichton-Browne's getting a headline.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
