SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to oppose the motion that has been moved by Senator Crichton-Browne. Like the Democrats, I did not attempt to take a point of order on Senator Crichton-Browne when he was moving for the suspension of Standing Orders because there was no point in doing so. He may as well have got the matter off his chest then as now. When one looks at the specifics of this issue and goes back over the argument and the difficulty of the last couple of months, one can see some enormous problems.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point to make is that when one speaks to sporting administrators around Australia, as I have done in the last few days as they have been queuing up to get on the telephone, one sees that a great many of them seriously question the decision regarding the 85 athletes. Those administrators include one of Australia's foremost sporting administrators who I hope will be involved in settling this issue today-someone who knows a great deal more about the difficulties than anyone else in the Senate. I really wonder how many senators here are aware of the selection criteria for Australian athletics. How many have looked at the 85 athletes and their performances and, therefore, how many senators feel qualified to make statements similar to those that Senator Crichton-Browne has made? I know a damn sight more about this matter than does Senator Crichton-Browne and I am not qualified to do so. Across Australia a number of sporting administrators and experts have been through selections of Commonwealth Games teams and Olympic Games teams and know, well and truly, that all is not perfect in the exercise that we have seen so far.

The Australian Democrats are supporting Senator Crichton-Browne's motion. I hope that one of the Australian Democrats will explain to us now the selection criteria, how the Australian Commonwealth Games Association has made its mistakes and how Athletics Australia justifies increasing the team size to 85 athletes. When the Australian Democrats do that we will see that they have an intimate knowledge of the matter and that they understand why they are voting the way they are. But they will not do that because they do not have a clue. The reality is that today, when we are trying to settle an argument, the Senate will actually pass a motion when almost no senators have any idea at all of its substance.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, none.
—Senator Collins says that not one senator knows, and I think that is probably true. Not one out of 76 senators understands the selection criteria and can talk to us abut the 85 athletes--
—How do you know?

—I challenge Senator Knowles to get up and tell me. She has not got a clue. The next athlete that she meets will be the first. The reality is that we will face a meeting this morning at which we will try to resolve a serious problem confronting sports administration and individual athletes. We will do that on the basis of absolutely no knowledge at all.
—You have an ego bigger than this building.

—The difference between Senator Knowles and me-apart from ego and a couple of other obvious ones-is that I do not pretend to know enough and she does. But during the course of the morning I will try, irrespective of the Senate's resolution, to do what I was doing yesterday-that is, trying to get a settlement. Having talked to both parties on the phone, I am very close to getting a settlement. It is going well. We can come out of this with the Commonwealth Games Association and Athletics Australia going forward to do the best for the Games and the best for those athletes. We will not do that by passing this motion. There is no hope at all of that. When the Commonwealth Games officials sitting in my office look around this room and know how ignorant people are of selection procedures, they will not be greatly impressed by this motion.
—Speak for yourself.
—Senator Sheil understands them. I will be waiting for him to stand up and explain them to me. I will be fascinated to hear his next contribution.
—If you want this debate to go for a couple of hours, it will.

—Senator Knowles can do what she likes. She is pretty tough. In any event I am only concerned with getting a solution. That is what I will spend the morning doing. I will not spend it wasting my time here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats supported the suspension of Standing Orders because we believed that it was right and proper that this matter come forward for public debate at the time. I point out to Senator Richardson that, whatever the Senate does or does not decide today, the decision making process will still be left in the hands of the Australian Commonwealth Games Association-the decision will still belong to it. The point of suspending Standing Orders means that we can at least open up the issues and this is being done. I have listened very carefully to what both Senator Richardson and Senator Crichton-Browne have said on the matter. In a debate it is not only speaking that is important; if we are to follow through the democratic process, we should also spend time listening and assessing the material brought forward in a debate. It may be pertinent that we debate the issue at the present time but do not actually carry the vote through until a later time this day. Therefore, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the debate be adjourned till a later hour of the day.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have to put the motion moved by Senator Jenkins. There can be no further speaking.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the motion (Senator Jenkins's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, under standing order 410 I seek to make an explanation in respect of the matters I raised during the previous debate.
—The honourable senator may proceed.

—Senator Richardson was so impertinent and arrogant as to suggest that he knows more about athletes and the criteria for their selection than anybody else in this chamber. I would not match myself with his arrogance or ignorance. But let me say, for his benefit, that the criteria used for the selection of 85 athletes for track and field events in the Commonwealth Games in Auckland was based on their best performances compared with the performances of athletes during the last Commonwealth Games. The performances of each of the 85 athletes would have qualified them for the finals of those Games. In other words, each had a time or performance comparable with the eight--

—Mr President, I have a point of order. I do not know what Senator Crichton-Browne is trying to do, but the issues he is traversing at this stage are ones that have been traversed already and I ask that you pull him up.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Puplick

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a point of order, Mr President. I appreciate the ignorance of Senator Bolkus of the Standing Orders of this place. I draw his attention to standing order 410, under which Senator Crichton-Browne is speaking, which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: A Senator who has spoken to a Question may again be heard, to explain himself in regard to some material part of his speech which has been misquoted or misunderstood.

Senator Crichton-Browne was accused by Senator Richardson of misleading the Senate in the sense that he was unaware of the criteria to be borne in mind as far as selections for the Commonwealth Games team are concerned. Senator Crichton-Browne is taking advantage of standing order 410 to explain himself in relation to some material part of his speech which Senator Richardson clearly misquoted and misunderstood. Under the Standing Orders, Senator Crichton-Browne is entitled to so do. Mr President, you having given him the call to do that, he is confining himself to the provisions of standing order 410 and is entitled to be heard. Senator Bolkus ought to read the Standing Orders.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bolkus

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on the point of order: putting aside the cheap comments made by Senator Puplick, maybe it would be better if you, Mr President, take into consideration the whole of standing order 410, particularly the second part of it, which Senator Puplick chose not to read out, which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . no debatable matter shall be brought forward or debate arise upon such explanation.
I suggest that Senator Crichton-Browne is re-debating the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I will listen to Senator Crichton-Browne. He must point out where he has been misrepresented or misquoted, and not open the debate again.
—Thank you, Mr President. When I sought to have Standing Orders suspended, I explained that a team of 85 athletes had been selected on certain criteria.
—Which are?

—The criteria are-Mr President, I will respond through you to the Government's request for further and better information-that the best performance of each athlete be equivalent to the performances of the first eight athletes in the last Commonwealth Games. Each of the 85 athletes falls within that criteria. It is a pity Senator Richardson did not understand that, because if he did he would not need 25 officials in his office now telling him that one and one makes two. It is a tragedy that we have athletes such as Robert de Castella saying that this decision has broken their hearts, souls and careers.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought that, under the circumstances, the criteria are quite clear to everybody. This Senate is capable of making a determination. I regret that it has been postponed for party-political purposes so that Senator Richardson can achieve the resolution I know he will get-that is, that the 85 athletes will go to Auckland, as a result of the determination of this chamber, and he will take the credit for it.

DEBATE.TITLE: HAZARDOUS WASTE (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS) BILL 1989INDUSTRIAL CHEMICALS (NOTIFICATION AND ASSESSMENT) BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 October, on motion by Senator Button:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I start in this debate on the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill and the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Bill by protesting in the strongest possible terms at the absence of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson. This debate was listed on the Notice Paper for yesterday but was postponed following a request to the Opposition, on the sole ground that Senator Richardson wished to be present for the debate. We were asked would we please not debate this in the absence of Senator Richardson yesterday. We therefore agreed not to debate the legislation yesterday and to wait until today so that Senator Richardson could be present in order to take part in a debate concerning the portfolio area in which he is the responsible Minister. I wish to object most strongly to our having been doublecrossed by the Government on the basis of being asked not to proceed yesterday with the legislation on the sole ground that Senator Richardson was absent and did not want the matter debated in his absence and would we please stand it over until today. We agreed to stand it over until today.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of technical matters, particularly in relation to the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill 1989, which Senator Coulter and I will be raising, which required the Minister to be here and give explanations. Therefore, I commence with a very strong indication to the Government that if this is the way in which, during the course of the remainder of the week, it wishes to deal with us-by seeking our cooperation to debate a particular matter, on a particular day, to suit the convenience of a particular Minister, who then leaves the chamber prior to the commencement of the debate-this week is, I think, going to be one which will strain a lot of the goodwill which I would have hoped, in dealing with substantive legislation, might have been available. I protest most strongly at that cavalier attitude on the part of the Government and I protest most strongly at being asked to cooperate with the Government and being treated in this appallingly shabby fashion.

There are two Bills which are now before the Senate in a cognate debate, the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill and the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Bill, and I propose to deal with both in my speech on the second reading. I shall turn, first, to the more straightforward of these Bills-the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Bill 1989. The purpose of the Bill is to establish a national scheme for the notification and assessment of industrial chemicals. It is designed to ensure that there is adequate information on any possible hazards associated with chemicals imported or manufactured in Australia. The Bill will not directly regulate the use of chemicals; that will remain a responsibility of the States and the Territories. However, under the scheme established by the Bill, the existing regulatory agencies will be provided with far better information on which to make decisions about regulating chemicals. This will encourage uniformity of regulation by the States and Territories, something which is to be greatly welcomed.

The legislation will provide for all new chemicals to be assessed before they are introduced into the Australian market, and for selected chemicals which are already in use to be reviewed. The Bill will provide for an inventory of all industrial chemicals currently in use in Australia. All new chemicals will be notified to Worksafe Australia, which is to administer the scheme, together with a notification statement of the chemicals' intended use and properties. The information will be assessed to determine the potential hazard to occupational health and safety, public health and the environment. Worksafe will be obliged to prepare and distribute assessments of the chemicals within a specified time frame. Such assessments would normally include recommendations for the safe use of the chemical. There is also provision for the selective assessment of existing chemicals where there are particular concerns about possible hazards. It is, of course, impossible to argue with the objectives of the Bill, which are to provide more information about hazardous chemicals, to reduce health and safety problems and to limit environmental damage.

It is worth noting that the chemical industry, through the Australian Chemical Industry Council, strongly supports this Bill. Indeed, a press release issued I think in September by Mr Frank Phillips, the Chief Executive Officer of the Australian Chemical Industry Council, States:
A new Commonwealth Bill to ensure that each industrial chemical in Australia is evaluated has been endorsed and welcomed by the Australian Chemical Industry Council.

I am pleased to see, on this particular occasion, that the cooperation between Government and industry has led to a situation in which the industry is happy with a regulatory regime which is being put in place. The chemical industry is already subject to a vast array of regulations covering aspects such as storage, transportation, occupational health and safety, environmental protection and consumer protection. These regulations, however, have grown up in an ad hoc manner and vary considerably from State to State. This means that industry is subjected to a variety of inconsistent regulatory regimes leading to substantially increased costs.

This Bill, of course, does not override the States' powers to regulate chemicals but by providing a common database it will encourage governments to develop uniform regulatory procedures and regimes. If a national scheme is not implemented, it is likely that pressure for improved environmental and occupational health and safety protection will lead to the States developing their own separate notification and assessment arrangements. This would undoubtedly increase costs both for Government and the industry and, indeed, for the consumers. Some parallel may be drawn between this and the debate which we had last week on the therapeutic goods legislation in terms of overlapping Commonwealth and State regulations. The scheme, as I have indicated previously, has been developed in close consultation with industry and is designed to minimise the cost burden.

The Business Regulation Review Unit-again I drew heavily on some of its comments in relation to the therapeutic goods legislation the other day-supports the introduction of a national notification and assessment scheme which it believes will lead to higher levels of public safety and lower costs in the manufacture and use of chemicals. The Business Regulation Review Unit has proposed some modifications to this scheme contained in the Bill. It argues that all new chemicals should be automatically approved where they are already included in recognised inventories of major Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries. This, it is argued, would avoid duplicating work done overseas, reduce costs and release resources to develop information on chemicals already in use that are of concern.

The counter argument, however, is that the Bill already provides for the use of overseas assessment. Under the Bill's provisions, where a new chemical has been notified and assessed under the recognised equivalent scheme of another country, that notification and assessment will suffice provided that the assessment is assessable and relevant to the proposed use and exposure profile of the chemical in Australia. The difficulty in automatically approving chemicals on overseas inventories is that simply being on the inventory of an OECD country does not mean that a chemical has been assessed for potential health or environmental hazards. Automatic entry for chemicals listed overseas, without any assessment, would perpetuate the current situation where chemicals can come onto the Australian market without any information as to the health or environmental hazards and appropriate safety recommendations.

As I say, the Australian Chemical Industry Council has endorsed and welcomed this particular Bill, and so does the Opposition. Rather than detain the Senate in the committee stage, I will simply raise with the Minister on duty the one matter which does give some concern as far as this Bill is concerned and seek some response; that is, the concern which is felt by the Opposition about the possibility that section 31 (2) of the Bill could lead to undue delays and costs to the applicant for assessment. The Bill clearly envisages that an assessment is normally to be made within a 90-day period. However, section 31 (2) provides for the 90 days to be restarted if further information is required. While section 27 allows the applicant to appeal against a request for further information, the appeal process itself could involve substantial delay and extra costs. The procedure therefore has the potential to lead to significant bureaucratic delays in assessing the chemicals. At this stage the Opposition does not propose to seek an amendment to the Bill, rather to seek clarification from the Minister on the way in which this will operate. I indicate that we will be closely monitoring the administration of the scheme and will seek to amend the legislation if there appear to be undue and unnecessary delays in assessing chemicals under this scheme.

I turn to the more complex and more significant Bill, the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill 1989. The legislation that we now face proposes a system for the control of the import and export of hazardous wastes by use of ministerial permits. The objective of the exercise is to ensure that such wastes are disposed of in an environmentally acceptable manner. In March 1989 the Basel Convention on the Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and Their Disposal was adopted and is now open for signature and ratification. This Bill would enable Australia to meet the requirements of the Basel Convention with regard to transboundary movements of such wastes.

While the Bill adopts definitions and principles found in the Basel Convention-that is to say it adopts them in the main; we will come back in the committee stage to the question of their adequate adoption of the definitions in the Basel Convention-it should be noted that the Commonwealth clearly possesses the power to regulate this matter in any event through existing constitutional powers over customs, exports and imports. Consequently, adherence to the Basel Convention does not, I believe, increase the Commonwealth's powers over the States, nor make what I would characterise as improper use of the external affairs power. The permit scheme provides that all decisions made by the Minister are subject to judicial review and the scheme will be self-financing as there will be a fee of up to $4,000 prescribed to cover the costs of administering the Act. It should be noted that the scheme excludes control of radioactive wastes as these are not dealt with in the Basel Convention and, in any event, are the subject of other Australian legislation already in place.

For the last few years concern has been increasing about the dumping of toxic wastes from major industrial producers, in particular on to the Third World. We have seen ships such as the Zenobia, the Khian Sea and the Karin-B roaming the high seas in search of a port to offload their cargoes of toxic wastes and being denied entry to ports on four continents. This particular matter was already under scrutiny, first through a proposed OECD agreement in 1984, and then by the United Nations Environment Program (UNEP) which took over the work in 1987. At the same time steps for a regional control mechanism were being developed within our own region and, in particular, within the Association of South East Asian Nations. I refer to an article by Amado Tolentino, the director of the Environmental Management Bureau in the Philippines, which appeared in the journal Industry and Environment in early 1988, entitled `Hazardous waste management in the ASEAN: an emerging regime'. Lengthy articles similarly appeared in popular magazines such as Time and Newsweek drawing attention to the increasing profile that this issue was receiving in various international fora. Under this pressure, and under the auspices of the UNEP, the Basel Convention was developed and in its final session was approved by 105 of the 116 participating countries. The Convention has so far been signed by 34 countries, or thereabouts, including Canada, France, the Philippines, the European Community, Belgium, Italy, Norway, Sweden, the Netherlands, Spain, plus several countries in Latin America and the Middle East.

Concern has also been expressed about the need to develop a stricter code within the EC and for OECD countries and a lead has been taken in this area by the new British Secretary of State for the Environment, Mr Christopher Patten. Indeed, on 21 August 1989 Mr Patten put out a statement entitled, `The movement and disposal of toxic wastes', in which he said in part:
. . . the disposal of waste throughout the world raises questions which can only be dealt with effectively internationally.

This Bill and the Basel Convention are an attempt to deal with those matters on that international level. Support for the Basel Convention is widespread, although it must be conceded that the Convention is drawn primarily to protect the Third World countries by casting an onus upon the exporting nations to prevent their waste producers from exporting toxic wastes to vulnerable destinations. This, for example, is apparent in the inclusion of controls of exports of what are defined as `categories of wastes requiring special consideration' so as to include certain household wastes and residues arising from their incineration. This reflects a primary concern with the dumping of ash containing heavy metals and dioxins or the mercury-cadmium wastes from batteries.

While Australia has major problems with the inadequate storage of its own domestic toxic wastes-for example, problems at Botany in New South Wales, or at Kingston near Brisbane-and while there are disputes about the development and location of high-temperature waste disposal facilities, the subject of a study involving the Commonwealth, New South Wales and Victoria at this very time, we are not at the moment an importer of any toxic wastes. The matter is subject, as I have said, to a current tripartite inquiry involving the Commonwealth, New South Wales and Victoria which I regret is taking far longer than it should have done and in which an urgent decision is required as a matter of some national significance.

In recent years Australian toxic wastes have occasionally been incinerated at sea-for example in 1982 on the incinerator ship the Vulcanus. However, virtually all of our significant toxic waste is exported to Pontypool in Wales for incineration. The main wastes exported appear to be polychlorinated biphenyls derived primarily from the operations of electricity commissions around Australia. Indeed, it is of interest that this trade appears to be virtually a monopoly in terms of the handling and transportation in the hands of TNT Ltd.

I will not deal at length with the actual proposed scheme; I will simply mention something about it in broad outline. An operator seeking to import or export hazardous waste must get a permit from the Minister, who must be satisfied that the applicant is a fit and proper person to receive a permit, that he has adequate insurance cover, that the waste can be disposed of in an environmentally acceptable fashion, and that the receiving country has agreed to accept the waste in question. Decisions on permits are subject to Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act appeals and determination. A permit may be refused if the Minister considers that, having regard to Australia's international obligations, the waste should be dealt with in another way; if it can be disposed of safely within Australia; or the grant of the permit is contrary to the public interest. A fee may be levied for the permit. I am glad to say that in clause 17 there is an absolute prohibition on the export of hazardous wastes to the Antarctic. Details of permit application and grants must be notified in the Gazette and decisions must be made within specified periods. The Minister has power to deal with illegally imported wastes and may order their export, or that they be otherwise dealt with. In these cases the Minister may seek to recover the consequential costs from offenders through the courts. Failure to operate according to this system carries a potential maximum penalty of a five-year prison sentence. Inspectors are to be appointed to run the scheme with the usual powers granted in these circumstances. An annual report is to be provided to the Parliament and regulations are made in such a way as to allow the schedule to the Act to be kept current with the provisions of the appropriate annexes of the Basel Convention.

When this Bill was first introduced it was presented to me as shadow Minister for the environment. I suggested a number of changes which might be made to the legislation. I simply want to acknowledge the changes that have been made between the Bill in its draft from and the Bill in its final form. Perhaps the most interesting of these was that in the draft Bill, which was first presented to the House of Representatives, clause 18 provided for a system of determining whether an applicant was a `fit and proper person'. In the light of the various decisions about Mr Bond and the definition of the term `fit and proper person', I drew the attention of the Government to the fact that I thought that the old clause 18 was quite irrelevant and, in particular, that in determining the question of `fit and proper person', the Minister should have regard to such things as-and I quote from the Bill as it was first presented:
(a) any conviction of the applicant for an offence against this Act committed within 10 years before the Minister received the application;-
which was probably fair enough-

(b) any conviction of the applicant for an offence against another law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory that is punishable by imprisonment for 12 months or longer, being an offence committed within 10 years before the Minister received the application . . .

I thought that is was drawing a particularly long bow in dealing with environmental matters that the Minister was required to take into account a conviction of the applicant for a breach of the traffic laws or similar laws and that such a conviction could be held against the applicant in determining his `fit and proper' status to operate as an exporter or importer of hazardous waste. After some discussions, the Government introduced amendments to provide that the old clause 18 be dropped entirely. In the current clause 17 (1) (c) which we now have before us under the heading `Grant of permits', the Minister has to be satisfied in relation to the granting of a permit with regard to the following matters:
(i) the applicants financial viability; and
(ii) the applicant's previous record in relation to environmental matters;-
which was the key that I was trying to establish-
and (iii) any other relevant matters . . .
That gives the Minister the power to take into account a whole range of extraneous matters, but subject to Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act procedures.

The second change that was made arose largely from recommendations, I think, of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills to provide in clause 51 that the length of currency of the warrant be reduced from one month to seven days. There was a minor amendment to clause 17 (5) to insert the word `safely', to read:
The Minister may decide not to grant the permit if the permit sought is an export permit and the Minister thinks that:
(a) the hazardous waste could be disposed of safely by using a facility in Australia . . .

That, again, is a minor amendment. There has been a change in that the original Bill only had attached to it annex III to the Basel Convention. At my request, the Government has now attached annexes I, II, II and IV of the Basel Convention as schedules to the Bill, so that people reading the Bill will be able to read it in a more complete fashion without having to refer to the very lengthy document which constitutes the Basel Convention in its entirety. Finally, in the House of Representatives a moment of history, almost, was made-it probably was a moment of history-when my colleague Mr Warwick Smith moved an amendment to the Bill which actually succeeded. Clause 10 (2) of the original Bill said:
Nothing in this Act permits the Crown to be prosecuted for an offence.
In the House of Representatives we moved to delete that provision. Despite the conniptions of the Attorney-General's Department, it was deleted. The Clause 10 now says:
This Act binds the Crown in right of the Commonwealth, of each of the States, of the Australian Capital Territory, of the Northern Territory and of Norfolk Island.

It no longer contains the exemption of the Crown from being prosecuted for breaches of the Act. That is a very valuable addition to the Bill. The Crown, after all, in terms of its own possession or its own responsibility in these matters, should not seek to come to the Parliament and ask the Parliament to say that everybody else should be subject to prosecution for breaches of the Act other than the Crown. It is only if we are particularly vigilant to ensure that the Crown in this respect stands on equal footing with any company or any individual citizen in Australia that we have adequate controls of these particular matters. I am glad that the amendment which was moved by Mr Smith on behalf of the Opposition in the House of Representatives was successful.

I will wait until we reach the committee stage of the Bill to deal with a matter which I know Senator Coulter wishes to raise and which, I am sure, he will indicate as being the basis of some discussion that has taken place between us in order to improve what we regard as the adequacy of coverage of this legislation. I will wait until the committee stage to talk about the amendment which Senator Coulter will be putting forward.

As I said, this is an important Bill. Not only are countries of the Third World quite genuinely concerned but countries such as Nigeria and Guinea-Bissau are finding themselves unwillingly the recipients of noxious, hazardous wastes left on their coastlines, dumped on their shores, and often imported as a result of bribery and corruption that takes place within those countries' administrations. They will be protected by the regime of the Basel Convention, provided they are signatories to it. There is a very clear indication that people should take responsibility for their own toxic waste, that they should dump in their own backyard if they are going to dump anywhere. It is an argument which has some relevance to the point we have been making about French nuclear tests. There are certain things we ought to be able to do in our own backyard and certain things that we should not do in other people's backyards.

TALK.START.PARA: —And there are some things you should not do anywhere.

—There are some things, as the Minister says, that we should not do anywhere. This Bill does not prevent things from being done at all; it simply regulates where they shall be done. It is not a matter of simply ignoring the significant problems we have within Australia. Earlier this month a major explosion at the Diversey Industrial Chemicals plant in Seven Hills in Sydney led to massive clouds of toxic smoke being swept over large parts of the western suburbs of Sydney for a considerable time. Among the chemicals stored in that plant were chemicals such as methylated chlorine, caustic soda, chlorine, sulphuric acid, nitric acid and sodium hypochlorite. Under the regime of both these Bills, those chemicals need close attention. There are outstanding problems in the use of heptachlor and chlordane for white-ant treatment in buildings. There is increasing public concern about the level of chemical storage in our major metropolitan areas and about the effective control of their transport and disposal.

SPEECH.PARA: I am disappointed that we have not yet got a final recommendation out of the tripartite government study on the location of a high temperature waste incinerator. That committee has had adequate time to get on with its work. We ought to be looking at some positive recommendations, particularly since New South Wales has made it clear that it is prepared to play host to such a facility and that as a result there will not be a brawl between the Commonwealth and State as to the establishment of the facility. We will need the time, the resources and the expertise of all concerned to establish the appropriate site for that facility to be developed. That will be no easy task. The sooner it is started, the sooner we will get a resolution of the whole thing.

This legislation also has the support of the Australian Environment Council. It was first suggested as the correct way to proceed by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts in its first report on the inquiry into hazardous chemicals which took place and reported in 1982. The Opposition will support both of these Bills. We look forward to the Minister's response to the question I raised on the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Bill and some of the comments which I have raised during this second reading debate. I look forward to further discussion on some of those issues at the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The theme I wish to develop during the second reading stage of this debate is that, as someone who has been active as a research scientist for a number of years dealing with hazardous chemicals and also someone who has had a long term interest in the environment, I am very pleased to see these two Bills, the Hazardous Waste (Regulations of Exports and Imports) Bill 1989 and the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Bill 1989, coming forward. I recognise that they have been a long time in coming forward and that, indeed, other complementary legislation also needs to be passed. These two Bills are part of a package of Bills. The package is still incomplete. The package has been a long time coming but, nonetheless, we are pleased to see this part of it.

SPEECH.PARA: We are dealing this morning with Bills relating to notification and assesssment and the import and export of hazardous wastes. The notification Bill has been a long time in coming. Indeed, for many years I was one of the substitute members of an advisory committee on behalf of the Australian Conservation Foundation dealing with this matter, and it seemed to progress very slowly indeed. The inventory to be established under this legislation will be a list of chemicals. It will be largely composed of or based on information provided by those who import, manufacture, use, market, et cetera, chemicals in Australia and will provide a basis of information, and the database will better serve the protection of the environment, workers and people in the community generally. The scheme will be administered by Worksafe Australia and, of course, that organisation has recently been created by this Government. That is another element in the program for the control of hazardous chemicals.

This legislation, of course, does not place any controls on the chemicals as such. It will simply act as a database of information, but that database of information is a prerequisite for any controls which could be imposed later on either by the States or the Commonwealth. There has been a presumption over many years that many chemicals used industrially do not find their way into the general environment. Indeed, that presumption has been extended also in the past to therapeutic drugs and agricultural chemicals. For a long time, we suffered the ridiculous assumption that the organochlorin pesticides used on food crops, because they were used to deal with pests on food crops, did not find their way into the human food chain and, therefore, did not pose a hazard to human health and, moreover, that they did not get off-site and did not pose a hazard to the environment. Fortunately, we have gone beyond that and now recognise that chemicals used as therapeutic agents, agricultural chemicals or, indeed, industrial chemicals very often do leave the site where those chemicals are used and turn up in other situations where they pose a hazard to the environment and to human health. So this legislation, the notification scheme, will ensure that these industrial chemicals are evaluated before they enter the Australian market and that other chemicals can be called back from time to time for review.

I stress the point-because it has turned up a number of times in my experience in relation to the knowledge of chemicals, and the qualities of chemicals-that in the past very often particular qualities have led to chemicals being dealt with in ways which perhaps were adequate in the short term but totally inadequate in the long term. On a number of occasions we have seen spills of industrial chemicals, perhaps from road tankers. Firemen who are often called in to clean up these spills are perhaps aware of the short-term nature of the hazard. For instance, they might be aware that a particular chemical is inflammable and, therefore, they address the problem as if they are dealing with an inflammable agent which may cause a conflagration and do damage to property, but very often they are not informed about the long term hazards such as the ability of a chemical to cause mutations or cancers in those who are exposed to it.

Indeed, several years ago a group of firemen in Canberra were exposed to the chemical toluene di-isocyanate, often called TDI, and were ill-informed as to the extreme hazard associated with that chemical in relation to long-term health problems. Very briefly, toluene di-isocyanate is a chemical which can cross-bond naturally occurring agents in the body and make naturally occurring chemicals in the body appear like foreign chemicals, against which the body then makes an antibody. So toluene di-isocyanate is a supremely active agent in stimulating such things as asthma, eczema and chronic allergic-type skin diseases. Firemen who dealt with that spill in Canberra are still attempting to get compensation for a situation which should never have developed in the first place.

Hopefully, as further information develops, the database which will come from this notification scheme will allow the accumulation of more and more accurate information in relation to effects still on the periphery of recognition. I am reminded that some years ago a study was undertaken in Sweden in relation to workers exposed to paint solvents at levels well below the levels which were accepted as hazardous. Nonetheless, those workers were experiencing a whole range of psychological symptoms such as headaches, insomnia, poor concentration and the like. Hopefully, the collection of data will progressively allow an improvement in our knowledge of those situations and give better protection to both the environment and human populations.

Finally, on this Bill, it is highly desirable in this area that there be uniform controls imposed by the Commonwealth and that, as far as possible, those individual controls imposed by the States, which vary very often from State to State, can be superseded so that one is then dealing with one set of notifications, one database, one lot of information, which can be improved and that that will be to the benefit of both the regulators and regulated.

Turning to the import and export provisions in the other Bill, when populations were small and humans lived as gatherers and hunters, nomadic existence led itself to a certain amount of nest fouling. When a hunter-gatherer site because too polluted a tribe would move on and establish itself at a new site. The waste left behind, being organic, would slowly return to the soil and after a time the tribe could return to the same site without fear of being poisoned or infected by transmissible disease. But since the rise of industrialisation, and especially since the Second World War, the chemical industry has produced an increasing range of novel chemicals which had not been experienced before by nature and for which nature has no mechanism for breakdown. The whole class of halogenated organic compounds used in plastics, pesticides, refrigerants, fire-extinguishants, solvents and a large number of other applications are of this sort. When this class of compound came into widespread use it was generally reckoned to have great advantages precisely because these compounds were so stable. This was especially the case with the organochlorin pesticides. We now understand that this stability is a two-edged sword. Those compounds are very hard to destroy. If discarded into the environment, they continue to pose a hazard for very long periods. Many are acutely toxic; many are mutagenic; and many are carcinogenic. While the latter qualities may not be particularly important in nature, they are, of course, extremely important in relation to human exposure. Human populations are now so large that we can no longer leave our fouled nests and travel to fresh, unpolluted sites. Even if we did, the sites contaminated with halogenated organics and the other hazardous wastes with which this Bill deals would remain polluted for a very long period.

It is against that type of background that we are considering the question of the import and export of hazardous wastes. They form part, but only part, as I indicated earlier, of a package that has been a long time coming. We need the whole package to manage properly this very important matter. One very important missing element, an element to which Senator Puplick referred a moment ago, is an Australian high temperature incinerator to dispose finally of these hazardous and intractable wastes. In November 1985 a meeting of the Australian Environment Council dealt with the question of movement of hazardous waste and said:

The OECD of which Australia is a member, has decided that such international movements should be controlled. Australia has yet to formally endorse the Decision. Control of imports and exports is formally within the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth . . .

I make the point that that meeting was four years ago and it has taken four years for this legislation to come forward. The Australian Democrats are grateful that we now have such legislation, but we have been frustrated that it has taken so long to legislate in an area of such importance. A comprehensive scheme for handling these agents will involve not only a notification scheme and an import and export scheme, but also mechanisms for waste minimisation and for recycling as well as for destruction. We hope that these other parts will not be so long in coming.

The Commonwealth has been tardy in accepting its overriding responsibility in most aspects of the control of hazardous chemicals: their manufacture, transport, storage and destruction. On several occasions I have raised questions about proposals to establish petrochemical plants manufacturing plastic precursors. Senator Richardson has consistently expressed the view that such matters are State concerns. In every such proposal, and there have been four in South Australia and one in Western Australia, there has been unnecessary exposure of populations and the environment to ethylene dichloride (EDC) and vinyl chloride monomer (VCM), two compounds which are intermediates-I stress that-in the path to the manufacture of polyvinyl chloride (PVC). Both these compounds are mutagenic and carcinogenic, and vinyl chloride monomer is highly inflammable. In a well-designed continuous production plant neither of these hazardous chemicals would be present in very large amounts. In every proposal floated in Australia so far, these highly toxic intermediates have been intended for export-a totally unnecessary activity-with the finishing of the process occurring in some other part of the world.

In the most recent proposal at Kwinana on Cockburn Sound it was intended that there should be two 10,000-tonne tanks of EDC and VCM on the foreshore awaiting shipment overseas. When the question of a possible leak of vinyl chloride monomer was raised, the environmental consultant with Petrochemical Industries Co. Ltd, the company responsible for developing the proposal, naively defended the storage of 10,000 tonnes of vinyl chloride monomer by pointing out that the tanks would be bunded, that is, surrounded by a moat to collect the spill. I suspect that at that stage he did not know that vinyl chloride monomer boils at minus 14 degrees Celsius. A spill of such a magnitude of either ethylene dichloride or vinyl chloride monomer, under the usual conditions of a south-westerly wind which prevail in that area of the world, would necessitate the evacuation of the whole of the Perth metropolitan area. Yet the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, said that this is a State matter and is not to be legislated for at the Commonwealth level. We are now manufacturing some very dangerous chemicals indeed, and these are often handled in very large amounts. There is a need to minimise the risks as far as possible, both at source and at the transport and disposal end. There is a need for uniform Federal control of all stages of the manufacture, handling and disposal of these agents. The Federal Government has the power under the corporations power of the Constitution; it should use that power.

The volumes of hazardous wastes are very large. The United States, which has more heavy chemical industry than any other country, is accumulating such waste at the rate of 265 million tonnes per year. Some 57 million tonnes of this is organic waste. It is estimated that over the last 35 years some six billion tonnes have been generated. The United States has not handled this waste very well. Over the years hazardous chemical wastes have been disposed of into ordinary land fill and by way of deep well injection. Land fill sites have sometimes been built on and have resulted in such things as the Love Canal phenomenon. Deep well injection has resulted in very long term contamination of ground water. Disposal in land fill has also been practised in Australia.

The recent Four Corners program dealing with the intolerable situation in the Brisbane suburb of Kingston, in which residents had to evacuate their homes as a consequence, comes to mind. The people in Kingston were living in houses built over an old mine that had been filled with waste. The waste eventually oozed up through the ground. People were ill for quite a long time before the health authorities took action and moved the residents. Decontamination of this site is probably impossible, and the area will remain a no-man's land for the indefinite future. It seems to the Australian Democrats that this is an excellent example of what sustainable development does not mean. No generation should be closing options for later generations in this way.

The situation in the United States is much worse. Some 8,660 sites where hazardous wastes have been dumped have been identified, almost a thousand in the State of Michigan alone. So serious is this problem that the United States has created what it calls a super fund to clean up the worst of these sites. In the most dangerous category, 1,177 sites have been identified. A recent report suggests that the cost of this clean-up will be some $500 billion over the next 50 years. Very few sites have actually been cleaned up, and even this estimate may grossly underestimate the ultimate cost. The real cost may be leaving future generations with permanently contaminated no-go areas.

Just as Alvin Weinberg a number of years ago proposed a permanent priestly class to care in perpetuity for nuclear waste, we may need such a class of dedicated citizens to care for these dangerous, chemically contaminated sites. Where deep soil injection has been practised, there is no way of decontaminating ground water. The water in situ remains unusable. Expensive chemical decontamination may make a small amount usable for human consumption, but at a very high price. A large part of the ground water in the United States is now contaminated with identifiable chemicals which have been so injected into deep wells.

The various Australian States have considered the problem of hazardous waste and have concluded that the problem relates particularly to chlorinated hydrocarbon wastes, in particular to polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs). These substances have been used for a number of years as transformer coolants. They are also used in a number of other settings, including self-copying paper used for receipt books, prescription pads and a whole range of other things. There have been cases of acute poisoning where PCBs were mixed with cooking oil in Japan and a large number of people were acutely poisoned. But the principal concern is over their persistence in the environment and in body tissues, where they accumulate-their bio-accumulation-and their mutagenicity and carcinogenicity. The many examples of chemicals of this class therefore pose a long term and delayed threat to both the environment and human health.

In the same general class are the polybrominated biphenyls, which have been used as fire retardants and share the properties of PCBs. These are only a small part of the enormous range of halogenated organic compounds which need to be handled and disposed of with a great deal of care. As already mentioned, compounds of this general class do not occur naturally and, therefore, all of them pose problems for the environment. It is easier-and I want to stress this point-to regard all of them as hazardous than to argue about individual chemicals. That goes to the matter of the amendment that I shall move in the committee stage of this debate.

Another group of compounds of this general class with which we will need to deal as a matter of urgency in the next few years includes the chlorofluorocarbons and the halons. As these are recalled from use in refrigerators, air-conditioners and fire extinguishers they will need to be stored safely, in many cases under pressure. I remind the Senate that freon 12 boils at something like minus 30 degrees Celsius. This underscores the urgency of the establishment of a high temperature incinerator in Australia. In the early 1970s-as I recall, about 1971 or 1972-the South Australian Jordan report made a strong call for a high temperature incinerator to dispose of organochlorine pesticides. It is an indictment of successive Australian governments that we still lack such a facility.

It is estimated that about 8,000 tonnes of chlorinated organic waste are in storage in Australia. Ninety-five per cent of this is in New South Wales, and 95 per cent of that is at the ICI Australia plant at Botany Bay. The rate of generation of these wastes is about 800 tonnes per year. Of this, 700 tonnes, or 88 per cent, is generated in New South Wales. These compounds often turn up as unwanted side reaction products in the manufacture of intended end products. Of course, that is exactly the situation at the ICI plant at Botany, where these materials accumulate as a result of the manufacturing process of a range of other quite valuable chemicals.

Much of this waste is now stored in drums, where it slowly polymerises and becomes solid. This creates further difficulties for its disposal in a high temperature incinerator. In Australia such an incinerator would need a capacity of about 1,500 tonnes per year, which is very small by world standards but essential for the safety of the Australian environment. It follows that, therefore, we need one incinerator, not two. The Federal Government should resist Western Australian plans for an incinerator on the goldfields or elsewhere in Western Australia. A well-run high temperature incinerator poses no threat to the environment or to the health of nearby residents. Disposing of wastes in this way is much safer than leaving these toxic materials lying around in rusting drums from which they must from time to time be decanted or transferred into fresh containers.

One principle to which governments must adhere is that the polluter pays. The cost of properly dealing with these materials is considerable and acts as a strong incentive to minimise waste generation. The present practice of exporting wastes overseas is more costly than burning them in an Australian incinerator. This may act as an incentive in the other direction-namely, illegally to dump hazardous wastes into sewers or land fill in this country.

The Government is to be congratulated for bringing forward these two Bills, which are long overdue and form part of a package of necessary legislation for the proper handling of hazardous wastes. This matter should be legislated at the national, not State, level. Pieces of the necessary package are still missing and there is an urgency about putting these other elements into place. Australia must have a high temperature incinerator which should be sited in New South Wales, preferably at the ICI works, so that the largest portion of these wastes do not have to be transported.

The former Labor Government in New South Wales mismanaged the public relations aspect of this proposal so as to make it unacceptable to the people living nearby-the so-called NIMBY not in my back yard phenomenon. Making a national decision may avoid some of this problem. Other components of the waste management strategy which need national attention are waste minimisation, standards for major chemical plants such as petrochemical plants-and I stress that these are all national requirements-and waste recycling. The Australian Democrats support the Bills, with one amendment, and express the hope that it will not be too long before we see the rest of this necessary package.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill 1989. During his second reading speech, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to control the export and import of hazardous wastes in order to protect human health and the environment. The Act will enable Australia to take part in international measures to control the movement of hazardous wastes which also have this objective.
He went on to say:
. . . several of the obligations in the convention-
that is, the Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and Their Disposal-

such as the requirement to minimise waste production and the provision of acceptable disposal facilities, fall within the responsibilities of State and Territory Governments. Therefore the controls introduced by this Bill will be complemented by State and Territory waste management legislation.

Being aware of the problems which have been experienced in Western Australia with regard to the transport and disposal of hazardous wastes, I welcome the introduction of this legislation which will lead to improvements in the way in which this waste is handled. Protecting human health and the environment through improving the way we manage hazardous wastes is a matter of great public interest, especially in Western Australia. The debate has been more widespread over the last two years as a result of the now defunct proposal to construct a petrochemical plant at Kwinana. That proposal has had a great deal of publicity. As well as exporting the hazardous substances, previously mentioned by my Australian Democrat colleague Senator John Coulter, the proposed plant would have also produced large quantities of intractable wastes.

The proposals put forward to dispose of such wastes have favoured high temperature incineration, with the Western Australian Health Department choosing a site at Mount Walton in the Eastern Goldfields in Western Australia. The proposal has been opposed by residents in the area and it seems that wherever a high temperature incinerator is proposed public opposition is sure to follow-the `not in my back yard' routine. Many Western Australians are not convinced that such an incinerator will operate to the high standards promised by the Government. A similar type of incinerator is proposed for the Eastern Goldfields by the joint task force on intractable wastes which was set up to find solutions for hazardous wastes, which originate predominantly in eastern Australia.

While I commend the joint task force for its preliminary report of April 1988, I can not support all of its conclusions. The two-volume report summarised the serious position which exists in Australia in respect of intractable wastes. The brochure describing the report, entitled The Management of Intractable Wastes, compiled by the Commonwealth, New South Wales and Victorian governments, says:

Australia does not have proper disposal facilities for some of the chemical wastes it produces. While these wastes are only a small proportion of the total hazardous waste stream, they are harmful to the environment because they do not break down easily. Known as `intractable' wastes, they include wastes containing polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), mainly from electrical equipment; hexachlorobenzene and other residues from plastics manufacture; and organochlorine pesticides such as DDT and dieldrin. It is estimated that 9,100 tonnes of this material is stockpiled, 3,000 tonnes is still in service and 425 tonnes is generated each year. It is probable that further detailed surveys will reveal significant extra quantities of organochlorines requiring destruction.

Only one overseas facility, a high temperature incinerator in Wales, has been prepared to accept waste from Australia and there is no guarantee that this option will continue. The cost and risk associated with transporting wastes overseas for disposal has led to large quantities of wastes being stored. Long-term storage is unacceptable because of the risk of accident through spillage or fire.

While I agree with the report's statement that Australia needs a safe and environmentally sound management and disposal system in Australia, in Western Australia the immediate problems arising from the stockpiles of intractable wastes must be addressed. The unsatisfactory situation with regard to stockpiles of hazardous wastes such as PCBs is a major cause of community concern in Western Australia. I refer in particular to the situation in respect of a recent proposal for the disposal of PCB waste from Mount Newman Mining Pty Ltd. The original intent was to export the waste but with very few details about the proposal being publicly available. Although this matter was referred to the Environmental Protection Authority of Western Australia initially the proposal to ship the PCBs overseas to a destination not at that time determined was to be assessed only at an internal level by the Department. However, in response to appeals by concerned citizens the Western Australian Minister for the Environment has determined that the proposal should be assessed publicly as a public environmental report. While the decision to conduct a formal public environmental assessment for the disposal of the PCBs is welcome, had it not been for the appeals by concerned Western Australians to the Minister it is unlikely that the assessment would have been public. I would like to point out that each individual citizen who wishes to put in this sort of appeal has to pay the price of $10.

A further concern about this proposal to dispose of PCB waste overseas is that at precisely the same time the Western Australian Government has been promoting the construction of a high temperature incinerator. I believe that the logical procedure at present is to ensure that intractable wastes such as PCBs are safely stored on site in Western Australia until an environmentally acceptable solution is found for their disposal. The transport of hazardous wastes over the long distances in Western Australia poses grave dangers which are not solved by the decision to construct an incinerator in the Eastern Goldfields. While the stockpile of PCB wastes is causing concern, Western Australia also has a problem with the storage and disposal of agricultural organochlorin chemicals. Following on from the detection of residues or organochlorin chemicals in Western Australia's beef for export, the Agriculture Department in Western Australia bought back farmers' supplies of these chemicals. I am reliably informed that these chemicals then became a storage and disposal problem for the Department of Agriculture. I am not sure that their disposal has been satisfactorily dealt with.

The need to provide for the public to be well informed and have access to accurate information on the disposal of hazardous waste is paramount. The Bill before the chamber at present should overcome some of the deficiencies that concerned citizens are experiencing in Western Australia. Australia needs to set high standards for ensuring safe transit and disposal of intractable wastes. Equally important is the need to give more emphasis to ensuring that production of intractable wastes is, in the first instance, minimised.

While I believe that much stronger action needs to be taken by Australia in addressing this issue from the Western Australian perspective I support many of the provisions in the Bill. I welcome the legislation as a first step in improving accountability for transport of hazardous waste worldwide-a problem which has become more serious in recent years. However, I urge the Government, once it becomes a party to the Basel Convention, to use its good reputation to strengthen the Basel Convention so that it more truly reflects the rising community concerns about disposal and transport of hazardous waste. I join with my Democrat colleague Senator John Coulter in stating that if this is not achieved it may be that the positive aspects of the legislation will be nullified by some sections which could lead to more problems than exist in Australia at present with regard to the transport and disposal of hazardous waste.
