TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Puplick referred to the 90-day question during his contribution earlier. I would like to address that first. I think the first point that needs to be made is that the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Bill 1989 has been arrived at after literally years of consultation between government and industry. We did not pluck the 90-day figure out of the air without considerable care. I believed that there was no real dispute about this until comparatively recently. I think some people in the industry got a bit windy that perhaps they had given too much. Obviously, it does place some burden on them in that it will be to their advantage in notifying to include in the statement every possible piece of information. That is important.

SPEECH.PARA: When one tries to extend that 90-day period obviously the director, a senior person appointed by the Governor-General, will be responsible for making a decision. Given that any decision the director is to make is reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and subject to queries from the Ombudsman, I doubt very much whether the director will not take that sort of responsibility lightly and leave himself or herself open to a successful challenge. Written into the provisions of the Bill is a sufficient restraint upon the activities of the director in that respect. In any event, I think it is also the case that, if the notifier has included all the relevant information in the first place, there is no reason for the assessment to take 90 days on every occasion. In fact, I am advised that it can take much less. Indeed, the Government would aim to have it take much less. Obviously, 90 days is for those difficult assessments. Given the sorts of chemicals referred to in the debate there are obviously plenty of those. Every time this matter gets debated I hear about some new ones. I am very confident that the 90-day rule will not be a hindrance to industry or to those doing the assessing. Rather, it will focus their minds on the job. At the end of the day the decision is reviewable.

Prior to the committee stage I should also like to indicate that the amendment proposed by Senator Coulter touches on the reversal of the onus of proof. I find that to be of concern. I hope that the Australian Democrats and the Opposition have considered that in indicating their support for the amendment. I am always concerned about reversals of onus. It is a point that I will make when we get to the committee stage. I certainly share most of the concerns raised by Senator Coulter and Senator Jenkins. There are considerable difficulties that we all face with chemicals in the coming years. Whether I should propose the use of the corporations power to regulate every step in the process as Senator Coulter suggests is one point on which we might disagree. I would have thought that it would be very difficult to get the sort of cooperation that we have been able to get from the States in a Bill such as this. It must be remembered that I mentioned consultation with industry; the States have been right through this process. I think I have rattled the odd sabre about Commonwealth power but I hope not without purpose. I am a long way from being convinced that the States do not share the concern of the Democrats and my concern about some of these very dangerous substances. I hope that there will be no need for us to act in the manner in which the Democrats have prescribed in the future. I have been reminded that I should have tabled the revised explanatory memorandum. I neglected to do so, so I take this opportunity to do so.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: HAZARDOUS WASTE (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS) BILL 1989
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 3, clause 4, definition of ``hazardous waste'', before paragraph (a) insert the following new paragraph:

``(aa) wastes that belong to any category contained in Annex 1 to the Basel Convention (a copy of the English text of which annex is set out in the Schedule), unless they do not possess any of the characteristics contained in Annex III to that Convention; or''.

The Australian Democrats have only one amendment to clause 4 of the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill 1989. The amendment, which has been circulated, deals with the definition of hazardous waste. I think it is worth while reading out the words which are in the Bill at the moment. It states:
`hazardous waste' means:
(a) waste that has any of the characteristics mentioned in Annex III to the Basel Con- vention . . .
The Bill then explains that a copy of the English text is attached and it continues:
(b) household waste; or
(c) residues arising from the incineration of household waste;

When we turn to the Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and their Disposal we find a number of annexes attached to it. Annex I, which is headed `Categories of Wastes to be Controlled', lists a number of what it calls `waste streams' and it goes on to refer to wastes having as constituents certain things. Annex II, which is headed `Categories of Wastes Requiring Special Consideration', contains only two entries:
Wastes collected from households
Residues arising from the incineration of household wastes.

Annex III, which is headed `List of Hazardous Characteristics', has a number of characteristics such as explosives, flammable liquids, flammable solids, et cetera, and it concludes-and this is interesting-with ecotoxics under paragraph H12, which is a lovely term which I wish we used more in Australian legal circles. Paragraph H12 states:
Ecotoxic Substances or wastes which if released present or may present immediate or delayed adverse impacts to the environment by means of bioaccumulation and/or toxic effects upon biotic systems.
That is a lovely characteristic but it is very hard to prove exactly. Similarly, paragraph H11 states:
Toxic (Delayed or chronic)
Substances or wastes which, if they are inhaled or ingested or if they penetrate the skin, may involve delayed or chronic effects, including carcinogenicity.

Only a week or so ago we were debating the Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements (Prohibition) Bill. In the course of that debate I think all honourable senators were reminded about the rearguard action which has been fought for years and years by the tobacco industry over whether tobacco posed a carcinogenic hazard for humans. Also in recent weeks we have been looking again at asbestos and we have a long history of legal battles in this country in relation to whether asbestos poses a hazard to human health, particularly in relation to carcinogenicity, with companies battling very hard to attempt to establish that neither of those substances was carcinogenic. With my long experience, both in the environment movement and as a research scientist, a combination of those things has brought me into conflict with chemical company after chemical company over the years as to whether their chemicals posed precisely that sort of hazard.

Some honourable senators may recall my raising, in the context of agricultural chemicals, the substance dibromochloropropane (DBCP). I made the claim in this place that DBCP caused sterility in male rats and that was known to the Dow Chemical Co. as early as 1960, that it failed to make that information available and, as a result, a number of workers in the Occidental Chemical Corporation in California became sterile in the mid-1970s and this eventually led to the banning of DBCP. I have a very strong note from the Dow Chemical Co. saying that that original paper in 1960 did not show sterility in male rats. I went back and had a look at that paper and found that that paper showed that the testes of those male rats simply atrophied. It did not exactly show that the chemical caused sterility, but simply that the male rats' testes atrophied. So I have decades of experience in arguing with chemical companies as to whether their agents posed precisely the sorts of hazards that are talked about in category 3.
Going back to the Bill which is before us, `hazardous waste' means:
(a) waste that has any of the characteristics mentioned in Annex III to the Basel Convention-
in other words, wastes which are defined by way of characteristics-
(b) household waste; or
(c) residues arising from the incineration of household waste;

Clearly, paragraphs (b) and (c) contain the exact words which are in Annex II of the Basel Convention. I am seeking, by way of amendment, merely to put in all the words which are in the Basel Convention; in other words, I am seeking to include Annex I. As I have said, Annex I is entitled `Categories of Waste to be Controlled'. Clearly, the Basel Convention anticipates that those substances are to be controlled. Moreover, Annex I defines those substances by way of their chemical composition. For instance, if we look at paragraph Y19 we find:
Y19 Metal carbonyls
Y20 Beryllium; beryllium compounds

And so it goes on down the list. We also find a reference to thallium, lead, mercury, tellurium, phenols and organic solvents. Paragraph Y45 refers to organohalogen compounds. The whole class of organohalogen compounds are included in Annex I and there is no argument then as to whether they are hazardous wastes. But if we turn to Article 1 of the Convention we find:
(a) Wastes that belong to any category contained in Annex I, unless they do not possess any of the characteristics contained in Annex III;

The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) is quite right in saying that that, in a sense, implies a reversal of the onus of proof. But, given the experience that we have had over a long period with arguments as to whether a substance poses a hazard, if we are to define things by characteristics-that is, by Annex III-surely it makes a great deal more sense to put in those classes of things which most disinterested scientists would accept as hazardous. The onus is on the person who wants to claim that those substances are not hazardous to establish that they do not have the characteristics of Annex III. For example, someone might be wanting to import or export a halogenated or organic solvent such as dioxins. Dioxins are a whole class of compounds. The one that is most well categorised is the so-called 2378-TCDD. We know a lot about the toxicity of that. But there are tens of other dioxins which are not so well characterised. I would stake my reputation on the fact that all of them pose similar threats, but perhaps to a varying degree, to human health and to the environment. Suppose somebody wants to dispose of a different dioxin, not the particular one that has been dealt with so much in relation to 2,4,5-T and other chemical processes: that substance would be included because we are wanting to include Annex 1. The onus would be on the person who wanted to import or export it that that substance did not pose a carcinogenic hazard or any of the other characteristics which are mentioned in Annex 3. That is precisely the way it should be. We should not be putting ourselves in the position that we have been in for years and years, in relation to those poor unfortunate workers who were exposed to asbestos in Western Australia-having to fight through the courts for compensation.

This is a reasonable situation in which we should be looking to reversal of the onus of proof, recognising that we should not be extending to chemicals the sorts of rights that we extend to human beings. We are dealing with chemicals, not human beings. Those chemicals should be categorised by class, and the onus should be on the establishment by those who would import or export those things that they do not have those characteristics which are mentioned in Annex 3. I cannot more strongly support the change which we want to make to the definition of hazardous wastes so that that definition is brought absolutely word for word into line with the Basel Convention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will support Senator Coulter's amendment. I will just recite briefly a little of the history of the development of this amendment. Some days ago Senator Coulter circulated an amendment to propose a change in the definition of hazardous waste. That original amendment read:

SPEECH.PARA: categories of waste included in Annex I to the Basel Convention (a copy of the English text of which annex is set out in the Schedule);

I indicated at that stage that I was persuaded by some of the arguments put to me by the Minister's advisers and departmental officials that, in fact, that may involve regulation of a greater number of substances and more classes of substances than was really intended, and that, in addition, the Commonwealth was laying itself open to some difficulties in terms of being required to enforce regulations which were not really appropriate. I indicated, therefore, that in that first formulation the Opposition was not in a position to support Senator Coulter's amendment.

However, when we looked at Article 1 of the Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and their Disposal, which appears on page 41 of the primary document, we found under the heading `Scope of the Convention' that Article 1 reads:
The following wastes that are subject to transbounary movement shall be ``hazardous wastes'' for the purposes of this Convention:
(a) Wastes that belong to any category contained in Annex I, unless they do not possess any of the characteristics contained in Annex III; and
(b) Wastes that are not covered under paragraph (a) but are defined as, or are considered to be, hazardous wastes by the domestic legislation of the Party of export, import or transit.

It then goes on to deal with categories of waste contained in Annex II, wastes which are radioactive, and wastes which derive from the normal operations of a ship. It was the view of the Opposition that this legislation should be brought more properly into line with the scope of the Convention as defined; that Article 1 subclause 1 (a) should in fact stand in the same words in the Bill as it does in the Convention. It is for that reason that Senator Coulter re-drew his amendment so that it now reflects accurately the words in Article 1:
wastes that belong to any category contained in Annex I to the Basel Convention . . . unless they do not possess any of the characteristics contained in Annex 3 to that Convention;

As to the second part of Article 1, paragraph 1(b)-`Wastes that are not covered under paragraph (a)'-such wastes are now defined within the legislation and therefore that is taken care of. Wastes that belong to any category contained in Annex II-which is the second major part of Article 1 of the Basel Convention-are covered in the definitional clause, which departs slightly from the exact wording of Annex II of the Basel Convention and in fact does so in a more expansive fashion, because hazardous waste is defined on page 3 of the Bill as:
(b) household waste; or
(b) residues arising from the incineration of household waste;

Therefore, the element of the wastes that have been collected, which is a test which is apparent in Annex II to the Basel Convention in its simpler form, has been refined in terms of the definition and in fact refined in a way which actually expands the definition. Annex II, headed `Categories of Wastes Requiring Special Consideration', provides:
Y46 Wastes collected from households
Y47 Residues arising from the incineration of household wastes

The formulation in the definition section of this Bill is slightly clearer and indeed somewhat wider in its scope. The other two areas contained in Article 1 of the Basel Convention-radioactive wastes, which I dealt with in the course of my speech on the second reading, and the wastes which derive from normal operations of a ship-are dealt with under all of the conventions which we have about pollution of the high seas, the MARPOL Convention, which is the international Convention for Prevention of Pollution from Ships, and the legislation which regulates the discharge of wastes from ships and vessels on the high seas, and are therefore adequately covered.

I accept the Minister's characterisation, in some respects, that this is a bit of a belt and braces job. I do not believe, however, that it in any sense detracts from the overall operation. I am conscious of some of the legal arguments that have been put about enforcement. I select the word `conscious' quite deliberately. I am conscious in that I am aware of what they are; I do not pretend for one moment actually to understand entirely what they mean. They have been put to me by a most erudite and learned adviser of the Minister. It is not her fault that after a very considerable period I am not altogether sure that she was saying anything to me other than, `You cannot trust judges'. If in fact that was what was being said, I certainly understand it, have sympathy with it and entirely agree with it. If the point was intended to be more refined and sophisticated, I simply have to apologise for my ignorance in these particular matters.

Nevertheless, the amendment which Senator Coulter has moved does, I think, two things. Firstly, it brings the definitional section of this legislation more closely into line with that which is adopted throughout the whole of the Basel Convention. Secondly, it gives us the capacity to ensure that there are no loopholes created in the way in which this Act might operate. Thirdly, I do not believe that it imposes any additional burden by way of regulatory requirements on the Commonwealth or anybody else or, indeed, that it imposes any tests upon the importers or exporters of hazardous chemicals that it is not legitimate to impose. Under those circumstances the Opposition will support Senator Coulter's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to oppose the thrust of Senator Coulter's amendment. I do not believe it will ensure that one piece of material would come to our notice that would not have come under the definitions contained in the Bill. The characteristics in Annex III are more than adequate to cover every bit of waste about which Senator Coulter may have concern. I mentioned earlier my concern about the question of onus which I think should be repeated. I listened intently to what Senator Coulter said about onus of proof. Honourable senators should remember that the amendment, in part, reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Wastes that belong to any category contained in Annex I . . . unless they do not possess any of the characteristics contained in Annex III . . .

That represents a pretty strong reversal of the onus of proof. In spite of what Senator Coulter might feel, had the Government put this amendment the Scrutiny of Bills Committee would have jumped all over us and we would have been forced to amend. To that end I do not believe that this amendment in its current form ought to be proceeded with. The amendment should be modified to read:

Waste within any category listed in Annex I to the Basel Convention (a copy of the English text of which annex is set out in the Schedule), which has any of the characteristics mentioned in Annex III to the Basel Convention; or . . .

If that is done there is no reversal of onus. The main thrust of Senator Coulter's amendment is carried through, whatever the thrust is. I do not really think it will make any difference, but it does not do any harm so I am not opposed to it. That ought to happen. By the way, it ought to be put in immediately after existing paragraph (a) rather than just before it, for the sake of tidiness. That makes more sense as it would come after the larger class of which it is a subset. I think Senator Coulter ought to propose that; I do not think it would be a problem for him.

I do not think I have drawn this to Senator Puplick's attention yet but a small consequential amendment to subclause 62 (2) is needed which will enable us to amend Annex I as well as Annex III. This is small beer but as long as we are to have the first amendment, we need the second. Perhaps it would be of advantage if I could get an indication of whether there is any support for not having this reversal of onus. If there is no support for it, I do not intend to press the matter. I just think it makes more sense. It certainly adds up to compliance with the procedures which the Senate has been observing ever since I have been here and I hope for the 80-odd years before that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened carefully to what Senator Richardson said. The Opposition will continue to support the amendment in its current form. TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I will speak on the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 and the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1989. The Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, which deals with the sentencing of federal offenders, has been a long time coming. It goes back to a reference given to the Australian Law Reform Commission in August 1978 and is based on report No. 44 which the Commission released in early 1988, some 10 years later.

SPEECH.PARA: People who commit federal offences are dealt with by the courts in the State or Territory in which they have offended. The range of penalties available is that which is provided by the State or Territory. A person sentenced to imprisonment for a federal offence serves the term in a State prison, as there are no federal prisons for the simple reason that there are not enough federal prisoners to justify an exclusively federal institution. Because such prisoners are relatively few in number, there has been no federal law to regulate federal prisoners. They have always been covered by the law of the State in which they are incarcerated. State laws about imprisonment are continually being changed and modified, with the obvious result that administrative measures have been increasingly required to keep the terms of imprisonment of federal prisoners in line with State regimes so that federal prisoners are not disadvantaged.
One of the most important themes of the Law Reform Commission's report is the concept of truth in sentencing. The rationale of this concept was explained in the report as follows:

Under the present system, a substantial sentence of imprisonment may be imposed by the court, yet it is generally understood that the offender will be released on parole long before the period is served. Remissions further reduce this period. This had led to public disquiet and the procedure having been judicially described as an `elaborate charade'.

`Truth in sentencing' means that there should be a consistent and recognisable relationship between the sentence of imprisonment imposed by the court and the actual time served behind bars. This seems to be a sensible concept, and the Opposition supports it.

The first provision of the Bill that I would like to discuss is proposed new section 16a, which sets out the matters to which a court is to have regard in sentencing a federal offender. The Bill, as originally introduced, provided that the court must choose the least severe type of sentence, and then pass the least severe sentence or order appropriate in all the circumstances. It is interesting to note that this is not what the Law Reform Commission recommended in its report. Recommendation No. 2 stated:

there must be an appropriate degree of severity in the range of punishments available so that the community can be rationally satisfied that a breach of the criminal law is attended by significant consequences; and
the punishment imposed for a particular offence must be just, that is, of a severity appropriate to the offence.

This is evidently not the same as the statement made in the Bill that the court must pass the least severe sentence appropriate in all the circumstances. Therefore, we moved an amendment in the other place which, I am pleased to say, was accepted by the Government. Pursuant to this amendment a court will be obliged to impose a sentence or make an order that is of a severity appropriate in all the circumstances of the offence.

Further guidance is given to the court by way of a list of matters which it must take into account. I think it is worthwhile, on this occasion, mentioning these factors. They are: the nature and circumstances of the offence; other offences to be taken into account; the course of conduct, if the offence is part of one; the personal circumstances of any victim; injury, loss or damage resulting from the offence; the offender's degree of contrition; a guilty plea; cooperation with law enforcement bodies; a deterrent effect on the offender; the need to ensure that the offender is adequately punished for the offence; the offenders' character, antecedents, age, means, physical and mental condition; prospects of rehabilitation; and the probable effect of the sentence on the offender's family or dependants. Many of these factors are already taken into account, to differing extents, by sentencing courts. We support the move to have the criteria set out in this legislation.

However, one aspect which concerns us is that the provision with respect to victims does not go far enough. The court is not required to have regard to what the victim says about the offence. Therefore, I will be moving an amendment to the Bill to allow the victim to inform the court of his or her personal circumstances and of any injury, loss or damage so that the court can take these matters into account when imposing a penalty. Such provisions are now part of the law in my home State of South Australia.

The Bill also makes other provisions in relation to sentencing. For example, a court is required to take the financial circumstances of a person into account before imposing a fine. Also, corporal punishment may not be imposed. The non-parole period is to be determined by the court and it should be generally so fixed in cases where the offender is sentenced to more than three years imprisonment. In line with the principle of `truth in sentencing', the non-parole period is not to be reduced by remissions.

Under this Bill, it will still be possible for prisoners to be released on licence by the Attorney-General, whether or not a non-parole period has been fixed. We find it somewhat strange that, after having established the principle that prisoners should not be eligible for release during their non-parole period, the old system of release on licence should be retained. Since this effectively means that prisoners may be released during their non-parole period, this seems to undermine the principle. In other words, it goes against the whole notion of `truth in sentencing'. There will also be an obligation on the court when it imposes a federal sentence on a person and fixes a non-parole period, to explain the purpose and consequence of fixing that non-parole period.

Another aspect of the Bill which concerns us is the provision for automatic parole upon the expiry of the non-parole period of offenders whose sentences are between three and 10 years. Where the sentence is more than 10 years, release is at the discretion of the Attorney-General. This seems to us to be contrary to the whole concept of parole. We would argue that, upon the expiry of the non-parole period, a prisoner should become eligible for parole no matter what the length of his sentence is. In this way there is some incentive for a prisoner to be of good behaviour while in prison. To put the matter quite simply, we do not believe that release on parole should be automatic. For this reason, we will be moving two amendments to the effect that release on parole should be, in all cases, at the discretion of the Attorney-General.

In this Bill, the courts are given a range of sentencing options. Apart from imprisonment, they may order discharge without conviction, a conditional release after conviction or alternatives such as community service orders. The Bill also contains a number of provisions relating to mentally ill offenders. Those provisions institute procedures available in the event of a defendant being found unfit to be tried. There is also an important provision relating to offenders who are acquitted on the grounds of mental illness. The Bill states that the court is to order the person's detention in a prison or hospital for a specified period, which does not exceed the maximum period of imprisonment that could have been imposed for that particular offence. A range of sentencing alternatives is provided for offenders in cases where the court is satisfied that they are suffering from a mental illness, and that the illness contributed to the commission of the offence.

Hospital orders are available where the court would have sentenced the person to imprisonment; psychiatric probation orders can be made by the court, without passing sentence, requiring a mentally ill offender to reside at or attend a specified place of treatment; and intellectually disabled offenders may be required to attend a treatment or education program. The Opposition supports those measures and hopes they will provide the courts with a greater degree of the flexibility that they so desperately need in dealing with psychiatrically ill and intellectually disabled offenders.

The Bill also amends the Cash Transactions Reports Act and the Opposition is supporting the bulk of these amendments-although I must say that we have some difficulty with the provision for the Attorney-General to declare a class of persons as acceptable referees. The Australian Federation of Credit Unions Ltd has made representations to the effect that credit unions, among other such organisations, should be consulted before acceptable referees are gazetted. Its point is that some consultation would be desirable. We are pleased that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), in the other place, agreed with this point during debate on the Bill.

The final matter that caused us some concern under the provisions of the Cash Transactions Reports Act was that which was included in Government amendment No. 10 in the debate in the House of Representatives. That amendment set out under new paragraphs (7) and (8) a procedure that requires cash dealers to carry out a prescribed verification procedure for the purpose of identifying the signatory to an account. It was not apparent, and as far as I know it is still not apparent, what would be the details of such regulations and exactly what the procedures would be. It is suggested, I understand, that they would include a check on the electoral roll, the examination of a primary identification document and a check with the signatory's employer. We expressed concern in the other place about doing this by regulation and compromised on the basis of an undertaking by the Attorney-General that the detail of the proposed regulations would be produced to the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Brown, for his consideration and comment before the regulations were introduced into the House. I remind the Government of that, as I understand my colleague Mr Brown is still to receive details of the proposed regulations.

Subject to that, and subject to the amendments that I have outlined and which I will be moving in the committee stage of this debate, we support the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). We think some of its provisions should have been incorporated within federal law a long time ago; it is just that the Law Reform Commission's taking 10 years to report has somewhat prolonged the procedure.

The second Bill being dealt with in this cognate debate is the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1989. This Bill started off as an omnibus Bill, containing some 20 pages of amendments to a number of Acts covered by the Attorney-General's portfolio. Most of the amendments are of a formal nature and they do not require comment in this debate. Nevertheless, a number are important and I would want to make mention of them. In relation to telephone offences, two new offences are incorporated, I think within amendments to the Crimes Act, which will outlaw, firstly, unauthorised call switching devices that are used by illegal bookmakers and others to divert calls and thus prevent detection and, secondly, the actual equipment with which illegal telephone interceptions are effected. The Opposition supports those changes to the law.

In relation to telephone interceptions, the Bill will allow designated technical officers employed by the Australian Federal Police (AFP) to give technical assistance when telephone interceptions are being carried out. We do not object to that in principle. We understand there will be circumstances in which the assistance of technical officers will be valuable. We do, however, indicate a concern that the clause is too wide as it allows, again, classes of persons to be declared as designated technical officers as well as named individuals. I propose to move an amendment in this place-an amendment was moved in the other House, but it was unsuccessful-to omit the reference to classes of persons. It seems to us more appropriate that, when we are dealing with the subject of telephone interceptions, the individuals being given special powers are named individuals.

I now mention changes in relation to the Privacy Act. Officers of the ombudsmen around Australia will be authorised to review and handle privacy complaints on behalf of the Privacy Commissioner to enable the Privacy Commissioner to have an Australia-wide presence. We support that. I raise also the important subject of evidence prejudicial to security, measures in regard to which we support. Nevertheless, because of its consequence we should specify our support in this particular debate. The Act allows evidence taken in Australian courts to be used in proceedings in foreign courts. The amendment proposes that the Attorney-General may make an order prohibiting the production of a document or the giving of evidence or information that would prejudice Australia's security. The Federal Court may enforce compliance with the order. That reform to ensure Australia's security has, as I indicated, our support.

In relation to the omnibus Bill, as was presented to this chamber, we had little concern except for the definition of those technical officers that are given powers to assist the AFP in telephone interceptions. The matter was then complicated, however, by the Government introducing substantial amendments to its own Bill; amendments which I do not think have even reached the other place yet. We object to this procedure. The Government has had all year to determine the contents of its omnibus Bill and there was no reason, other than a failure on its own part, to have not incorporated all that it wished to deal with in this particular calendar year within the piece of legislation that was first introduced in the House of Representatives. In fact, I am advised by my colleague, the shadow Attorney-General that he had asked on a number of occasions whether there were any further amendments contemplated, and had always been advised in the negative.

What concerns us more is that some of the Government's amendments to its own Bill are of a substantial nature and are not really the type of amendments that are of a formal nature or procedural nature which we normally find included within a Bill of this type. They are much more appropriately dealt with by separate legislation. We would submit that that is the correct way in which the matter should have been progressed. Nevertheless, the Government having determined to amend its own Bill in this very substantial way, we have had to address whether we can support the Government's amendments to its own Bill. Generally speaking, we are prepared to do so. We again have some amendments which I will mention in a moment. These additional amendments make changes to the Australian Federal Police Act; they set out procedures for the use of listening devices by the AFP in relation to certain offences other than narcotic offences; they make changes to the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act 1979; they exempt the transfer of personal information from Commonwealth bodies to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation from the provisions of the Privacy Act 1988; and they make changes to the Customs Act, the Judiciary Act and the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979.

I want to mention briefly the areas of particular concern that we have. The first relates to the proposed amendments to the Australian Federal Police Act 1979. The Government is seeking to insert a new division into this Act which will regulate the use of listening devices by the Australian Federal Police in the investigation of non-narcotic offences. The proposed amendments are in the same terms as the provisions of the Customs Act 1901, dealing with the use of such devices in the investigation of narcotic offences. Overall, we believe that the provisions should be supported, but we are concerned by the breadth of the definition that will permit telephone interception and the gathering of evidence by telephone interception. The fact that similar wording has been used in previous pieces of legislation does not deter us from raising the matter in this particular instance. I think it is fair to say that it has been a trend of recent times to extend very rapidly the capacity of law enforcement bodies in this country to use telephone interception devices in the gathering of evidence. There was a time when it was regarded as a last resort. We rapidly seem to be approaching the situation where it is regarded as just a normal method of gathering of evidence or the investigation of an alleged crime. We in no way wish to take any action that would in any way counter the responsibility of effective law enforcement, but we are concerned by the continuing extension of powers in this area and as a longer term issue we intend to review it in some depth.

We are concerned that this particular amendment gives power not only in relation to a number of very serious offences, but also in relation to what might be described as less serious offences-they are described as class 2 general offences-which carry a penalty of seven years imprisonment or more, and which involve certainly loss of life, which is very serious, right down to loss of revenue and, in the case of the Australian Capital Territory, loss of revenue to the Australian Capital Territory Government. We think the generic expression of offences that permits the AFP to use telephone interception devices is unsatisfactory and specific offences should be stated in the legislation. Therefore, in the committee stage we will be introducing an amendment that deletes this reference to class 2 general offences and we will call upon the Government to specify the offences that it claims justify giving these extra powers to our law enforcement officers.

We are not proposing amendments in regard to judicial immunity. This provision gives Federal judges the power to issue warrants authorising the use of listening devices and, in effect, bestows a non-judicial or administrative function upon the judicial officer. We accept that in these circumstances. With regard to the designated technical officers, I mentioned in relation to the Government's principal Bill that we would be seeking an amendment.
