—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Resources, follows a question I asked him on Thursday of last week. Has his attention been drawn to reports of the reaction by the management of Robe River Iron Associates to the Minister's criticism of the company's industrial relations policy? Do these reports allege that the Minister's criticism was inaccurate and misleading? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether there is any foundation to this allegation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have noted the comments by the Executive Director of Robe River, Fred Madden, as reported in the West Australian of 16 December. I received a letter from him on 13 December in which he expressed his views on what I had said, along with the Deputy Premier of Western Australia, the Honourable David Parker, as a co-chairman of the West Australian Iron Ore Industry Consultative Council. The startling thing in what Mr Madden has put is that he has not directly answered the matter raised by me and Mr Parker, namely, that, in order to attend a meeting of this consultative body, shop stewards at Robe River sought leave without pay. They were told that leave without pay would not be provided and that they could apply for leave only if they applied for holidays. They sought to have three days of their holidays put aside so that they could conduct union business. They were then told that holidays would be granted only in five-day lots. They then applied for a five-day lot and were ruled out because, they were told, they needed to give a month's notice. That fact has not in any sense been rebutted by Robe River. Given that it has taken the trouble to write to me, to put out a flurry of press releases on the issue and has not answered that point, I guess it is confirmation that it recognises that that point is true. It argues how its productivity per head has increased. It has, but so has the productivity of the whole iron ore industry.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Stone interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It comes back to something that Senator Stone would be familiar with-the H. R. Nicholls Society's view of industrial relations. Robe is an unabashed admirer of removing the dignity of ordinary workers by intimidatory tactics in the work place, of obtaining compliance by intimidation. That is a central plank in the H. R. Nicholls Society view of how industrial relations should be worked out in Australia. It is one that is not practised in the iron ore industry by any company other than Robe River. If diminishing the human dignity of ordinary workers were to catch on as a method of conducting industrial relations, this country would be diminished as well. In respect of the claims of increased productivity, in Robe's case they are true but, as we have seen in history, certain regimes can make trains run on time through the use of particular strategies of maintaining discipline in their own communities.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer him to statements made by the Chairman of Darling Downs TV Ltd that aggregation is rapidly developing into a national catastrophe-they were his words-and that the station is seeking legal advice to prevent aggregation going ahead. Is it a fact that almost a month ago the Minister for Transport and Communications received advice from the Solicitor-General that the network affiliation agreements were illegal but, as usual, the Minister has done nothing about the issue? Is it correct that, as a result of the Minister's policy of drift, a delegation of regional operators is seeing the Minister tomorrow in a desperate attempt to have the Government at least defer the aggregation timetable? Is the Government aware that a major report on the impact of aggregation on regional television is about to be released which is believed to indicate that eight out of the 12 regional operators will make losses in aggregated markets for the foreseeable future? In view of the almost universal concern that aggregation is on the verge of becoming yet another unmitigated broadcasting disaster of this Government, will the Minister for Transport and Communications announce a complete review of this disastrous policy?

—It was not thought to be a disastrous policy either by the Government or by the Opposition when it was introduced. I received a copy of the letter from the Chief Executive of Darling Downs and I have referred it to the Minister for Transport and Communications for an answer. When I get that answer I will have a better understanding of the issues. I will also refer Senator Alston's multifaceted question-which has a number of points in it such as `Is the Minister meeting with somebody tomorrow?' to the Minister in order to obtain an answer for the honourable senator as quickly as possible.
—You do not think it is a serious issue?
—Of course I think the issues Senator Alston raises are important. They sometimes are. As I said, I will refer that many faceted question to the Minister and obtain an answer.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I regret that I did not make a statement earlier about ministerial arrangements. Senator Robert Ray is now back and will resume responsibility for questions relating to the portfolios of foreign affairs and trade, and transport and communications.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Attorney- General been drawn to comments by a former senior member of the Australian Federal Police that `a single national criminal code would be an enormous step forward in the fight against criminals'? Has the Government ever considered the possibility of seeking the cooperation of the States and Territories to establish a national criminal code?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth does not have constitutional power to enact a general crimes statute, as is well known in this chamber. At present, Commonwealth criminal laws deal only with specific areas of Commonwealth responsibility, for example, drug importation, currency offences, stealing or damaging Commonwealth property, fraud against the Commonwealth, and so on. Each of the States has its own criminal statute, three States having adopted comprehensive criminal codes many years ago, and the Northern Territory more recently. The others rely on statutes which modify the common law in varying degrees. There is considerable variation between each jurisdiction, particularly with respect to levels of penalties. There are also variations in principles of responsibility, the elements of some offences and defences.

ANSWER.PARA: While there could be considerable benefit in a uniform system, the States have shown no enthusiasm for such an approach. From time to time, particular criminal law issues are considered by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General-for example, computer offences-but it is generally left to each State to legislate in the context of its own laws. It might be noted that the question of penalties is closely linked to that of sentencing and the treatment of offenders, which are State matters.

The Commonwealth has been giving priority to the review of Commonwealth criminal law and has set up for that purpose a review committee chaired by former Chief Justice Sir Harry Gibbs. It is expected that this project, the first comprehensive revision of Commonwealth offences since Federation, will lead to a greatly improved criminal statute book at the Federal level. It should also be noted that the Commonwealth has put considerable effort into reforming the general criminal law in relation to the Australian Capital Territory and that even after ACT self-government the Commonwealth will have responsibility for general criminal law in particular situations: for example, some other Territories, on board aircraft and in relation to Defence Force personnel. However, the development of a uniformed national system is not feasible unless the States agree to cooperate towards that end.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to the recent official visit by the United States national security adviser and the deputy secretary of State to the People's Republic of China and their meetings with senior Chinese leaders; and also to the visit by the national security adviser in July which was revealed by the White House today. What is the Government's attitude to the high-level United States delegation to the People's Republic of China? Has the Government considered sending former Prime Minister Whitlam to renew high-level relations with China? Will the Foreign Minister or his representative meet with leaders of the Federation for a Democratic China who are now visiting Australia and, if so, when will the meeting take place? What assistance, if any, will the Government give to the Federation for a Democratic China?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government viewed with obvious interest the recent official visit to China by the United States national security adviser and deputy secretary of State, but it is not really for us to comment on that visit; that is a matter for the United States and China. The idea of a visit by Mr Whitlam was suggested following the recent visit by former United States President Nixon. The Government has no plans at this time to send Mr Whitlam to China as an unofficial envoy. However, there are at least two outstanding invitations for a visit to China by Mr Whitlam in his capacity as chairman of the Australia-China Council. Mr Whitlam has undertaken several such visits in the past few years. It is my understanding, however, that Mr Whitlam does not intend to take up these outstanding invitations in the near future.

ANSWER.PARA: As for the visit to Australia by leaders of the Federation for a Democratic China, the Government will not be receiving the delegation at a ministerial level. The Government will also not offer any assistance to the Federation. Nevertheless, as a private political organisation, the Federation, like any other similar group, is entitled to carry out information and lobbying activities in Australia in accordance with the law. I understand that as part of these activities the visiting leaders will be meeting interested members of parliament, including the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, as well as talking to the press and organising public meetings over the next few days.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the country reviews carried out under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). Can the Minister inform the Senate of the outcome of the review of Australia's trade policy undertaken under GATT's new trade policy review mechanism?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 December Australia became the first country to have its trade policies and practices reviewed under GATT's new trade policy review mechanism. Australia volunteered for an early review as a demonstration of its commitment to a successful operation in its objective of fostering openness in trade policy formulation. The review was done on the basis of two reports, one prepared by the country itself and the other by the GATT secretariat.

ANSWER.PARA: The GATT secretariat report commented favourably on Australia's trade policies-in particular, the rationalisation of bounties, reform of the anti-dumping and countervailing measures and the general tariff reduction program. It still expresses concern about the high assistance provided to the passenger motor vehicle and textile, clothing and footwear sectors. The question of Australia's low level of binding was raised at the review. That is a technical matter. But overall the Australian report set a demanding precedent for the surveillance mechanism, and there was unanimous support for the Government's program of structural reform which will reduce overall protection by the mid-1990s. From Australia's point of view it was a very successful endorsement of trade policies.
Senator Chaney interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, Senator. It was also consistent with the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development comment that in the process of structural adjustment, which has been taking place in a number of countries, Australia and New Zealand were by far the most successful, particularly in respect of tariff reductions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Resources to an article about his own senior Minister Mr Kerin, which I hope he has seen, which appeared in the Sunday Herald on 17 December. The article is an interview with his friend Phillip Toyne, the director of the Australian Conservation Foundation. In that article Mr Toyne is quoted, in relation to the future of the woodchip industry, as follows:

QUESTION.PARA: Even gung-ho ministers like Kerin accept that. He's said to me a couple of times that he can't understand for the life of him why the Government doesn't move pre-emptively to run Harris Daishowa out of Australia.

Is Mr Toyne lying or does Minister Kerin believe that Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Ltd should be run out of Australia? If the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy does believe that Harris-Daishowa should be run out of Australia, is this official government policy or just another breach of policy by Mr Kerin? If the Minister believes this, does the Minister for Resources? If Mr Kerin does not believe this, has the Minister any idea why Mr Toyne should be such a frightful liar? Is he trying to set Minister Kerin up for the sack? Does the Minister know whose side of this fight Minister Richardson is now on?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the paper, but since Senator Parer has got it over on the other side of the chamber--
—Sack your advisers for incompetence.

—Just keep your hair on. Since Senator Parer has got the newspaper over there, maybe he will do me the courtesy of sending it over to this side of the chamber so that I can actually read, in the full context of the remarks reported, what in fact was said. Having said that, if Mr Toyne made those remarks about Mr Kerin to which Senator Parer referred I find it quite unbelievable.
—Why is that?

—Because it is not consistent with my understanding of what Mr Kerin's views are. I cannot answer Senator Parer's second question about whether Mr Toyne is lying because I am not privy to any conversations that have been held between Mr Toyne and Mr Kerin, but I do not believe it is Mr Kerin's view that Harris-Daishowa should be run out of Australia. What I think would be Mr Kerin's view and, indeed, is my view, since Senator Parer asks me for my view, is that we should look to a time in Australia when we stop exporting woodchips out of this country and start exporting higher value added commodities than woodchips. The objective of simply seeing that we export from our forests the lowest value added item-woodchips-and not seek to move downstream into pulp and paper manufacture is a point on which Mr Kerin and I are at one and is, I imagine, if there were such a conversation, a point that Mr Kerin would in a typically colourful way be at pains to point out.

ANSWER.PARA: I cannot answer Senator Parer's question about lying; I was not there-I do not know whether or not the conversation was held or, indeed, its full text.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you will follow it up, won't you?

—I do not think it is worth following up. It is not a substantial question. It is not a question that concerns the Government. After all, our policy on these things is quite clear. We want more and better downstream processing and we look to a time when we can achieve the greatest value added for the product from our forests and the best return for Australia from exporting forest products overseas.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Have the Indonesian and Australian governments finalised arrangements governing petroleum exploration in the Timor Sea? Can the Minister advise honourable senators what these arrangements are? Is the Minister in a position to advise honourable senators what the prospects are for petroleum exploration in that area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —One week and one day ago at approximately this time, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, on behalf of Australia, signed with Minister Ali Alatas of Indonesia the Zone of Cooperation Agreement between Australia and Indonesia on the Timor Gap. As a consequence of that treaty, which means that there is now a zone of cooperation in the Timor Sea about the size of Tasmania, it falls on me, as the Minister for Resources, and Dr Ginandjar Kartasasmita, as the Indonesian Minister for Mines and Energy, to conclude the details under the heads of that agreement to make possible exploration and, hopefully, production in the Timor Sea zone of cooperation.

ANSWER.PARA: The first step for the Government in Australia will be to bring before the Parliament in the autumn session legislation amending several Acts of this Government to give force to the treaty. I understand that the Indonesians have a parliamentary session commencing in January and that they will do the same. We will put $A2.5m as a loan to a joint authority created between the two countries and Indonesia will match that as an operating basis for the joint authority, the loans to be repaid from fees gained from exploration companies. A joint Bureau of Mineral Resources-Indonesia survey will look at the prospect of taking a seismic survey over the area and we will look at how we divide zone A, the zone of cooperation, into 10 or 15 blocks. These will then be put out for bidding to oil exploration companies in Australia. It is our expectation that the first meeting of the joint ministerial council will be in the second half of 1990, from which we will call bids, and exploration ought to commence, by that timetable, in the first half of 1991.

One of the other matters that I can comment on at this stage is that there were some companies, Australian in origin or registered in Australia and forming consortia with Australian companies, that had prior claims to areas in the disputed territory prior to 1975, when the seabed boundary debate began. In the case of those prior claims, it is agreed between Indonesia and Australia that favourable consideration will be given to those companies if they evince interest in bidding when the particular blocks come up at the time they are released.

To conclude, we have some detailed work ahead in writing the fundamental terms of how exploration will be conducted and we have the duty of establishing a technical directorate in Darwin, which will be the mainland beneficiary of this agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I refer the Minister to a document entitled Strategy Proposal for the Management of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Program, which has been presented to the Pharmacy Guild of Australia for consideration by the Health Insurance Commission (HIC). Is the Minister aware that this document outlines radical changes to the way records of patients' pharmaceutical prescriptions are kept? Is the Minister aware that an independent assessment of the proposal by the computer company that provides pharmaceutical software states that all patients, be they general benefit patients or concessional patients, should be issued with a Medicare-like number on a health care card, allowing the Health Commission to monitor prescription details about all Australians? These details include surname, date of birth, sex, doctor's code number, name and volume of the prescribed drug and the number of authorised repeats. Can the Minister confirm whether Australians will be issued with this type of card or number to enable prescriptions to be dispensed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been many specious claims about what is proposed for the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and about this card. Indeed, Mr Matthews, speaking on behalf of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, has made allegations startlingly similar to the ones Senator Boswell has just enumerated. Perhaps not only can I tell Senator Boswell that those claims by Mr Matthews are as spurious as the claims inferred in his question, but also I can go to the detail of what is intended by the Health Insurance Commission. The HIC is simply looking at redesigning processing systems for pharmaceutical claims to overcome deficiencies identified in a report by the Auditor-General. It is because of the Auditor-General's identification of what he sees as deficiencies that the HIC is moving in the first place.

ANSWER.PARA: The pharmacists have always submitted details of scripts filled as part of the claiming process. Over 50 per cent of claims are now submitted in computer form, with the full cooperation of the Guild, as well as the provision of hard copies of all scripts. It is difficult to see how pharmacists could expect to be paid for dispensing without providing to the Commonwealth details of what they do. All the HIC is looking at is how to improve the efficiency of this process. Indeed, one of the advantages is that it would facilitate prompter payments to pharmacists.

The HIC is holding discussions with the Guild on the proposed new system. The Government has made no decision on the proposal at this stage. It is waiting to look at the outcome of the consultations with the Guild before considering what it will then do. It is nonsense for Mr Matthews or for Senator Boswell, as he did in the way he phrased his question, to infer that this is some sort of Australia Card revisited. The HIC has made it clear to the Guild that the proposal--

TALK.START.PARA: —Your words.

—It is the inference from Senator Boswell's question-the reasonable, rational inference from his question. Senator Boswell used the words `Australia Card' in his question or there was an allusion to it. I am simply rebutting that allusion. If Senator Boswell wants to withdraw and rephrase his question he should do so. The HIC has made it clear to the Guild that the proposal involves no more data than the current long-established Pharmpay system. The proposal involves giving pharmacists the capacity to check entitlements to concessions and to process claims through devices connected to the HIC claims processing computers rather than having to send claims in floppy discs or to use computer dial-up facilities. The HIC proposals in no way change the responsibilities of pharmacists to give the Commonwealth more data. The Commonwealth has been receiving the scripts since the inception of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme over 30 years ago and the information has been used for the reimbursement of chemists.

ANSWER.PARA: Pharmacists are required under section 87 (3a) of the National Health Act to satisfy themselves that a person is entitled to a pensioner or concessional status before supplying a benefit. Long-standing legislative provisions protect the privacy of this data. The data will also be protected by the new Privacy Act, which covers all Commonwealth data. The Commonwealth will not be receiving data on all people as it will not be receiving any data on those scripts falling below the maximum patient contribution, for which there is no direct cost subsidy. Currently, there are over 30 million scripts per annum in that category.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his very long and detailed answer, but I am still not aware of whether there will be a card or not. Can the Minister answer yes, there will be a card, or no, there will not be a card, for the benefit of the many hundreds of thousands of Australians who are worried about this?

—Clearly Senator Boswell was not listening to the answer I gave. If he were listening to the answer I gave and thus genuinely seeking information rather than trying to make a trite political point, he would have heard me say that the Government has made no decision on this, that the Government is in consultation with the Pharmacy Guild. When those consultations have been completed and as a consequence of those completed consultations, the Government will then make a decision.
—When?
—As soon as we have completed the consultation. It is a simple process.
—A lot of chemists are listening to this.

—Yes, and a lot of chemists will be beneficiaries of the more efficient system that is being proposed. They will get their payments sooner. I make the fundamental point, lest Senator Boswell's warped political consciousness try to distort the truth, that the HIC is acting because of an Auditor-General's report. That is the motivation. What is in question is a simplified and more efficient system; not the creation of new knowledge banks garnering different information from what already is the case.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy aware of proposals to cut expenditure on the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS)? Is the Minister also aware of proposed taxation changes which, if implemented, might create the need for such cuts? Is the Government considering implementing such cuts? What would be the consequences for AQIS if such cuts were implemented?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only proposal that I am aware of is a proposal outlined in the Opposition's Economic Action Plan to cut 14 per cent off the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service's budget by reducing allocations to that Service by $10m and by changing the cost recovery provision from 60 per cent of costs incurred to 50 per cent of costs incurred, meaning in total a net reduction of between $23m and $26m or 14 per cent of the total budget.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked whether the Government is considering implementing such cuts. No, we are not. Such cuts do not recognise the fact that over the last five years, through economic stringency and fiscal responsibility, this Government has reduced total outlays to the Quarantine and Inspection Service by 30 per cent-that is a real reduction-in terms of inspection costs alone. It is harder to calculate the reduction in quarantine costs but overall there has been a significant reduction, and there is a better targeted, leaner, more efficient quarantine service as a consequence. I might add that we have conducted, by way of the Lindsay inquiry, a major review of the Quarantine Service. The report of that review has been supported by the farming interests in this country. We have implemented the report's findings in order to have a better Quarantine and Inspection Service.

If the 14 per cent reduction suggested by the Economic Action Plan were implemented, Australia would be at considerable risk because there would not be the financial wherewithal to mount an effective quarantine service. Thus there would be the prospect of importing exotic diseases and our rural products, be they wool, wheat, beef or horticultural, could be at considerable risk. Of course, these are Australia's major export earners. The Opposition is proposing a very dangerous policy which would have a major impact on our ability to operate not only as a world trader in agricultural products but also a consumer of safe, clean, healthy agricultural products.

Senator McMullan asked me whether I am aware of proposed taxation changes which, if implemented, might create the need for the cuts proposed in the Economic Action Plan. I am aware of the Opposition's proposal to abolish the capital gains tax and replace it with a speculative gains tax. I am also aware that the direct beneficiary of that would be John Elliott-to the tune of $18m. It can be said clearly that there would be a windfall gain by the President of the Liberal Party of Australia while at the same time Australia's Quarantine and Inspection Service would be put at risk.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health confirm that the Medicare levy is essentially a taxation measure which only partially finances health care in Australia and that its payment is not related to eligibility for Medicare benefits? If so, does the Minister agree that the much touted universality of Medicare is obviously a false claim as many people in this country who would be required to pay the levy because they are earning taxable income would be debarred from Medicare benefits because they do not satisfy the residency requirements of the Health Insurance Act?

—I am amazed at the gall of this question. The Opposition is touting a health policy to abolish Medicare and make the rich pay less and the poor pay more for health care in this country. It is pretending that that policy is socially equitable. The medicare levy is a taxation measure which funds Medicare which, for the most part, provides ordinary Australians with free health care and treatment in this country.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister attended the hearing of Estimates Committee F at which I was staggered to find that one could pay a Medicare levy and not be entitled to Medicare benefits. The question was taken on notice. Subsequently, Mr Ian McNeil, First Assistant Secretary of the Health Care Access Division of the Department of Community Services and Health, wrote to me about it. I am sure the Minister has seen a copy of the letter. It is only a short letter and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
DEPARTMENT OF COMMUNITY SERVICES
AND HEALTH
GPO Box 9848
Canberra ACT 2601
Telephone: (062) 89 1555
The Chairman
Senate Estimates Committee F
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
MEDICARE LEVY

At a hearing of the Committee held on 10 October 1989 Senator Sheil asked a question about the number of people who are liable for payment of the Medicare levy but who may not be eligible for Medicare benefits. I undertook to seek advice on the matter from the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) for the Committee's information.

The ATO has advised that it does not have the information requested. Overall it knows the number of people who pay the levy but more specific details of levy payers are not recorded. The ATO advises that it has no need to maintain such statistics for tax purposes because it has been solely concerned with the imposition and collection of the levy and not with eligibility for Medicare benefits.

The situation is that the Medicare levy is essentially a taxation measure which only partially finances health care in Australia, and its payment is not related to eligibility for Medicare benefits. It is an income related tax and not conceptually a health insurance premium.

The levy is governed by the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Medicare Levy Act 1986, whereas Medicare eligibility is established under the Health Insurance Act 1973. Liability for payment of the levy and entitlement to Medicare benefits are each determined by reference to a person's residency status. However, the respective sets of legislation do not contain a common definition of resident. I might add that the definition of ``Australian resident'' in the Health Insurance Act is substantially the same as that contained in other Federal social welfare legislation (eg the Social Security Act).

Circumstances may therefore arise where persons may be liable for the levy but are not eligible for Medicare benefits. Examples could include, persons visiting Australia as working holidaymakers; visiting entertainers and sportspeople; or other persons who may earn taxable income whilst temporarily in Australia.

Conversely, many people who do not pay the levy are eligible for Medicare benefits. Examples include, pensioners and others who either do not earn taxable income or whose income is below the threshold at which the levy is payable; overseas students whose studies in Australia are sponsored or subsidised by the Australian Government.
Ian McNeil
First Assistant Secretary
Health Care Access Division

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I want to read a couple of parts of the letter.
—Senator Sheil, you will have to ask a supplementary question, I am afraid.
—I have a supplementary question. The letter states:

QUESTION.PARA: The situation is that the Medicare levy is essentially a taxation measure which only partially finances health care in Australia, and its payment is not related to eligibility for Medicare benefits. It is an income related tax and not conceptually a health insurance premium.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! You cannot make a speech, Senator Sheil.

—The Minister has just said that Medicare is available for everybody, and it is not available for everybody even if they pay their premiums. In the light of the letter, I wonder whether the Minister would care to withdraw or modify the statement he has made to the Senate.
—I find the dissertation interesting and bordering on boring. I have nothing further to add to my earlier answer.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL PARKS AND RESERVES: WESTERN AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories aware that as at 30 June 1989 a total of 154 exploration and prospecting tenements and 11 mining leases were pending over national parks and nature reserves in Western Australia, several of which are on the Register of the National Estate. Has the Minister been informed that the Western Australian Government's policy, as documented under the title of `Mining and the Environment-Balancing the Scales', has closed national parks and nature reserves to mining activity except under certain detailed provisions and unless both Houses of the State Parliament approve? Does the Minister agree that mining the deposits of mineral sands in the D'Entrecasteaux National Park will destroy its wilderness and conservation values and result in a major loss to the National Estate? As the park is on the Register, has the proposal to explore the D`Entrecasteaux National Park for heavy mineral sands been referred to Senator Richardson or his Government? How much longer will the Government be prepared to stand by and allow the 1.8 per cent of Western Australia which is set aside as national park-a considerable portion of which is on the Register of the National Estate-be destroyed by mining activity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jenkins asked about 154 exploration and prospecting tenements and 11 mining leases. I cannot say that I am aware that all of those are pending over national parks and reserves in Western Australia but I understand there are quite a number and I will accept her word for it. Senator Jenkins asked whether I know about the Western Australian Government closing the option of mining activity in national parks without the approval of both Houses of Parliament. Yes. I think as a result of the Bailey report, legislation to that effect was enacted last year, 1988, so I understand that that is the case.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Jenkins asked whether I agree that the mining of mineral sands in the D'Entrecasteaux National Park would destroy its wilderness and conservation values. From memory, there is a proposal for sandmining in the area but my recollection is that it is in an area adjacent to the D'Entrecasteaux National Park. I am not actually aware of a proposal to mine inside the park. I will have to check the details for Senator Jenkins but I believe that my Department and the Western Australian Government have settled on a Western Australian Government environmental impact statement (EIS) procedure in which some of our ideas were included. I understand that that EIS procedure is still going on. I do not expect it to be completed for a few more months. That is certainly the indication Premier Dowding gave me when I saw him last week. I am not aware of any proposal for mining inside the D'Entrecasteaux National Park. Obviously Senator Jenkins would be aware, because I have said it here in the chamber a number of times, that the Labor Party's national policy is to oppose mining in national parks. Like all of my colleagues, I support all Labor policies. So, we all agree with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does Mr Kerin have to say about that?

—I do not think Mr Kerin has ever suggested that we should be mining in national parks. He totally agrees with me on that question. So that is not a problem. As to whether a proposal to explore the park has been presented to me, I certainly cannot recall one.
—Senator Gareth Evans has. He wanted mining in Kakadu.

—I think Senator Crichton-Browne will find that D'Entrecasteaux is a long way from Kakadu. I will have to check whether a proposal to explore has come up. I cannot remember one. As to whether or not this Government is prepared to stand by and see national parks mined, the mere fact that both Houses of parliament in Western Australia have to approve of this occurring, and given the enormous public interest in questions of this kind, if there were to be any mining in the D'Entrecasteaux National Park in Western Australia or any other national park in Western Australia we would hear all about it. There will be a chance for it to be thoroughly debated.

ANSWER.PARA: Where national parks are not on the Register of the National Estate there is no Commonwealth interest. The only way in which the Commonwealth would then get involved would be either by foreign investment, export controls or world heritage. There are no world heritage proposals for the area Senator Jenkins referred to. Obviously, any sandmining proposal would involve export control and so the Commonwealth would be looking at it. Over time we have demonstrated that when the Commonwealth has a look it makes sure that these proposals are put to very rigorous tests indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and pertains to the live sheep trade dispute. Is the Minister aware of the article in last Friday's Australian headed `Live sheep trade with Saudis ``doomed'' '? Does he agree with Mr Al-Khalaf that Australia has no hope of regaining that market? Does he share Mr Al-Khalaf's view that the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) was too hasty in ceasing the shipments to Saudi Arabia? Finally, what is the Government now doing to retrieve the trade?

—As to the first question, the answer is yes. As to the second question, the answer is no. As to the third question, I do not think the AMLC was too hasty in suspending the trade. I believe that that will be proven in due course. Senator Panizza asked what the Australian government is doing to revive the trade. He will be aware that a mission from the AMLC has just returned from Saudi Arabia and has been in consultation with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin. The Government will be saying something on that subject shortly.

—Can the Minister for Resources advise honourable senators of the effects of the present condition of the wool market on the Australian economy? Can he indicate whether or not the downturn in the wool market will have a significant effect on the current account deficit? Are there any indications of improvement in prospects for commodity exports generally?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect to all but the last couple of seasons we have seen abnormally high prices. It can now be said that the market is likely to return to more usual trading levels. However, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) today released the December quarterly bulletin, the Agriculture and Resources Quarterly. Its forecast for wool exports in 1989-90 show a significant drop. The fall will be caused mainly by increases in auction offerings of wool as a result of large carryovers of stocks as well as increased production of shorn wool as a result of good seasonal conditions and larger sheep flocks. In addition, we have seen an increased world wool supply, combined with depressed wool demand, principally due to falling sales to China and to the Republic of Korea and Japan.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Wool Corporation stocks are estimated to be at a record level of 2.1 million bales by the end of June 1990. The value of our wool exports in 1989-90 is expected to drop by $2 billion from $6 billion in 1988-89. However, significant increases in export returns for meat, dairy products, sugar and cotton will partly offset the deterioration in the wool market. When the selling season begins in late January it is expected that Japan, which traditionally takes about 22 per cent of our clip, will re-enter the market. If it does we will see an increase in prices as well.

According to ABARE the total value of rural exports for 1989-90 is expected to decrease by 6 per cent to $14.9 billion. On the other hand, it should be noted that minerals and energy sectors have shown considerable improvement. The forecast increase of mineral resource exports in 1989-90 is 15 per cent in September. It has been revised upwards to 18 per cent in the December quarterly bulletin. The value of total commodity exports is forecast to increase by 7 per cent in 1989-90 to $39 billion compared to a 6 per cent increase in 1988-89. Significant price rises are expected for iron ore, coal and petroleum and higher production levels are forecast for a wide range of minerals including crude oil, natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas, gold, base metals, nickel, coal and mineral sands. The Bureau sees the major reasons for the increase in production as due to substantial increases in new capital investment in the mining industry, reflecting the Government's view that much of the recent rise in the level of imports is due to the investment surge. While in the short term it is acknowledged that this rise in imports has a dramatic effect on the current account deficit, in the long run it will result in a better export performance as evidenced by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics forecasts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister Assisting the Treasurer for Prices aware of the article which appeared a few days ago in the Sydney Morning Herald alleging that the Government had deliberately deferred making a decision on the report of the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA) on book pricing in Australia? Is that correct? When does the Government intend to make some positive determination about the Prices Surveillance Authority's report on book pricing? Is the Minister conscious of the need to take steps to do something about reducing the price of Australian books, if not before Christmas, as the opportunity has now passed, at least before the commencement of the next academic year?

—In terms of the last part of the question, I am conscious of the complications and implications for book traders now operating in Australia. To that extent in cooperation and consultation with the Attorney-General we asked the Prices Surveillance Authority to investigate the industry. Its interim report was made available some months ago. I did see the Sydney Morning Herald article indicating some deferral of decision-making. In terms of when the Government intends to make a decision, I anticipate that a decision could be made in the near future.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Does the Minister accept that Australians are paying too much for their books? Does he accept that the Government has within its power the ability to do something about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question deserves a fuller answer. The Government has recognised that the book trade was ripe and needed to be inquired into in terms of both the accessibility of books on the Australian market and the price of those books. The first report that we commissioned was the Shepherd report, a report on the copyright law in this area. That report came out some time in 1988. It noted the need to conduct an inquiry on the economic level of book prices. As a consequence the PSA inquiry canvassed those issues. It was made very clear from the PSA inquiry that Australian book buyers are charged more for books bought in this country than are consumers in other countries. By comparing our prices to those of books in Canada it was found that book prices may be 30 per cent more than is necessary. On the other hand, there are other arguments that Senator Puplick and the Senate are quite aware of. They are the arguments put forward quite forcefully by authors and book publishers that there is a need to protect their copyright in a real and meaningful way.

ANSWER.PARA: Those two major considerations have to be at the forefront of any Government deliberation. I am sure that, on the one hand, the interests of ensuring books are at the lowest possible price to consumers will be a major consideration. On the other hand, recognising a real need to protect authors' copyright will also be fully considered. Going back to the first part of Senator Puplick's question, I think the Government will make a decision in this area in the near future in the interests of both authors and book buyers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Finance to complaints made last month by the honourable member for North Sydney that the Government had asked him to pay a substantial amount of money under the Freedom of Information Act for access to documents relating to government costings of the Opposition's Economic Action Plan. Has the matter been resolved? If so, has it been resolved in Mr Spender's favour?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In order to answer this question adequately I think it is necessary to give a bit of background information. After the Department of Finance costings blew an $830m hole in the Opposition's Economic Action Plan, the honourable member for North Sydney thought up a stunt that he believed would help him get back onto the front bench, or he hoped it would anyway. He put in a freedom of information (FOI) request which implied freely that there was something improper about the Department of Finance doing the costings and that it was also most unusual for such costings to have been done. Anyway, he put in his freedom of information request, ultimately got a bill for $700 and was whinging endlessly in the House of Representatives on 28 November.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me demonstrate beyond any doubt that for the Department of Finance to do such costings was certainly not without precedent, nor was it improper. Indeed, I interpolate here to say that the Department of Finance, even without being asked, has, as a matter of course, costed propositions that have been put up by organisations other than the Opposition-by the National Farmers Federation, the Business Council of Australia and so on.

In order to put beyond any doubt that there were precedents and that there was nothing improper about it, I put in a request to the Department of Finance under the FOI Act for costings which had been done on the then Opposition's policies in 1980 and 1983 and I paid my deposit and expected to pay for all the rest. Mr Spender, however, made an official approach to the Department stating that the $700, or thereabouts, which he had been billed should be waived on public interest grounds. I saw today a recommendation from the Department that the request should be granted. Under the circumstances I believe that I have little realistic option other than to accept that recommendation and to waive the charge.

TALK.START.PARA: —That must hurt. It's enough to bring your shingles back, isn't it?

—Clearly, I cannot sit in judgment on myself in regard to my own obligation. There will be an Acting Minister for Finance early in the New Year. I have made no request to have the fee waived and I will pay the amount whether or not the Acting Minister for Finance chooses to recommend that it be waived. So the difference between Mr Spender and me is that I am paying for it, he is not-at least, he does not have to pay for it-and I hope that he will follow my excellent example and make an ex gratia payment to the Government.

—Is the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs aware of the hardship, both financial and emotional, that will be caused by the new legislation regarding application for resident status by foreign spouses of Australian residents? Can the Minister confirm that, whereas under the old legislation foreign spouses of Australian citizens already legally in Australia could stay here while their application for permanent residence was considered, the new legislation will force them to return to their country of origin to await confirmation? Can the Minister explain why the legislation regarding spouses has been changed while other categories of migrant applicants, such as those applying on occupational or strong compassionate or humanitarian grounds, will still be able to remain in Australia while their applications are being heard?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether I can agree with the categorisation for those other subject areas. But in regard to the application of the regulations that came into force at one minute past midnight, this morning, I have entered into correspondence and will be in future discussion with the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations. This is certainly one of the issues that this Committee raised with me and I will indicate to it that it is one of the issues I am willing to discuss. In the matter of making regulations I think it is much better to start off tough and then ease up, rather than the other way around.

ANSWER.PARA: But the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and others are facing a problem with the number of bogus marriages that is occurring. Marriage, as a device, is being used as a way of entering this country and I think the honourable senator would realise also that it is not particularly easy to establish that. This whole subject which the honourable senator has raised is still one of the few issues in the regulations that remain a matter of concern. I trust that it will be a matter of dialogue between me and the Select Committee and I hope that some resolution to it will be found in the next three to five months. So the regulations which exist at the moment will be applied but there is some belief that this is one of the areas that may change. I am not guaranteeing that it will change; it may change after discussion between me and the Select Committee in regard to spouses.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister suggested in his answer that the legislation targets what he described as bogus marriages or marriages of convenience. Does the Minister agree that these new provisions would be a relatively minor inconvenience for those determined to flout our immigration laws through marriages of convenience, whereas there will be many genuine cases of marriage where considerable hardship will be caused by the way in which the new regulations will operate? Will the Minister do something perhaps to distinguish between the two in considering the regulations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —That will certainly be taken on board as we reconsider the regulations. The regulations, as they exist at the moment, are not supposed to be holy writ; they will be subject to change. I was actually most anxious to see the regulations in working order so that any flaws or discrepancies would become apparent in their application. But it is true that, at the moment, at least people are on some warning that they do not have an automatic right to permanent residency just because they come here as visitors and subsequently marry. However, they have an automatic right to marry in this country and then migrate from another country to this country; that has not been imperilled in any way by these regulations. I stress that the great advantage that the honourable senator and others can now see of having these matters in regulations rather than in legislation is that they are readily amendable. Given the record of this place on legislation, I would hate to be waiting on a decision to change the legislation to cover one of my cases.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. When the Minister's Department evaluates a savings option does it treat the deferment of expenditure in the same way as a permanent reduction in the size of a program? If the deferment of expenditure and permanent reductions in the size of a program are treated differently, what are the implications of each?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the contemporary jargon-I think it has been around for a long time; it probably stretches right back into the distant past when the Opposition was in government-a deferment is pushing expenditure, as the name clearly implies of course, which a government had at one stage planned to undertake in a current financial year into some subsequent financial year. In other words, a deferment is a change in the timing of expenditure and not a reduction in total expenditure; whereas a true savings or recurrent savings option is something that goes on, with savings accruing year after year. That is the essential difference. If a deferment, therefore, is portrayed as an ongoing saving it is a deception.

ANSWER.PARA: I have one very recent example of this. A press release was put out yesterday by the honourable member for Bass regarding community development employment projects for Aboriginal communities. I had previously believed-along with everyone else, I suppose-that the `saving' in the Opposition's Economic Action Plan was an ongoing saving. But, according to the honourable member for Bass, that is not so. Mr Smith's press release of yesterday said:

Mr Smith said that criticism by some that the coalition planned to cut back on CDEPs was totally unfounded. ``Payments to communities are to increase this year by $25m to a total of $98m. Our cut of $4 million will mean only a slight delay in getting additional communities into the scheme''.

A slight delay of the ongoing level of expenditure, according to Mr Smith yesterday, will of course be the same as is proposed by the present Government and is in the Forward Estimates. So, it is not a cut at all; it is a deferment. Many other so-called cuts, in the Opposition's Economic Action Plan have similar question marks hanging over them. As I said earlier today, an error of over $830m has already been identified. One wonders just how much that error might blow out beyond $830m-odd once everything is properly qualified and assessed. The last comment I want to make is that should something terrible happen in the first half of next year and the Opposition be elected, I wish Senator Stone well in his attempt to impose some fiscal discipline on a coalition government, but frankly, I do not think he will be able to do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 December Senator Chapman asked Senator Gareth Evans a question on the jamming of radio broadcasts in China. The Minister for Transport and Communications is aware of the allegation by Mr John Tusa, head of the British Broadcasting Corporation World Service, of jamming of that service's broadcasts. On the evidence available, there is nothing to suggest any systematic or deliberate jamming of Radio Australia broadcasts. There are no immediate practical options for significantly improving Radio Australia's signal coverage to northern China from within Australia. This could be achieved using transmitters sited in a country much closer to northern China. The establishments of such transmission facilities would not be a simple matter and would not be a short term project. Early next year the Government is due to consider the future role and responsibilities of Radio Australia, including the options for upgrading the transmission system for the overseas service.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 December Senator Macklin asked me a question about the Australian Embassy to the Holy See, and the possible need for a resident ambassador. The Government maintains a resident charge d'affaires at the Embassy in the Holy See. He is an experienced officer, and his work is backed up by regular visits to the Vatican by our Ambassador, resident in Dublin. This practice is not unusual. We have used the Embassy to the Holy See to maintain close contact with the Vatican's diplomatic service, which has a deservedly high reputation for being well-informed and enjoying good access. DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 December, on motion by Senator Brownhill:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on two aspects of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy annual report for 1988-1989-the sections on forestry resources and water resources. The section headed `Forest resources' refers to the primary objectives of the Department's activities in the forestry area as being:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to provide advice and manage programs which contribute to the efficient and sustainable development of Australia's forest resources and the promotion of environmentally sensitive management practices.
The report states:
It is mainly in co-operation with the States that the Commonwealth is able to advance its forest policy objectives. The peak forum for this is the Australian Forestry Council.

I comment on the situation with regard to the limited and over-exploited native forest resources of the south-west area of Western Australia. The Department's annual report refers to the intention to renew the export woodchip licence of WACAP-the West Australian Chip and Pulp Co.-for another 10 years to 1998 and to approve two new export licences for up to 110,000 tonnes of woodchips a year to February 1998. The renewal of woodchip licences and granting of new woodchip licences for the 10-year period is opposed by a large number of Western Australians. The clear-fell process which is associated with woodchipping is abhorrent to many Western Australians, including those who live and work in the forest areas. It has not been made clear to Western Australians whether the proposed pulp mill, which is supported by Premier Dowding-and in saying that I refer to a report in the West Australian newspaper of 10 August 1989 headed `Premier makes his stand on pulp mill'-and which is to be based on eucalypts is to be resourced by an additional supply of woodchips above and beyond that for which WACAP, Whittakers and McLeans have export licences, or whether the proposed eucalypt pulp mill in Western Australia is to replace the export of woodchips. Have the Department of Primary Industries and the Commonwealth and Western Australian governments already committed Western Australia to both? In addition, WACAP's plantations will be harvested by machines, which are imported mostly from Scandinavian countries. So I say that in an area short of jobs and in a country short on foreign exchange, this situation will not help.
The section of the report on water resources states:
The Department furthers objectives of the Commonwealth's water policy by:
ensuring the availability of water, adequate in quantity and quality, for all beneficial uses;
encouraging and enabling the adoption of measures which improve the efficiency and effectiveness of water supply and use; and
developing a comprehensive approach to inter-related water and land management issues.

As the States have the main Constitutional responsibility for the management and development of water resources, Commonwealth/State co-operative arrangements are central to advancing the Commonwealth's water policy objectives.

Therefore, it is not unexpected that the objectives do not include the promotion of environmentally sensitive management practices. However, given the appalling water resource situation in Australia it may well be appropriate for the Department to enlarge its objectives in line with the growing community call for environmental protection.

In Western Australia the protection of water resources, especially ground water, is inadequate and does not meet the Department's objectives. I refer in particular to recent proposals to drain the Jandakot ground water area south of Perth and the Gnangara water mound, which is north of the Perth metropolitan area. The area of environmental and conservation importance has been neglected for far too long. Already, some of Perth's ground water is polluted, and now is the time for the Commonwealth Government to act. I regret that the cooperative arrangements between the Commonwealth and the Western Australian Government can only be described as a dismal failure as far as the ground water resources of the Swan Coastal Plain are concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the annual report of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, I continue the remarks I made earlier today concerning the live sheep fiasco. Honourable senators will probably remember that in August the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) decided to cease live sheep exports to Saudi Arabia because that country had rejected a couple of shipments on the ground that the sheep were diseased. It seems to me that the problem centres on the fact that the AMLC may have acted too hastily. The report shows the importance of this trade. It shows that Australia turns off about 28 million sheep a year, of which 13.1 million are slaughtered and 7.1 million are exported, representing annual export earnings of between $160m and $200m. It is unfortunate that the resolution of this matter is going nowhere; the Department of Primary Industries and Energy is getting nowhere; the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) seems to be getting nowhere.
—Why doesn't the Minister go over there?

—As I say, the Department and the Minister are getting nowhere because they have not even bothered to go there. I know that a high level delegation was sent to Saudi Arabia but when $200m worth of exports are involved, we need more than a high level delegation to go to Saudi Arabia to find out what the problem is. I am beginning to wonder what is happening. In hindsight I can now see that the AMLC may have been too hasty in cutting off this trade.
—Perhaps it was Kerin.

—Yes, perhaps it was at his suggestion. We all have 20:20 vision in hindsight, but perhaps the AMLC could have looked at continuing shipments to the Gulf but through another port while they tried to sort out the problem with the Saudis. The Saudis say that they have been insulted because we cut the sheep shipments without resolving the problem. Australia now cannot recommence those shipments. The people who have been forgotten in this situation are the sheep farmers who are faced with a loss this year of between $160m and $200m in sales. I repeat: nothing is being done. Why is the Minister not visiting Saudi Arabia? The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) flew over that area on his way to eastern Europe. We in this place suggested that while he was overseas he call in and try to do something. Obviously Senator Evans did not visit Saudi Arabia, or we would have heard about it.

SPEECH.PARA: Upon its return from Saudi Arabia, the high level delegation said that no progress had been made, that progress was impossible and that we may have lost the sheep export trade altogether. Having read an article in one of the newspapers last Friday entitled `Trade with Saudis doomed', I am beginning to believe that the trade is doomed. If that is the case I ask what the Minister and the Department have done to secure another outlet for the sheep. It will create a problem. Not only are numbers of export wethers already being held on properties, but the numbers are increasing to the production levels to satisfy the usual demand for exporting wethers, which is at its peak in July or August. That is not that far down the track. We will be in government by then and hopefully our Minister for primary industries will do more than the present one is doing.

This is an important issue that has to be addressed immediately. We should not have to wait continually. We have been told to be patient because the Saudis are people who are easily upset when they are not spoken to nicely. We have given the Government enough time to resolve the problem but still nothing has been done. I have a few suspicions that within Australia we may have been sabotaged as we were with the kangaroo meat scandal. Because the animal liberation groups have been very active I ask whether the problem is that we might have been sabotaged by people within Australia with respect to the diseased sheep issue. I know that this is a big accusation to make; but it is time that we got some answers. Perhaps the answer lies in that direction. We certainly are not getting answers from the delegation that went to Saudi Arabia, from our Ministers or from anyone else. The producers are sick and tired of being told to hang on and be patient while nothing is being done.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I hope that this will be the second last report of the Joint Coal Board. The final report will be for the current period, following which the new Government will dismantle the Joint Coal Board. This is no reflection on Mr John Wilcox, the Chairman of the Board, for whom I have the highest regard. I do not have the same regard for the judgment of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) in pressing to maintaining an anachronistic body which simply wastes taxpayers' money without getting an adequate return. Like so many of the Government's activities, the Joint Coal Board fits into that pattern comfortably. It also provides a position of status to some members of the union movement who can be appointed members of the board.

The problem with this body is that it no longer has any reason to exist. It did have a reason to exist. The Board has done a couple of things well, for which I commend it. However, they could have been done in a totally different and much more efficient structure. The Board at present has no justification to exist. There is no doubt that in workers' compensation, for example, the Board has done an excellent job. Some assessments are that the Joint Coal Board has performed better than other workers compensation funds around Australia even though there is evidence of some cross-subsidising, which is inappropriate. The Board has also been very effective in its rehabilitation program which I know has been of significant benefit to the Burragorang Valley area that falls within my area of responsibility in New South Wales.

The problem is that the Board's other activities simply do not justify its existence. As a result I am glad to say that the coalition parties intend to wipe out the Board after they win the next election. That is what the industry wants. The industry says that there is no reason for the continued existence of this body. As usual, the Government has taken no notice of the people who know what they are talking about and is determined to maintain the Board. The Chairman of the New South Wales Coal Association in his recent report on profitability results of the industry in the latest financial year said:
. . . the challenge for both the State and Federal Governments is to rationalise the outdated institutional framework involving the Joint Coal Board and the Coal Industry Tribunal.

The Joint Coal Board relates to no more than New South Wales any more, in any event. It is not joint in the sense that it involves joint State Government activities; it is joint only in the sense that it involves the New South Wales and the Federal Governments. The big question is whether or not the industry would do better without it. A massive submission from the industry asked the Government to wipe out the Board for a range of very sound reasons. If only we had the opportunity, we could debate these reasons. It is something that should be debated in the near future. It will certainly be debated when we introduce legislation to wipe out the Joint Coal Board in the New Year.

The industry recognises that the Joint Coal Board played an important and valuable role historically, contributing much to the industry; but the circumstances which justified that role have now changed significantly and the regulatory structure which existed in the past is no longer appropriate. The industry is just struggling out of serious losses into very modest profitability; I stress that it is modest profitability. That profitability would not have existed in New South Wales if it had not been for the fact that approximately $157m in non-interest bearing loans are held by coal companies operating in New South Wales. If normal interest rates had been applied to those loans, the industry would have incurred an overall loss. The reason is that average wage rates rose strongly in the second half of the year, rail freight charges rose by 5 per cent, port loader charges rose by 15.5 per cent at Balmain and 6.7 per cent at Port Kembla in June and the standard royalty rate rose by 25 per cent in August 1989.

I would like to refer to responses which Estimates Committee E received about the Customs Service. DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY: ELECTION FUNDING AND FINANCIAL DISCLOSURE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The election funding report in respect of the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly election of 4 March 1989 is remarkably small. In fact, it consists of four pages. Nonetheless, it is extremely interesting. It states as follows:

. . . the Australian Electoral Commission is required to prepare, as soon as practicable after polling day in the first general election, a report on the operation of the election funding provisions relating to that election . . . To be eligible for public funding, a registered political party or an independent candidate must obtain at least 4% of the total formal first preference votes in the election they contested.

A table on the final page of the report sets this out. From the table one sees that nine claimants-that is, seven parties and two independents-obtained more than 4 per cent of the first preference votes. Of those nine claimants, five succeeded in returning elected members to the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Legislative Assembly. What is particularly interesting is the first preference votes and the number of members returned by each of those five parties. The Australian Labor Party obtained 22.82 per cent first preference votes and returned five members; the Liberal Party of Australia obtained 14.87 per cent first preference votes and returned four members; the No Self Government Party received 11.47 per cent of votes, and returned three members; the Residents Rally obtained 9.62 per cent first preference votes and returned four members; and the Abolish Self-Government Coalition obtained 7.5 per cent first preference votes and returned one member.

What is particularly interesting about the modified d'Hondt system is that, although the threshold chosen in the electoral system is a Droop quota-that is, the same type as that used in the Senate and the Tasmanian Hare-Clarke system-that quota is treated in a different way. In the modified d'Hondt system any party or candidate which falls below that quota is excluded immediately. This means that a very different result is reflected by using that system. It also means there is a grave unfairness in the system because the final result is that members are elected to the Assembly who actually achieve a lower percentage of votes than those who had been excluded when the quota is first assessed.

Anybody who has seen the video distributed by the Australian Electoral Commission which describes the count of that election will appreciate what a complicated matter it was because two processes had to be entered into. First there was the exclusion, and secondly the final count of the votes. At the moment the situation is under review in the ACT Assembly and in the Federal sphere, and it is to be hoped that a fairer system can be devised. In fact, if we look past the percentages and at the number of actual first preference votes required to elect a person in the Assembly, we see that whereas it took 3,412 first preference votes to elect each of the four Residents Rally members, the Abolish Self-Government coalition obtained 10,641 first preference votes and elected one member. There are inequities in the system, especially when the surplus votes of people who have been elected, who have received their quota, cannot go beyond the party line because, in effect, any d'Hondt system is a party list system. But, modified as it was, it misfired very greatly. In Australia we can regard it as an experiment which failed dismally.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: MANAGEMENT AND INVESTMENT COMPANIES LICENSING BOARD

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to comment on the Management and Investment Companies Licensing Board's annual report 1988-89. The most notable aspect of the report is the effect of outside economic influences on management and investment companies (MICs). The objectives of these MICs are, firstly, to promote the development of a private sector venture capital industry in Australia and, secondly, to encourage the provision of management skills and equity finance to young, fast-growing, export-oriented businesses using innovative technology. However, the report notes the success in achieving these two objectives was well down on previous years. The poor showing of the MICs referred to in this year's report is revealed by the following figures: applications for certification of new businesses was down to 16 from 34 in 1987-88 and 82 in 1986-87; the capital raised was well down from a high of $69m in 1986-87 to less than $16m this year; and there was a further decline for the second year running in the number of new investments for the year and a further decrease in the number of new businesses.

Yet when the overseas high risk venture capital is examined, an opposite picture is to be seen. In Australia, 1988-89 can be viewed as a disappointing year. The overseas venture capital raising companies were an outstanding success. In 1987-88 the United Kingdom saw $699.3m raised as venture capital while in Europe $2.5 billion was raised, and similar successes can be seen in the United States and in Canada. Why is there a difference between those countries and Australia? The overseas companies are flourishing while the Australian Government is set to phase out the tax deductability benefits for MICs, and thus the demise of government encouragement for high risk, high technology, high capital venture industries. The difference is in the style of government. That is where the difference is. There is a difference between the style of government in Australia and elsewhere. Here we have a government that is naive in its handling of the economy, naive in its knowledge of how a business is run.

The causes of the demise of this industry in the last two years are the general economic conditions and, in particular, the high interest rates. The MICs are the forgotten casualty of this Government's interest rate policies. Access to investment funds is crucial to the survival and growth of these MICs. Our present investment climate, particularly the capital raising environment, is dominated by nervous and cautious investors. The safer available high interest rate bank bills, short term investments and various other safer short term money market investments attract the investor much more readily than high risk, high venture capital raising companies where one's money is tied up for about four years, with the possibility of a capital gains tax being payable on the sale of the company shares. This has placed a formidable obstacle in the path of the MICs. It is regrettable that the 1988-89 lack of capital caused the existing MICs to concentrate almost all of their limited energies on shoring up existing portfolios and, consequently, they have been unable to take advantage of the many new market opportunities being offered at reasonable prices. It should be noted that the taxation system was completely different in 1983-84 when the MICs were being set up.
