SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before lunch I was just completing my contribution to the second reading debate on the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 and I was running through the amendments that we intend to propose at the committee stage in order that the Senate might be aware of them now. There were two remaining amendments. The first concerned designated technical officers. I outlined a concern earlier, in relation to the principal Bill that is the subject of this debate, about giving permission to technical officers to carry out telephone interceptions to assist the Australian Federal Police. They were to be defined according to a class of persons and I indicated that we were dissatisfied with that description. We believe that they should be named individually if they are to be given this particular responsibility. This amendment introduces another area of concern to us; that is that proposed new section 12j (3) purports to restrict the powers of these officers to providing technical assistance only in installing, maintaining, testing, using or recovering a listening device. We are concerned about the expression `using' because it seems to us that it virtually gives the technical officer the power to use the equipment in the way that that power is being given to the Federal Police officer. We believe that there is an ambiguity in there that is unsatisfactory and that by a rather simply amendment it can be overcome. Basically that amendment is to remove the word `using' so that it becomes absolutely clear that what the technical officer is doing is assisting the police officers in relation to installing, maintaining and testing the equipment, not acting in lieu of the police officer in using the telephone interception equipment. It is a small matter; nevertheless, we think it is important.

SPEECH.PARA: The last amendment I want to mention is the amendment to the Judiciary Act 1903. The effect of proposed section 55e (9a) will be to provide that when the Australian Government Solicitor gives advice to two or more government bodies on non-litigious matters he will not be acting in a conflict of interest situation. For the practical administration of government the proposed amendment should, in our view, be supported. However, an amendment is suggested by us to cover matters which, at the time of the giving of the advice, could be reasonably contemplated as giving rise to litigation. Thus we would amend the Government's amendment which refers to matters that are not the subject of litigation by adding to it, `nor matters which may reasonably be expected to give rise to litigation'. It seems to us that if there is a reasonable expectation of litigation, it would be better if the Government engaged a private solicitor rather than got itself into this potential conflict of interest situation.

As I indicated, we will be supporting the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill. We will be supporting most of the Government amendments to its own Bill, but we have outlined, by virtue of my contribution, a number of amendments that we intend to make in the committee stage to improve the legislation. I hope that our amendments, which I would not have thought are particularly controversial, will receive the support of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Australian Democrats will support both pieces of legislation: the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 and the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1989. The points that are at issue I think are probably better discussed in the committee stage, particularly a number of items that appear in the second list of amendments circulated by the Opposition on phone tapping. In the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill the Government has, for the first time, really made an attempt to codify what has been an area of enormous concern to people who have civil liberties as a main pursuit in this country. Indeed, we are lucky that we still have a very large number of people interested in the protection of civil liberties. There is always a reason why civil liberties can or should be eroded in the interests of some or in an attempt to fight crime. There is a difficulty of balance that is often hard to judge particularly when one becomes aware of the extent of crime within our community.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to canvass those items at length now, but I indicate that our general view is to have a reasonably rigid exercise on the topic of phone taps. Any extension that is sought-this Bill does seek an extension-has to be argued for very strenuously and it has to be shown why this ought to be the case, not on the basis simply that the crime may, might or possibly could be committed. If that were the sole basis upon which phones could be tapped, there would be open slather with every crime. Hopefully nobody in the community has suggested that, or ever will. The privacy of an individual must be respected. The destruction of privacy in a society in an endeavour to prevent crime could very well generate the type of society that one is trying to avoid by combating crime.

With regard to the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill, we are dealing with a matter that the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) in his second reading speech and Senator Hill have pointed to; that is, a series of reforms that are long overdue. On this particular proposition, the Opposition has moved only two amendments. Again, I will defer my comments on those amendments to the committee stage so that we can at least raise the specific items involved in each amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senators who have spoken for their indication that these two important pieces of legislation have their in principle support, although I acknowledge that some matters of detail need to be worked out in the committee stage. As for the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill, the various matters that are covered there are many. It is necessary that from time to time the portfolio review those accumulated instances where some amendment is thought desirable and is brought forward in this particular form in the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill. I thank those honourable senators who have indicated that they are willing to support those particular provisions. The most interesting is the further set of amendments that have been circulated by the Government to do with listening devices. I believe that it is extremely important that this legislation be passed for the sorts of reasons indicated by Senator Macklin and which lie behind some of the concerns which led to the drafting of the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that we put in place for the first time a provision which would make it unlawful for members of the Australian Federal Police (AFP) to use a listening device anywhere in Australia in the investigation of any Commonwealth or Australian Capital Territory non-narcotics offence otherwise than under a judicial warrant. I think all honourable senators would agree that from a privacy point of view-it is an important consideration in the type of society which we hope to construct in this nation-this represents a major improvement in the current position especially in those jurisdictions such as Tasmania, my own home State, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory where there is no control on the use of listening devices in investigation of the offences that I mentioned by the AFP.

The attempt has been to take up the code to be found in the Customs Act which allows for the issue of warrants in relation to both persons and premises, and contains a number of safeguards designed to minimise the adverse effects on an individual's privacy. A judge would not be able to issue a warrant to use a listening device unless satisfied that information about the relevant offence that is likely to be obtained by using the device cannot be obtained by alternative methods of investigation. Other safeguards include a requirement that the Commissioner of the Federal Police ensure that those under his control do not breach the prohibition on the use of listening devices; that a warrant be revoked where the Commissioner is satisfied that the grounds on which the warrant was issued have ceased to exist; a prohibition on disclosure of information obtained from the use of a listening device except in specified circumstances is to be found; the destruction of material derived from the use of a listening device where it is not required for specific purposes is provided for; and copies of warrants and reports by the Commissioner on the use of such material are to be provided to the Attorney-General. These controls will apply in all parts of Australia, irrespective of the requirements of any local State legislation that may exist.

The Senate will be considering a very important piece of legislation this afternoon. For the first time, it provides the Australian Federal Police-both in its role in the Australian Capital Territory as the community police force here and as the premier law enforcement investigative agency throughout the Commonwealth-with a comprehensive regime which will apply to it whenever it attempts to enforce the laws of the Commonwealth or the laws of the Australian Capital Territory. It is an important advance and, as we come to the committee stage, I believe we will see that there are sufficient privacy safeguards built in to perhaps make it unnecessary for Senator Hill to press his amendment at least in the form in which he originally indicated he would bring it to the committee.

The other most important piece of legislation is to do with sentencing. Two major reforms are being undertaken by this Government. One tends to overshadow the other, so I will mention the overshadowed one first. For the first time we have reviewed, in a very practical and humane way, the laws governing Federal offenders found unfit to be tried or not guilty on the grounds of mental illness. These sections of the Bill, whilst not provoking any controversy amongst those who have considered these provisions, will be found, as they are worked through over the years to come, to be an important part of this proposal.

There is no doubt that the major reform being undertaken is in relation to those Federal prisoners whom we house in the various State and Northern Territory prisons. When we look at the total prison population throughout Australia we see that on 1 July this year there were 12,429 persons in prison, of whom only 517 were federal prisoners. These people tend to be the importers of drugs, those who commit fraud against the Commonwealth, particularly against the tax laws, and social security offenders who are found usually by a magistrate-to have received a benefit to which they were not entitled. There are some 517 Federal prisoners in State prisons at the moment. Up to this time the Commonwealth has greatly appreciated the fact that the States undertake the incarceration of these persons who have offended against Federal laws and has accepted that if, in a particular State, a sentence can be discounted for a State prisoner-in other words, remissions granted on the time to be spent in prison-the same system or regime should be available for a Federal prisoner to take advantage of.

I will give an example. A few months ago I came across a case where a Federal prisoner, who received a 15-year maximum sentence for conspiracy to import heroin, was given a five-year minimum term by the judge but, with State remissions, he served only three years and one month of his sentence. I am quite sure that throughout Australia there is a growing concern that where a judge pronounces a term of imprisonment-and he or she should do so only as a last resort-both the public and the prisoner ought to know that that term of imprisonment will be served. The time to be spent in custody pronounced by the judge in open court should be acknowledged by the prisoner and known by the public to be the time that actually will be spent in prison. Under the scheme of this new sentencing proposal, the judge will be encouraged to explain in clear language to the prisoner that he or she, the judge, is setting a gaol term and a parole period. They are two distinct concepts. I think parole is extremely important as it helps a released prisoner to make the transition into community life under supervision. Certainly, parole periods should not occur before the expiry of the time set by the judge for a particular offender to spend in gaol.

I believe there is a general feeling in the community at the moment that there is something of a fraud against the public in respect of those cases where a prisoner is released before the minimum term set by the judge is served. This sentencing legislation will address that concern. In other words, I believe that the community's confidence will be restored, certainly in respect of Federal prisoners, and in many other jurisdictions around Australia. State governments are coming to the same conclusion and introducing similar laws.

It needs to be made clear-and I am sure that the Senate, in supporting this proposal in principle, will understand-that we are not looking for more draconian penalties, we are not looking for greater severity; we are looking for certainty. That is the aim of this proposal. Senator Hill brought up the question of the `release on licence' provision, which he indicated might undermine this principle to some extent. That is to be used in those cases where, for example, a prisoner is found to be suffering a severe illness, such as cancer, which may lead to death. Of course we would not want such a person to linger in prison. The opportunity is there to grant a licence in those cases. But it is meant to be used in those exceptional circumstances and certainly not in the automatic way where remissions are known to the prisoner as he walks into the prison from the court. That automatic entitlement, which is calculated and known virtually from day one in prison, is what we are attacking and, I believe, will have the firm support of the public.

There are matters of concern which can be dealt with at the committee stage in relation to both the pieces of legislation. In the meantime, I thank those who have indicated their support for the second readings of these Bills. I commend the second readings to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: CRIMES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 7, clause 6, after proposed subsection 16a (2), insert the following new subsection:

`` `(2a) Before imposing a sentence or making an order, the court shall invite the victim of the offence and any other person who has suffered injury, loss or damage resulting from the offence to inform the court of his or her personal circumstances and of any injury, loss or damage resulting from the offence, and the court shall, in imposing the sentence or making the order, take into account any such information so provided to the court.''.

I dealt with the argument for this amendment in my speech on the second reading and I do not wish to repeat it. However, there is a growing community view that, in sentencing offenders, the court not only should take into account the circumstances of the victims but also should give the victims the opportunity to put those circumstances to the court. The legislation that the Government is seeking to pass today sets out very detailed criteria that the judge is to take into account. Most of the detail concerns the nature of the crime or the status of the offender. By this amendment we seek to make it clear that the victim has the opportunity to put the victim's case to the court to be taken into account in the assessment of sentence by the judge. We have, therefore, moved the amendment accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The amendment moved by the Opposition, as Senator Hill said, speaks to a widespread community concern about whether or not the criminal justice system tends too much towards the support of people accused of crime. Indeed, under our system, hopefully, that will always remain part and parcel of the operation of our criminal law so that we can, as much as is possible, guard against the unlikely event of an innocent person being found guilty of a crime. However, we have some difficulties with the amendment moved here by Senator Hill. If we look at the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) itself, on page 7, `Matters to which court to have regard when passing sentence etc.', we find this:

SPEECH.PARA: In determining the sentence to be passed . . . a court must impose a sentence or make an order that is of the severity appropriate in all the circumstances of the offence.
As Senator Hill has already said, that was partly amended in the House of Representatives at the end of the second reading debate. It then goes on to say this:
. . . the court must take into account such of the following matters that are known to the court:
Paragraph (d), interestingly enough, reads:
the personal circumstances of any victim of the offence;
and paragraph (e) reads:
any injury, loss or damage resulting from the offence . . .

In other words, the substance of the Opposition's amendment is already in the Bill. Indeed, it seems that the phraseology used by the Opposition has been taken directly from the Bill. The Opposition has suggested that at the other end of the exercise this ought to occur again. The court will already have heard the personal circumstances of the victim of the crime. The court now needs to be acquainted with those personal circumstances, and if the court is not acquainted with them, it is obvious that the judge is going to have to be acquainted with them.

`Any injury, loss or damage resulting from the offence' would normally be made known during a criminal trial. So, interestingly enough, I think that a lot of the items that the Opposition is maintaining ought to be dealt with in fact have been dealt with by the Bill itself.
Secondly, I think there is a problem with the introduction at the Federal level of the amendment which the Opposition has chosen to draft. The amendment, in part, says:
Before imposing a sentence or making an order, the court shall invite the victim of the offence and any other person who has suffered injury, loss or damage . . .

I am not at all sure what the legal fraternity will make of that when dealing with the tax law. I presume that `any other person who has suffered injury' with regard to a tax offence would be everybody within the Commonwealth. It would not in fact, because the amendment is dealing with a person; presumably, it is not dealing with the Commonwealth as the Crown but rather with the injury caused to people. In some way, one might feel interested in going into court with regard to some of the frauds committed on the public purse and actually having a say about what should happen to the person. Be that as it may, I think we might find ourselves in some considerable difficulty on that. I am quite sure that that interpretation is not the intention that the Opposition wanted to achieve in that amendment, but it does seem to be something of a problem.

The third problem is that this particular arrangement in my understanding is novel. Senator Hill said in his speech during the second reading debate that it is in operation in South Australia. By way of private comment to him afterwards, I did say that that had not been the advice given to me, and I hope that at least we can have some clarification now as to whether this is in place in South Australia. My understanding was that it is at least possible and, indeed, under the rules laid down in the crimes legislation and the operation of the Federal Courts, certainly no judge would be constrained in any way to call upon the victim to make a statement if he felt constrained to do so with regard to the provisions set down in the sentencing principles. If a judge felt in any way that the information was deficient, I would imagine that is precisely what a judge would proceed to do. It is not that one wants to rule out the substance of the amendment, but I do have great difficulty in actually putting the amendment into the legislation in the way in which it is drafted and at the particular time that it occurs.

I suppose my last feeling of some reticence to deal with this matter is a feeling-and it may be a conservative feeling-that it has been the established practice of the courts to allow out all the items that are relevant to any particular crime, for the jury to make its deliberations and then, upon that deliberation, for a determined process of the court to proceed. Of course, there is a possibility of a plea of mitigation where the prosecution, if it is in that criminal context, is able to disagree. So the items to which Senator Hill alludes are in some ways already performed, although not necessarily, as I understand the Opposition's amendment, by the person themselves. I am not at all sure how many people will actually want to take this particular option. Senator Hill did allude to the interest that the community has in making sure that the victim of a crime is not, as it were, shuffled off into a corner as at least it has appeared in the past. Quite frankly, I think that is probably what compelled the Government under its sentencing principles to actually state that personal circumstances and injury ought to taken into account.

As Senator Hill might well know, it is not only that which has to be taken into account. Indeed, if one uses the widow's rite argument, stealing the total wealth of a widow and stealing $100 from Senator Hill are materially the same crime, but in effect, of course, would have quite different circumstances. Of course, many criminals when committing crimes would not necessarily know what the outcome of the crime would be. So we cannot just simply say that it is the effect on the victim that is the only thing to be taken into account. Other principles are to be alluded to, including the quality of the offence, as it were, of itself and in itself. It is for those reasons that we have reservations, not about the principle that Senator Hill is seeking to enshrine, because that is, on my reading of if-and I would be interested in hearing Senator Hill's response-already enshrined in the legislation which we are currently passing, but rather about the way in which Senator Hill, in his amendment, has attempted to go about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government cannot accept this amendment moved by Senator Hill on behalf of the Opposition, and for basically some of the reasons which Senator Macklin indicated. First of all, I think we have to understand that the number of Federal offences that have an identifiable victim are relatively small. It is not impossible but it is very difficult to actually envisage a victim, in terms of Senator Hill's amendment, who would come forward. Most Federal offenders are drug traffickers or people who commit a fraud against the Commonwealth-against the tax laws, as mentioned by Senator Macklin, or the social security system and so on. While there is a general range of victims, really almost every Federal offender who faces a term of imprisonment would not be being convicted with respect to an offence against an identifiable victim. Admittedly, there would be a couple of exceptions: for example, where the murder, kidnapping and assault of internationally protected persons, heads of state or diplomats, or the hijacking of aircraft and so on are dealt with. But, thank God, these are very few and far between in our country. I believe that we have to deal with the general situation, which is that there are no identifiable victims in most cases of Federal offences which have led to convictions in our courts.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also important to give due weight to proposed section 16a (2) (d) and (e). If it is an appropriate case, the court must take into account relevant matters known to it, such as the personal circumstances of any victim of the offence and any injury, loss or damage resulting from the offence. Of course, that would be made known to the court by the prosecution at the sentencing stage. Perhaps Senator Hill is more conversant than I with the system in South Australia, but I believe that there the victim does not come before the court. That is a crucial difference between Senator Hill's proposition and the situation in South Australia. In that type of jurisdiction, where quite clearly crimes of violence are being prosecuted and convictions recorded on a daily basis, I commend Mr Chris Sumner, the Attorney-General, for his very real interest in and pursuit of the question of victim impact statements. But once again, I do not think that in South Australia the victim is invited to appear.

Whether or not that is the case, that would certainly accord with the general understanding of the criminal law in our system of common law as modified by statute and sometimes by a full code of criminal law. In the old days, the prosecuting of the criminal law was under the general title of `pleas of the Crown'. Indeed, when one looks at a criminal case it is entitled `The Queen against' or in the United States, for example, `The people against'. In other words, whilst a crime obviously has a particular victim in the case of murder, rape, assault or whatever it may be along those lines, nevertheless the offence is characterised as criminal because it is seen as an offence against the whole community. Indeed, it is the community which has an interest in prosecuting and securing the conviction of an offender because it is an offence against society's well-being-against the peace of the Queen, if you like, and against the well-being of society in a more general sense. In the title to an indictment one might see that philosophy underlying criminal law well displayed.

We certainly do not want to get to the situation in this country where, perhaps, the type of sentence awarded depends on how articulate a victim is in recounting to a court the suffering experienced at the time of an attack and subsequently. If an inarticulate person is perhaps overawed or simply does not want to come forward because of the trauma of recounting a matter, will that lead to a lesser sentence than in the case where a person has come forward and with great descriptive power recounted the horrors of the attack and outlined the subsequent suffering that was caused? There are very real difficulties here. I believe that we must not turn our criminal law or court system into one where revenge on the part of the victim becomes part of the sentencing process. It is important that the court know of the personal circumstances and any injury, loss or damage suffered by a person who is the subject of an attack. That can be made known through the prosecutor in the way I have indicated.

The Government, for all those reasons, cannot accept this amendment, but I emphasise that it is not out of a lack of interest in the question of victim impact statements. Their application in the case of Federal offenders would be minuscule. I believe that at the Australian Police Ministers Council, which is to be held in Darwin in March, this matter is on the agenda, put there by South Australia. It concerns, particularly, how the United Nations statement in relation to victims of crimes, adopted at the seventh United Nations congress on the prevention of crime and treatment of offenders, might be more generally applied in different ways to the various jurisdictions around Australia. That will be a most interesting discussion and a useful forum for discussing the way in which victim impact statements might be made available to court. But I do not believe that the Opposition's way of making them available should commend itself to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate that the Government and the Australian Democrats are not going to support this additional reform we are suggesting. Whilst I am disappointed in that, I nevertheless recognise, as Senator Macklin has indicated, that the provisions of the Government's Bill require the court to take into account the personal circumstances of any victim of the offence. We are pleased that the Government has been prepared to go that far. We certainly were not looking at it as an opportunity for revenge, but we do believe that the common law position, as outlined by Senator Tate, has already been departed from and, in effect, including the provision to take into account the particular circumstances of the victim demonstrates that.

SPEECH.PARA: The question now is how the court should obtain or seek that information. In some circumstances-for example, where there has been a plea and the judge has not been exposed to the circumstances of the victim-simply to be handed up some form of brief by a prosecution counsel does not, in our view, give the judge a sufficient understanding in some cases of the costs and consequences to victims of crime. Therefore we have sought in this amendment to take the process of reform one step further, that is, to invite the victim to put to the court his or her case as to the particular circumstances of injury, loss or damage. We cannot see that any damage to the system would be done by that. We can only see that it would enhance the system.

With regard to the reference to another person who suffered such injury, loss or damage, we had in mind that it might have been, subject to the difficulty the Minister has outlined of a Federal offence, an assault on two persons but the charge for one reason or another is brought only against one person. Nevertheless the circumstances of both victims, we would have thought, should be able to be taken into account by the judge. Therefore the judge should have the opportunity and, in fact, under our amendment, would be obliged to hear those victims as to the circumstances of the offence that was perpetrated upon them. I recognise the numbers, and at least I am pleased that the amendment the Government has brought does, in our view, take a step in the right direction.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 17, clause 9, proposed subsection 19al (1) lines 3 to 11, leave out the proposed subsection.

(3) Page 17, clause 9, proposed subsection 19al (2) lines 13 to 15, leave out ``a federal life sentence or a federal sentence of, or federal sentences aggregating, 10 years or more and a non-parole period has been fixed in relation to the person in respect of the sentence or sentences'', insert ``a federal sentence and a non-parole period has been fixed in relation to the person in respect of the sentence''.

These amendments relate to the question of the non-parole period. As the Bill stands at the moment, the Attorney-General does not have any discretion, for an offence with a sentence of more than three years but less than 10 years, to so act at the end of the compulsory period of imprisonment as to avoid release of a person. We say that there will be circumstances where there may be additional information that was not known at the time or there may be questions of the behaviour of the prisoner during the term of his or her imprisonment where this extra discretion would be useful and, in fact, important to the Attorney-General and should be contained. We think that additional discretion is important and should be included. Therefore, we seek to make the position consistent, whether the penalty is for a term in excess of 10 years or a term between three and 10 years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -These amendments pose another difficulty when one is looking at a question of balance. We are dealing here with the Opposition, which wants to go back, as I understand it, to the three-year exercise and onwards, where the Attorney-General would then be involved, and the Government, which wishes to restrict that to a post-10-year sentencing period. In many ways the normal operation of parole might be said to be reasonable until one is dealing with more serious crimes. I presume that the Bill, as the Government has introduced it, leans on the notion that after a certain period one is dealing with extremely serious criminal offences that could warrant the intervention of the Attorney-General in addition to the normal procedures by which parole is set by parole boards and the various appeal mechanisms.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has not made out its case as to why we should depart from the Government's original proposal. It is reasonable that, in the less serious cases, normal procedures ought to take place. I read the debate in the House of Representatives, where the Opposition argued these amendments, and also I have listened to Senator Hill. But I have not heard yet a compelling argument as to why one would pursue the Opposition's amendments in place of the Government's amendment. The Government amendment has the advantage of fitting in with the overall structure as it is set out in the Bill. There needs to be a serious reason to destabilise that by supporting amendments. At the moment, the only reason to do so is that undoubtedly there is community concern about a lot of early releases. In part, that has driven the Government to adopt, as it were, truth in sentencing proposals to try to get some more consistency and stability into the process. That is what a significant part of this Bill is about. In that sense, I think the Government has gone a long way-certainly a lot further than we have gone to date-in dealing with this matter. That is why I say that the Government's proposal fits into the framework better than do the Opposition's amendments.

The Government's proposal seems to come from a slightly different tack-that the Attorney-General will be involved in almost the entire panoply of the exercise with regard to parole. I am not at all sure that the obvious advantages in having a general parole mechanism and, certainly, the general parole exercises should be lost. It would be more appropriate at the moment to continue with the framework set out in the Bill. It is possible that at a later stage this will be reviewed. I presume Senator Hill will tell us that the Opposition will review it when it comes into government in a couple of months time, so we probably will not have too long to wait before this Bill is re-presented with that change in it. In the meantime, it might be better to stay with the framework set out by the Government rather than dropping in something which is slightly alien to the general concept of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept the amendments moved by Senator Hill on behalf of the Opposition. Those amendments would undermine the general fairness of the proposition being put to the Committee-that is, that a prisoner ought to know with certainty, and the community demands to know with certainty, that when a judge pronounces a gaol term that term will be served.
—This doesn't undermine it.

—No, but the prisoner is entitled to know that at the end of that gaol term he or she will be able to take advantage of the parole system. There is something of a balance to be struck between all the parties in this exercise-society, the court and the convicted person. I believe that it is important that the prisoner be told, as he or she will be, by the sentencing judge or magistrate that serving a sentence will entail a period of imprisonment for a certain time and, in addition, a parole period of a certain time, and that a person will have served his or her sentence only when that is all completed.

SPEECH.PARA: In the sentencing range of three to 10 years of imprisonment, that certainty and predictability for all parties is important. I do not believe that the Attorney-General should exercise a discretion to vary that certainty. In regard to sentences of 10 years or more, an ability is vested in the Attorney to delay the release of the prisoner. That has been put in as a matter of some cautious anticipation, I suppose, of a situation developing in the case of a person in gaol for longer than 10 years for a very serious offence which would make the release of the person on the due date something which society should guard against.

Whilst one could assume that the Attorney, even in instances of a person who had served a sentence of 10 years or more, would wish to ensure that the person is taken under the wing of the parole system as soon as possible so that reintegration and rehabilitation into the community can be supervised and facilitated, there may be instances where something comes to light which would lead to some delay in moving the prisoner into the parole system. I concede that that is somewhat arbitrary. But in relation to those who are imprisoned for a period of three to 10 years, the Government believes that its certainty principle need not be adorned with the sort of discretion which is vested in the Attorney in regard to sentences of 10 years or more. This is an important underlying principle. I concede that a line had to be drawn somewhere. We drew it at 10 years. Senator Hill's amendments would undo what is sought to be achieved in principle by this legislation as voted for at the second reading stage-that is, to introduce at the sentencing stage the certainty which I think the community requires.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to have one more attempt at persuading Senator Macklin because I think there is a strong argument on consistency alone. Therefore, it's worth a go. The Minister acknowledged that the difference between subclause (1) and subclause (2) is somewhat arbitrary. In fact, it is totally arbitrary because the Minister has included in the Bill two separate punishment regimes which totally differ, depending on whether one is sentenced to nine years imprisonment or 11 years imprisonment. We have said that there should be one system. Our preference is for the subclause (2) alternative, which is what Senator Macklin might have described as the more traditional mode.

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested to hear the rationale of punishment as expressed by the Minister. I had not heard it quite in those terms-that is, that when someone is now sentenced they are sentenced to a fixed and specified period of incarceration, the non-parole period, and a fixed and specified period of parole. We have never seen it quite in those terms. We have envisaged a person sentenced to imprisonment for the fixed term as determined by the judge-for the purpose of this debate let us say that it is 10 years-and an obligation on the judge under this legislation to set down a period of those 10 years which the person must serve in prison; that is, the non-parole period. Let us say for the purpose of this example that the non-parole period is six years. We argue that nevertheless the term of imprisonment was to be 10 years, as specified by the judge. When a person has served the prescribed minimum non-parole period as determined by the judge, in this case six years, probably in most cases he will be released under parole. However, some circumstances could come to light afterwards, as I indicated. The Minister acknowledged that that is a legitimate factor to be taken into account in the case of imprisonment for a period of over 10 years; I believe it is equally legitimate to be taken into account for a term under 10 years. That might lead the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to consider that in all the circumstances the person is not ready for parole. There could, as I indicated, be evidence that was not available at the time of sentencing-evidence that has come to light since. It could be something to do with the behaviour of the person in prison. Whatever it may be we believe that it is a better system of justice that allows the Attorney-General to have that discretion.

We are conscious of the very difficult job that those who administer the prison system experience and the concerns that they have in circumstances where a prisoner knows that he will be released on a specified date, whatever might be his behaviour. In other words, they argue for some incentive for good behaviour to make the prison system manageable in circumstances which are always difficult. Therefore, they would prefer-we support them in this instance-that the Attorney-General have some continuing discretion, a continuing capacity to force the prisoner to serve the initial sentence set by the judge or at least a greater part than the judge thought at the time was necessary before that person was released on parole. We urge Senator Macklin to consider the value of giving the Attorney-General that extra discretion, the flexibility that it allows, so that we will have consistency in the legislation and, therefore, an improved system upon that which the Minister has outlined.

We commend the fact that there will be a fixed non-parole period, in other words, that there will not be early releases as we have experienced in the past. I note the comments made that the licensing system would be used only in extreme circumstances. That debate is now behind us. The debate that we are addressing now is: what is the correct position upon completion of the non-parole period; should the Attorney-General then have a discretion upon the release of the prisoner or should the prisoner have a right of release at that time?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The point made by Senator Hill is a reasonable one with regard to proposed subsection 19al (1). We are probably setting a fairly firm exercise, one that does not provide a great deal of flexibility. But further on in the clause we have to note that we have more flexibility than Senator Hill was prepared to acknowledge. The difficulty in proceeding with what Senator Hill is suggesting is, as I said before, that we are taking one particular item in a general context. It is not only on this page. If we go through the rest of the Bill in terms of its structure we see these particular items built in. In terms of the amendment as it was drafted, I am not at all sure, but for example, under subsection 19ap relating to release on licence I think it would involve some consequential amendment. In terms of a parole order being automatically revoked, which is the next section, we would be dealing with some consequential amendment. Undoubtedly there are some other parts of this Bill which would involve consequential amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: The difficulty that I have is that, while the proposition may be reasonable in terms of its different philosophical framework, I must admit that I would prefer that we put in place a Bill on this particular matter at this time. I am not sure whether Senator Hill will disagree with that; I think he will probably agree. I do not know whether Senator Hill is able to assure me 100 per cent, absolutely, that there are no consequential amendments. I happen to think that there are probably some. We are faced, in terms of the pre-Christmas context, with no time available. For all his eloquence I am afraid I must desist from taking the bait that he offered. I would much prefer to actually proceed with the legislation before us in the hope that in its implementation the difficulties that Senator Hill alluded to will be overcome. Quite rightly, there could be some difficulties; I have a sneaking suspicion that one of the propositions that he raised will bring forward an amendment at some stage with regard to one or other person. We will suddenly find ourselves in a fair amount of difficulty-at least the Attorney-General will-and an amendment may come back at that stage. It is not that I cannot see some validity in the argument that Senator Hill is pushing. It is because of our desire to have intact a Bill that is able to be passed into law at this particular time that we cannot support the amendments.
Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.

Amendments (by Senator Tate)-by leave-proposed:
(1) Page 1, clause 2, line 10, leave out ``Sections 1 and 2'', insert ``Parts 1 and 1b''.

``PART 1a-AMENDMENTS OF THE AUSTRALIAN FEDERAL POLICE ACT 1979
Principal Act
``2a. In this Part, `Principal Act' means the Australian Federal Police Act 19791(a).
``2b. Before section 6 of the Principal Act the following heading is inserted in Part II:
`Division 1-General'.
``2c. (1) After section 12a of the Principal Act the following Division is inserted in Part II:
`Division 2-Use of listening devices in relation to general offences
Definitions
`12b. In this Division:
``class 1 general offence'' means a general offence that is an offence of any of the following kinds:
(a) murder, or an offence of a kind equivalent to murder;
(b) kidnapping, or an offence of a kind equivalent to kidnapping;
(c) an offence constituted by:
(i) aiding, abetting, counselling or procuring the commission of; or
(ii) being in any way, whether by act or omission and whether directly or indirectly, knowingly concerned in, or party to, the commission of; or
(iii) conspiring to commit;
an offence of a kind referred to in paragraph (a) or (b);
``class 2 general offence'' means a general offence that is an offence of any of the following kinds:
(a) an offence against:
(ii) the Secret Commissions Act 1905; or
(iii) section 13, 14, 15, 16 or 20 of the Crimes (Offences against the Government) Act 1989 of the Australian Capital Territory;

(b) an offence (other than a class 1 general offence or an offence of a kind referred to in paragraph (a)) punishable by imprisonment for life or for a period, or maximum period, of at least 7 years, where the particular conduct constituting the offence involved, involves, or would involve, as the case requires:
(i) loss of a person's life or serious risk of loss of a person's life; or
(ii) serious personal injury or serious risk of serious personal injury; or
(iii) serious damage to property in circumstances endangering the safety of a person; or
(iv) trafficking in narcotic drugs; or
(v) serious fraud; or
(vi) serious loss to the revenue of the Commonwealth or the Australian Capital Territory;
(c) an offence constituted by:
(i) aiding, abetting, counselling or procuring the commission of; or
(ii) being in any way, whether by act or omission and whether directly or indirectly, knowingly concerned in, or party to, the commission of; or
(iii) conspiring to commit;
an offence of a kind referred to in paragraph (a) or (b);
``customs narcotics offence'' means an offence punishable as provided by section 235 of the Customs Act 1901;
``designated technical officer'' means a person declared under section 12e to be a designated technical officer;
``eligible Judge'' means a Judge in relation to whom a consent under subsection 12d (1), and a nomination under subsection 12d (2), are in force;
``general offence'' means:
(a) an offence against a law of the Commonwealth that is not a customs narcotics offence; or
(b) an offence against a law of the Australian Capital Territory;
``general offence inquiries means:
(a) inquiries in relation to a general offence that has been committed or is reasonably suspected of having been committed; or
(b) if there are circumstances reasonably giving rise to the suspicion that a general offence is likely to be committed-inquiries in relation to the likely commission of the offence;

``listening device'' means any instrument, device or equipment capable of being used, whether alone or in conjunction with any other instrument, device or equipment, to record or listen to spoken words;
``official'' means:
(a) a member; or
(b) a designated technical officer;
``premises'' includes:
(a) any structure, building, aircraft, ship or vehicle; and
(b) any land (whether or not enclosed or built on); and
(c) any part of premises (including premises of a kind referred to in paragraph (a) or (b)).
Application of Division

`12c. (1) Nothing in this Division applies in relation to the use, in circumstances prescribed for the purposes of this subsection, of a listening device under a warrant issued under a law of a State or Territory, being a law prescribed for the purposes of this subsection.

`(2) Nothing in this Division, or in a warrant under this Division, applies in relation to the use of a listening device for a purpose that would, for the purposes of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979, constitute the interception (whether or not in contravention of subsection 7 (1) of that Act) of a communication passing over a telecommunications system within the meaning of that Act.
Judges eligible to issue warrants for use of listening devices
`12d. (1) A Judge of a court created by the Parliament may, by writing, consent to be nominated by the Minister under subsection (2).
`(2) The Minister may, by writing, nominate a Judge in relation to whom a consent is in force under subsection (1) to be a Judge who may issue warrants under section 12g.

`(3) An eligible Judge has, in relation to the performance of a function or exercise of a power conferred on an eligible Judge by this Division, the same protection and immunity as a Justice of the High Court has in relation to proceedings in the High Court.
Appointment of designated technical officers
`12e. (1) The Commissioner or a member appointed, in writing, by the Commissioner for the purposes of this subsection may, by writing, declare:
(a) a staff member to be a designated technical officer; or
(b) a class of staff members to be designated technical officers.
`(2) A person who is a designated technical officer stops being a designated technical officer if the person stops being a staff member.
Use of listening devices in relation to general offences

`12f (1) It is unlawful for an official to use, for the purposes of general offence inquiries that are being made by members, a listening device for the purpose of listening to or recording words while they are being spoken by a person unless:

(a) the official is the speaker of the words or is a person, or is included in a class or group of persons, by whom the speaker of the words intends, or should reasonably expect, the words to be heard; or
(b) the official listens to or records the words with the consent, express or implied, of a person who is permitted by paragraph (a) to listen to or record the words; or
(c) if the general offence concerned is a class 1 general offence or a class 2 general offence-the official does so in accordance with a warrant under section 12g and the provisions of this Division.

`(2) It is unlawful for a person acting by arrangement with an official to use, for the purposes of general offence inquiries that are being made by members, a listening device for the purpose of listening to or recording words while they are being spoken by a person unless the first-mentioned person is the speaker of the words or is a person, or is included in a class or group of persons, by whom the speaker of the words intends, or should reasonably expect, the words to be heard.
`(3) It is the duty of the Commissioner to take reasonable steps to ensure that subsections (1) and (2) are not contravened by officials.
`(4) Despite any law of a State or Territory:
(a) an official does not act unlawfully merely because the official uses a listening device as mentioned in subsection (1) in circumstances to which paragraph (1) (a), (b) or (c) is applicable; and

(b) a person acting by arrangement with an official does not act unlawfully merely because the person uses a listening device as mentioned in subsection (2) in circumstances in which the use of the device is not declared to be unlawful by that subsection.
Warrants for use of listening devices
`12g. (1) A member may apply to an eligible Judge for a warrant under this section authorising officials to use a listening device in relation to a particular person or particular premises.
(a) the application is for a warrant authorising officials to use a listening device in relation to a particular person; and
(b) the Judge is satisfied, by information on oath:
(i) that the person has committed, or is suspected on reasonable grounds of having committed, or of being likely to commit, a class 1 general offence or a class 2 general offence; and

(ii) that information that would be likely to be obtained by the use by officials of a listening device to listen to or record words spoken by or to the person would be likely to assist members in, or in relation to, inquiries that are being made in relation to the commission, or likely commission, of the offence by the person; and
(iii) that, having regard to the matters mentioned in subsection (6), some or all of that information cannot appropriately be obtained by methods of a kind referred to in paragraph (6) (a); and
(iv) if the offence is a class 2 general offence-that, having regard to the matters mentioned in subsection (7) and no other matters, such a warrant should be issued;
the Judge may issue a warrant authorising officials to use a listening device for the purpose of listening to or recording words spoken by, to, or in the presence of, the person.
`(3) The warrant may authorise:

(a) officials to enter any premises in which the person is, or is likely to be, for the purpose of installing, maintaining, testing, using or recovering a listening device or a part of a listening device; and
(b) the use of a listening device for the purpose of listening to or recording words spoken by, to, or in the presence of, the person anywhere in Australia.
(a) the application is for a warrant authorising officials to use a listening device in relation to particular premises (which may be premises anywhere in Australia); and
(b) the Judge is satisfied, by information on oath:

(i) that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that the premises have been or are likely to be, used in relation to the commission, or likely commission, of a class 1 general offence or a class 2 general offence; and

(ii) that information that would be likely to be obtained by the use by officials of a listening device to listen to or record words spoken by or to persons in the premises would be likely to assist members in, or in relation to, inquiries that are being made in relation to the use, or likely use, of the premises in relation to the commission, or likely commission of the offence; and
(iii) that having regard to the matters mentioned in subsection (6), some or all of that information cannot appropriately be obtained by methods of a kind referred to in paragraph (6) (a); and
(iv) if the offence is a class 2 general offence-that having regard to the matters mentioned in subsection (7) and no other matters, such a warrant should be issued;
the Judge may issue a warrant authorising officials to use a listening device for the purpose of listening to or recording words spoken by or to any person while the person is in the premises.
`(5) The warrant may authorise officials to enter the premises for the purpose of installing, maintaining, testing, using or recovering a listening device or a part of a listening device.
`(6) For the purposes of subparagraphs (2) (b) (iii) and (4) (b) (iii), the matters to which a Judge is to have regard are as follows:
(a) the extent to which methods of conducting inquiries in relation to the offence that do not involve the use by officials of a listening device have been used by, or are available to, members;
(b) how much information of a kind mentioned in subparagraph (2) (b) (ii) or (4) (b) (ii), as the case may be, would be likely to be obtained by such methods;

(c) how much the use of such methods would be likely to prejudice inquiries in relation to the offence, whether because of a delay in obtaining some or all of that information or for any other reason.
`(7) For the purposes of subparagraphs (2) (b) (iv) and (4) (b) (iv), the matters to which a Judge is to have regard are as follows:
(a) how much the privacy of any person would be likely to be interfered with by the use by officials of a listening device in relation to the person or premises concerned;
(b) the gravity of the conduct constituting the offence;
(c) to what extent information of a kind mentioned in subparagraph (2) (b) (ii) or (4) (b) (ii), as the case may be, would be likely to assist in connection with inquiries in relation to the offence.
`(8) A warrant under this section must be:
(a) signed by the Judge issuing the warrant; and
(b) in accordance with the appropriate prescribed form.
`(9) A warrant under this section may be expressed to be subject to conditions or restrictions specified in the warrant.
`(10) If a warrant under this section authorises officials to enter premises:
(a) the warrant must state whether entry is authorised to be made at any time of the day or night or only during specified hours; and

(b) the warrant may specify that entry may be made without permission first being sought or demand first being made, and may authorise measures that the Judge is satisfied are necessary to effect the entry.
`(11) A warrant under this section must specify a period (not exceeding 6 months) for which it is to remain in force.
`(12) Subsection (11) is not to be construed as preventing the issue of any further warrant.
Information to be given in support of application for warrant
`12h. Information given to an eligible Judge for the purposes of subsection 12g (2) or (4):
(a) may be given orally or otherwise; and
(b) must include the facts and other grounds on which the applicant considers it necessary that the warrant should be issued.
Exercise of powers under warrant

`12j. (1) The authority conferred by a warrant under section 12g is to be exercised only by the Commissioner or other members approved, for the purposes of the warrant or warrants under that section, by the Commissioner or a member appointed, in writing, by the Commissioner for the purposes of this subsection.
`(2) Despite subsection (1), a designated technical officer may provide technical assistance to a member who is exercising the authority conferred by the warrant.

`(3) A reference in subsection (2) to the provision of technical assistance includes a reference to the doing of any act in relation to installing, maintaining, testing, using or recovering a listening device, or a part of a listening device, in accordance with the warrant.
Discontinuance of action before expiration of warrant
`12k. If, before a warrant under section 12g expires, the Commissioner is satisfied that the grounds on which the warrant was issued no longer exist, the Commissioner must immediately:
(a) take such steps as are necessary to ensure that action authorised by the warrant (other than the recovery of a listening device or a part of a listening device) is discontinued; and
(b) revoke the warrant by signed instrument.
Application of certain provisions of Customs Act
`12l. Sections 219f to 219k (inclusive) of the Customs Act 1901 apply for the purposes of this Division as if:
(a) references to a warrant under section 219b, or under Division 1a of Part XII, of that Act were instead references to a warrant under section 12g; and
(b) reference to narcotics inquiries were instead references to general offence inquiries; and
(c) references to a Judge were instead references to an eligible Judge; and
(d) references to an instrument issued under section 219e of that Act were instead references to an instrument issued under section 12k; and

(e) for the purposes of the provisions of subsections 219f (1), (2) and (3) (other than paragraph (2) (a)) of that Act, the Australian Federal Police were the only Commonwealth law enforcement agency within the meaning of that Act; and
(f) any other necessary changes were made.'.
