SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: No. 1.-Proposed new section 12b, definition of ``class 2 general offence'', paragraph (b), leave out the paragraph.
No. 2-Proposed new section 12b, definition of ``class 2 general offence'', paragraph (c), leave out ``or (b)''.

Both amendments deal with the question of class 2 general offences. We also touched upon this debate in the second reading stage of the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 and, therefore, I want to limit discussion at this time, particularly bearing in mind the time of year. Whilst we accept the right of the Australian Federal Police to use the telephone interception method as part and parcel of its investigatory capacities in serious criminal activities-serious criminal activities beyond those of narcotic offences-nevertheless we are concerned that the amendment the Government is seeking to enact into law today goes too far. We have no concern with that part that deals with class 1 general offences, which speak of murder, kidnapping and aiding and abetting of the same. We have no concern with the first part of class 2 general offences, which are specified in the Government's amendments which list section by section of the Crimes Act, the Secret Commissions Act or the Crimes (Offences Against the Government) Act 1989, but we are concerned with the next part, which simply gives a generic description of offences; in other words, it gives the terms of the penalty for offences with a maximum period of at least seven years, plus general detail of the type of criminal activity.

In the case of some of those areas of general activity my concern would have been less. For example, the first is `loss of a person's life' but, as I have indicated, murder is already covered within the class 1 general offence. But as I move down this list of the types of criminal activity I become more concerned. For example, if I go to the last type of criminal activity on the list, involving `serious loss to the revenue of the Commonwealth or the Australian Capital Territory-I certainly will not argue that an offence that causes a loss of revenue to the ACT is not necessarily serious-we, on this side of the chamber, are concerned as to whether it is of such a nature that it warrants giving police officers the power to intercept telephone calls.

As I have said, whilst we do not want in any way to inhibit effective policing, nevertheless, we are concerned by the continued movement to extend the power of telephone interception. I know that that is a little irrelevant to this debate; but we can reflect momentarily on press reports over the last few days that have been referring to alleged illegal telephone interceptions by the Australian Federal Police and, in the case of the Bond companies, to another set of illegal telephone interceptions. I think the whole area is one of growing community concern. I touched on that argument only momentarily-it is not strictly relevant to this debate-because clearly, those interceptions were illegal.

What we are talking about here is the extent to which the power to legally intercept should be extended and I am submitting to the Committee that the Government has taken this a little too far. For example, as I am advised, this description of offences would include offences such as stealing postal articles, failing to renew an export or import licence, providing false or misleading information regarding agricultural chemicals and damaging data in Commonwealth computers. Obviously, those offences are serious-I will not argue it-but I question whether they are the types of offences that should justify the police having what most of us would regard as an enormous capacity to invade privacy through telephone interception. We would like to see that capacity left to what the community would generally interpret as very serious crime to be utilised when other more traditional methods of policing prove unsatisfactory.

We are surprised by the way in which the Government has moved to these amendments. For example, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) said in the other place that these amendments are to be an interim measure. We do not understand that. The Government has had many reports and considerable time within which to determine a fixed and settled position in this acknowledged difficult debate. It has had the report of the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interceptions dated 30 January 1987; it has had Australian Law Reform Commission reports into privacy and criminal investigations, which are found in the Law Reform Digest of 1983; and it has had volume 1 of the report of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions, which Commission investigated the Age tapes. So a lot of carefully prepared material has been put on the public record. What has happened, though, is that this Government has said that, at this stage, it can only put before this chamber an interim measure. We do not understand that. We cannot see why the Government cannot have a final and conclusive position. If we look to the Law Reform Commission's report as the basis for the Government's justification of this move, we find that it sets out a whole series of recommendations, one of which concerns the seven-year penalty; but many of the others are not picked up, and we do not understand why the Government has picked this up without picking up the other protections that are included in the Law Reform Commission's report. I could take the Minister through all of those protections, but I will not do so; he can read the report. I would like to know why, in these circumstances, the Government has picked up this provision which extends the power of police officers without looking towards the additional safeguards.

The Government should specify offences that justify the Australian Federal Police having this unusual power of telephone interception. It should not talk about classes or types of offences; it should be specific. Only in those circumstances should the Parliament be asked to give to the police force these additional powers. Our amendments Nos 1 and 2 to the Government's amendment have the effect of removing class 2 general offences under subclause (b). Certainly, that would force the Government to go away and come back, if the Parliament sits again under its authority in the new year, and bring a specific list of offences that it wishes us to pass into law in relation to this extended power. I think that better law would result from that course of action than from adopting the amendment that the Government has put.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with listening devices, not telephone interception. This was a confusion of language which I do not think was entirely intended by Senator Hill during his contribution. His general theme was that we would need to justify giving the Australian Federal Police the capacity to install listening devices in order to gather information and intelligence relating to the commission of an offence. However, what has to be understood is that it is happening every day now without a statutory regime. There is nothing unlawful about the Federal Police using listening devices in relation to their investigation into the commission of a crime at the moment-for example, in the Australian Capital Territory in the instance which Senator Hill alluded to.

SPEECH.PARA: I could have allowed that situation to continue. But instead of allowing for an unfettered ability to use those listening devices-always, of course, within the law relating, for example, to their installation in particular premises-it has, nevertheless, been thought wise and proper, for the very reasons that Senator Hill put forward, to bring into this Parliament a regime to regulate the obtaining of permission to use these listening devices from a judge.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not just listening devices placed in the building? They can be listening devices extraneous to the building?

—Yes, of course. I have mentioned premises because obviously it would be unlawful to break and enter a premises in order to install a listening device, and that could not be permitted even now. The sorts of concerns that Senator Hill brings forward are, of course, the reason for dividing the particular classes of offences into class 1 and class 2. Class 1 offences are the sorts about which there would be no argument. Class 2 offences are those which are very serious, and that is indicated by the need for a possible term of imprisonment of seven years or more to be attached to the commission of an offence. But class 2 carries with it further protections over and above those which apply where one applies for a warrant in relation to a class 1 offence.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at proposed section 12g (2) (b) (iv), one sees that, in addition to the various matters which the judge needs to take into account when dealing with class 1 offences, he has to have regard to matters mentioned in sub-section 7, which states that for the purposes of the relevant subparagraphs, the matters to which a judge is to have regard-and this is in class 2 offences only-are as follows:
(a) how much the privacy of any person would be likely to be interfered with by the use by officials of a listening device in relation to the person or premises concerned;
(b) the gravity of the conduct constituting the offence;
I interpolate there that that would probably deal with the minor interference with the postal articles matter that Senator Hill pointed to. And:
(c) to what extent information of a kind mentioned in subparagraph (2) (b) (ii) or (4) (b) (ii), as the case may be, would be likely to assist in connection with inquiries in relation to the offence.

They are additional safeguards specifically put in. I remember the debate in our Caucus committee-led in a most vigorous way by our friend and colleague Senator Barney Cooney, who insisted that further protections be placed in relation to these other offences than was already the case in general.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the qualification where other investigative procedures have been tried and failed, or are impracticable?

—That covers both class 1 and class 2. That is an essential in both instances. But in relation to class 2 offences there are those particular provisions inserted in proposed section 12g (7). I think they amount to an answer to Senator Hill's concerns. There is a much greater responsibility on the judge to satisfy himself as regards the gravity of the offence, the invasion of privacy concerned, and the sort of assistance that might be obtained from the use of the device.

SPEECH.PARA: It might be that some further amendments may be required in light of the practice that evolves, but I believe that we have here an attempt by Parliament to regulate the way in which the Australian Federal Police use these listening devices. It is most essential. It is important that the safeguards that are indicated there be given due weight.

The list of the class 2 offences deals with matters where I believe the community would agree to seeing police forces use listening devices-for example, serious personal injury or serious risk of serious personal injury. It would be an intolerable matter if there were a serial rapist or a serial basher of old women roaming around the Australian Capital Territory and the police force could not use a listening device in order to help nail the attacker. In relation to trafficking in narcotic drugs it seems to me to be very sensible that one would be able to use a listening device, as one can in relation to the importing of such drugs.

I believe we have here an indication of the types of offences that are involved. They are serious offences. The offences are punishable by a term of imprisonment of at least seven years. I believe that in these situations and with the sorts of protections and safeguards that I have outlined, which are additional to those relating to class 1 offences, the Committee could safely reject the amendment moved by Senator Hill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to this section, I ask the Minister whether, if the Opposition's amendments were carried, the Government would proceed to proclaim this particular piece of legislation. The reason I ask is that fairly obviously, if we have an unregulated situation at the moment and we seek to bring in regulation, what this Bill is in fact doing is making much more specific and constrained the operation of the police force. Since one of the items is with regard to trafficking in narcotic drugs, it does not seem to be sensible, in the case, for example, of a person who has a tape-recorder strapped to him in an endeavour to gather evidence of a drug offence, that we should move to prevent that sort of practice occurring. Although we would like to see a regulation in this area, we accept the general thrust of what the Opposition is saying. The difficulty I am having now is that if this amendment is accepted we may end up preventing the Government from proceeding because it will impose such a restriction on police in a number of areas-I referred to narcotics, but the restriction would also apply to other areas such as extortion, threats and the like-that it would prevent them from taking the action which they are currently taking and which is totally acceptable to the community. It would certainly not be our intention for that to occur.

SPEECH.PARA: We are in somewhat of a dilemma. The Bill itself is acceptable in terms of a restriction by putting in place a regime of control in an area where it is necessary. Yet if we subscribe to Senator Hill's amendment, which follows much the same philosophy which induced the Government to introduce the Bill in the first place but takes it a bit further, we could end up killing off the Bill. I seek the Minister's response to that point before I continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a new regime which puts in place a constraint, as Senator Macklin said, on the Australian Federal Police in regard to investigation of crimes committed particularly in the Australian Capital Territory. The constraints are not confined to that area but most of the class 2 offences will be those which occur in the Australian Capital Territory. I must confess that I did not quite grasp the exact kernel of Senator Macklin's question so I wonder if he might just briefly repeat it.

-If the amendment moved by Senator Hill were to be accepted I wonder where the Government might go. I used the example of a policeman who might have a tape-recorder strapped to him in regard to a class 2 subparagraph (iv) general offence, trafficking in narcotic drugs, which is a fairly normal exercise as the Minister well knows.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have to consult the Attorney-General. The temptation would be to drop the project and to say, `Let's leave the situation as it is where the Australian Federal Police are not regulated by any statutory regime'. I would be very loath to do that. It would go against everything that we are seeking to achieve particularly with the extra privacy protection in relation to this class of offence. I do not utter that as any sort of threat. I simply say that that is one thing that would have to be considered.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police would wish to be consulted also on the effect of carrying the amendment which would be to disable the use of those devices in regard to trafficking in drugs or serious personal injury cases, rape and so on. I do not believe that could be tolerated in the community if it thought that the police could not use these listening devices in those instances; therefore, the only way to enable their use would be to withdraw this whole project. That would have to be the subject of discussion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposition which the Minister has set out is the one that I assumed might be the case. That is why I asked for clarification. I acknowledge that since I had not discussed this matter previously with the Minister, he did not have the opportunity to consult prior to this time. In perusing the list that Senator Hill wishes to delete, it seems to me that there is a very strong analogy between class 1 general offences, particularly those in paragraph (a)-murder, or an offence of a kind equivalent to murder-and class 2 general offences, subparagraphs (i), (ii) and (iii) dealing with serious matters. The legislation sets out such matters as involving cases where a person could either lose his life or is in serious risk of loss of life. Class 2, subparagraph (iv) offences-trafficking in narcotic drugs-is the one in which the community has expressed itself very clearly in favour of wider powers for police forces to be able to deal with what the community perceives as being an extraordinary attack upon itself. However, I must admit that the last two subparagraphs, (v) and (vi)-serious fraud and serious loss to revenue-of class 2 offences seem to be somewhat at variance with those. I seek Senator Hill's indication as to whether or not he wishes to push ahead with the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: I indicate that we would support the deletion of subparagraphs (v) and (vi), but could not support the Opposition with regard to deleting the ability of police to deal with a range of matters that are likely to cause a person's loss of life or to undermine in any way the ability of the police force to deal with trafficking in narcotic drugs, having quite clearly in mind that under the Customs Act dealing with the importation and operation of narcotic drugs, the police force already has the ability to use listening devices. All we are talking about here is the next step down the track. It would be passing strange if we said, `You can use all of these devices to catch people bringing drugs into the country but you can't do that in regard to what often is the very lead item to that type of importation-the trafficking that goes on within the country'. Senator Hill well knows this from his service on the Joint Statutory Committee on the National Crime Authority. I seek Senator Hill's comments as to whether or not it is his intention to press ahead. I indicate that a restriction of the deletion to offences in class 2 subparagraphs (v) and (vi) would be a totally different matter. Taking those out would leave those more serious and equivalent crimes to class 1 general offences in the legislation. I am not at all sure that offences in the categories of subparagraphs (v) and (vi) should have been in the legislation in the first place. They seem to me to be of a totally different kind, possibly class 3 general offences.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —While Senator Hill is looking at the proposition which has just been put to him, I will speak for a moment. I do not understand-probably because I have not focused from the outset as carefully as I ought to have-why there is a problem with the Bill if it is simply required by amendment to specify the offences. I will just return to something that Senator Hill said earlier on. I understand the point being made by Senator Tate that much of the legislation has sought to lay down some penalties and some provisions to deal with the question of unlawful intercepting of telephone calls and of recording of conversations.

SPEECH.PARA: It was from that point that the legislation originally moved. In recent times telephone interceptions and recordings of what normally would be private conversations have not been the last resort of those acquiring evidence or demonstrating prima facie evidence of an offence or the likelihood of the commission of an offence. There has been a temptation for it to be the first resort, rather than the last resort. We all understand that. It is a great deal easier for people in the business of law enforcement if they can use the facilities at their disposal. I acknowledge the point that has been made by Senator Tate that the granting of a warrant for the planting of a device should be available only when other investigative procedures have been tried and failed or where they would be impractical-or words to that effect. I would have thought that is the least that should be provided in terms of a safeguard.

The great problem with privacy-and it is sad that it is not debated often enough in this Parliament-is that it is a rather abstract, esoteric concept. When we are dealing with law and order, this concept has to compete with the harsh reality of what is defined as the common good. In this day and age, when we regularly read on the front pages of newspapers about organised crime-whether of a white collar or drug related nature-there is a capacity for the public to imagine that such crime has to be dealt with in the most draconian way. In that environment, it may be that society can be tempted by the emotion of the debate to trample on the individual and personal rights of people on the basis that the common good will be better served if those rights are sacrificed. This debate cannot be dealt with objectively and reasonably in that sort of environment. Therefore, it is incumbent upon governments and legislators-of whatever part of the Parliament they come from-not to allow the emotions of the moment, the emotion of the debate or temporary circumstances to be used as a forum or platform for a more intrusive form of invasion of privacy.

I well remember, as we all do, the height of emotion that was reached with the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and the wild allegations that were made, many of which fell to the ground. Indeed, references which were transferred to a new authority were found to be of no consequence. In that environment it is ter- ribly easy for a government to come to the Parliament and say, `We must deal with this terrible, insidious, pernicious disease that is corrupting us. We must cleanse ourselves of it and take whatever steps are necessary. If it means, just for the time being, subjugating the rights of individuals, so be it, because there is a greater common good to be had'. As I say, it is incumbent upon governments to make decisions in the long term with a measured reflex and consideration, and not simply to accommodate short term concerns that we might have.

I hope I have given the Minister sufficient time to negotiate with Senator Hill. I always find it interesting in these debates-and this is not a reflection on anybody who has participated today-that there seems to be a contrast as to what the definition of a `civil libertarian' is. I can give a bad example: I well remember that when Michael Chamberlain came to my office to plead the case of his wife, Lindy, I selected the names of several people who I thought would be receptive to his appeal-people who had held themselves out as caring for individuals' rights and the preservation of those rights, and having a compassion that is unparalleled by right wing, fringe lunatics such as me. I found, when I contacted these people, that he could not even get in the door to see them.

They had judged. I do not say that in an abstract and unkind way. I simply say that nobody has got a mortgage on these things. One does not have to be a refugee from East Timor to need protection in this world. An ordinary John Citizen in Australian society deserves the same consideration as those other people deserve. I hope that, as we look at this legislation, we will consider those things.

I ask myself: Why the measure of seven years? As Senator Hill quite properly pointed out, there are some offences that would not be judged, by definition, to fall within the category of `serious'. The concern I have is that expressed by Senator Hill-that the Government has not defined the offences. I suspect that will make it much easier, at a later date, to amend the legislation. Let us remember that whatever is passed in this Parliament is, in the future, always judged to be right. When we seek to amend legislation we always work on the premise that the legislation before us is the benchmark of what is right and what is wrong, and we just try to adjust it accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer the general points raised by Senator Crichton-Browne and then proceed to the actual amendment.
—He should withdraw that slanderous attack on himself.

—I am advised by Senator McKiernan that Senator Crichton-Browne should withdraw that slanderous attack on himself. I would like to set Senator Crichton-Browne's mind at ease, because if he glances at proposed section 12g (6), he will see, in relation to all class 1 and class 2 offences, that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the matters to which a Judge is to have regard are as follows:
(a) the extent to which methods of conducting inquiries in relation to the offence do not involve the use by officials of a listening device have been used by, or are available to, members.

The judge has to make that judgment. I agree with Senator Crichton-Browne that it should not be the first resort. The use of these devices should be made available by a judge, on argument, after he has considered whether an alternative method of obtaining the information has been, or could be, usefully employed.
In relation to our class 2 offences, proposed new section 12g (7) states:

. . . a Judge is to have regard . . . how much the privacy of any person would be likely to be interfered with by the use by officials of a listening device in relation to the person or premises concerned; the gravity of the conduct constituting the offence.

Those criteria were deliberately put in as additional matters which the judge has to take into account. I am sure that would give some of the protections which Senator Crichton-Browne quite rightly seeks in this legislation in relation to this intrusion into the privacy of those in our community who might fall under suspicion. It is an important matter which, I think, has been left for far too long to be remedied. I believe we are at one in seeking to get the balance right in that regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —After some brief negotiations with the Australian Democrats, and discussions with the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), I seek leave to amend my amendment No. 1, so that it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new section 12b, definition of ``class 2 general offence'', subparagraphs (b) (v) and (vi), leave out the subparagraphs.

We are still of the view that this would be better legislation if it specified the offences that come within this definitional provision. Nevertheless, realistically, it is impossible to do that from this side of the chamber at this stage of the debate. On the other hand, Senator Macklin was quite persuasive in his comments about not wanting to exclude the provision in relation to trafficking in narcotic drugs. Therefore, we would be excluding the reference to serious fraud or serious loss of revenue of the Commonwealth or the Australian Capital Territory. If this amendment attracts the support of the Committee, I would not want it to be thought that there may not be, within that description, offences which should be specified in the legislation. There may well be. We invite the Government, during its last few months of office, to consider amending this provision so that it specifies the offences which it wishes to be covered by this regulatory regime.

I am sorry that I confused the listening device provision with the telecommunication interception device provision. The latter is referred to in the Bill and the former is included within the amendment to the Bill which the Government has put today. In those circumstances, I hope that my confusion can be forgiven. In fact, I have amendments to both, so that makes it all the more complicated. I seek leave to amend my amendment in the way I have outlined, and that would also include not pursuing my amendment No. 2.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Government will, without dividing, oppose Senator Hill's amendment. I understand the reasoning which Senator Macklin put forward which has proved attractive in negotiation between the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. I think that Senator Crichton-Browne hinted at a reason why it should not be accepted; that is, since the time of Mr Frank Costigan QC and his revelation of the terrible damage that is done to society by persons who engage in fraud against the tax base of this country, which provides the money for the elected governments of this country to carry out their programs, it has been found not to be as easy as it was thought 10 years ago to distinguish between serious criminal activity, being that which affects individuals and which involves identifiable crimes such as assault, battery or rape, and those cases where the whole of society is greatly damaged by major fraud carrying severe penalties, as indicated by the Parliament saying that the offence if proved could carry a term of imprisonment of not less than seven years.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst there are true distinctions between an offence which leads to a personal injury and one that defrauds the general revenue, I do not think they have the significance which would allow the dropping of clauses (5) and (6) out of the paragraph relating to the definition of class 2 general offences. I might also, as a matter of good faith, say that I will undertake, in relation to the comprehensive legislation which we hope to bring forward next year in relation to this whole area--

TALK.START.PARA: —When next year will that be?

—Very early, probably. I will undertake to have a look at the listing of specific offences. I can see the point that the honourable senator is making, but this has been brought in as an interim measure in order to provide a legal regime. We can certainly look at the question of listings of specific offences when it comes to the more comprehensive legislation next year.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 1 (Senator Hill's), as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new subsection 12j (3), leave out, ``, using''.

I foreshadowed this amendment in the second reading debate. It concerns technical assistance being given in relation to listening devices. We accept that technical assistance might be given in relation to maintaining, testing or recovering listening devices but we argue that the Government, by including the word `using', has confused the issue and may well allow an interpretation that such technical assistance goes to operating the listening device, whereas that should clearly be limited to the police officer. Therefore, I have moved the very simple amendment that the word `using' be deleted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be supporting Senator Hill's amendment. The problem I have with the amendment is that it seems to me that, of all the things relating to technical assistance, using it may be the most important issue. Maintaining and testing is all very well, but if one is confronted with some of the devices that Senator Hill and I have seen, knowing how to use the thing would be of great assistance. Without that I cannot see why one would bother. The reference here seems to be straightforward enough. We are talking about technical assistance, and it is covered under the exercise of powers under the warrant. Under sub-clause (2), a designated technical officer may provide technical assistance to a member. This merely says what type of technical assistance one is going to get and the basic one, I would have thought, would be using it, otherwise there would not be much point in having it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was wavering but I am compelled by Senator Macklin's argument to respond. It must be the case that obviously ensuring that the device is functioning properly, at the time that one needs it to function properly, is the key to securing the assistance of a technical person. I think a couple of things ought to be said. Firstly, it ought to be very clear from proposed section 12j, on page 7, that it is always the case that the warrant is obtained by and is authorising activity by a sworn police officer. It is not as though the technical officer can go on a frolic of his or her own; it is always in assistance to a member. For example, proposed section 12j (2) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a designated technical officer may provide technical assistance to a member who is exercising the authority conferred by the warrant.

It is always the sworn member who is exercising the authority conferred by the warrant and the technical assistance is rendered to that member. I believe that that is an additional point which might weigh with the Committee in considering the amendment that Senator Hill has proposed.

The technical assistant is also a member of the Australian Federal Police; I think that also has to be remembered. We are not talking about a technical assistant brought in on a contract or somebody who is phoned up at the local electrician's to come in and give some assistance to the sworn police member-it will be another member of the Federal Police. In that situation we have, particularly with the unified work force concept, a very real protection against the abuse of this situation which perhaps Senator Hill feared. For all those reasons, in addition to the compelling reason put forward by Senator Macklin, I would ask the Committee to reject the amendment.
Amendment (Senator Hill's) negatived.
Amendments (Senator Tate's), as amended, agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 3 to 21-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 22 (Interpretation).
Amendment (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
(3) Page 7, clause 22, lines 8 to 16, leave out the clause, insert the following clauses:
Interpretation
``22. Section 219a of the Principal Act is amended:

(a) by inserting `in relation to whom a consent under subsection 219aa (1), and a nomination under subsection 219aa (2), are in force' after `Territory' in paragraph (a) of the definition of `Judge' in subsection (1);
(b) by omitting from subsection (1) the definition of `prescribed offence' and substituting the following definition:
` ``prescribed offence'' means:
(a) a narcotics offence; or

(b) an offence (other than a narcotics offence) against a law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory punishable by imprisonment for life or for a period, or maximum period, of not less than 3 years;';
(c) by inserting in subsection (1) the following definition:
` ``premises'' includes:
(a) any structure, building, aircraft or ship, or a vehicle or other carriage; and
(b) any land (whether or not enclosed or built on); and
(c) any part of premises (including premises of a kind referred to in paragraph (a) or (b);'.
``22a. After section 219a of the Principal Act the following sections are inserted:

Use of listening devices

Certain information not to be disclosed

(b) by omitting paragraph (2) (a) and substituting the following paragraph:

(i) an official of that agency; or
(ii) an official of the other Commonwealth law enforcement agency; or
(iii) an order of the Police Force of a State of Territory; and'.
Certain records to be destroyed
``22d. Section 219g of the Principal Act is amended by omitting subparagraph (b) (i) and substituting the following subparagraph:
`(i) in, or in connection with, a relevant proceeding; or'.''.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 23 to 28-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Amendment (by Senator Tate) proposed:
(4) Page 11, after Part 10, insert the following new Part:
``PART 10a-AMENDMENT OF THE JUDICIARY ACT 1903
Principal Act
``28a. In this Part, `Principal Act' means the Judiciary Act 19039A.
Australian Government Solicitor
``28b. Section 55e of the Principal Act is amended by inserting after subsection (9) the following subsection:

`` `(9a) In the application of subsection (9) in relation to matters that are not the subject of litigation, that subsection does not prevent the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department, or a person authorised under subsection (4), from acting for 2 or more parties in the same matter.'.''.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill, your amendment No. 4 is appropriate now to Government amendment No. 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the provision in relation to the Australian Government Solicitor, which I also outlined in my speech at the second reading stage. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4.) Proposed new section 28b inserting proposed subsection 55e (9a), leave out ``that are not the subject of litigation,'', insert ``that:
(a) are not the subject of litigation; and
(b) are not reasonably expected to give rise to litigation;''.
I do not think that it is necessary that I repeat the argument that I put earlier today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just looking for a piece of paper which indicates that what the Federal Government is attempting to do here has already been done in the case of New South Wales over the last two years. The Legal Profession Act 1987 No. 109 of New South Wales provided that the Crown Solicitor may act under subsection 2 with or without charge, or for a party in a matter that is not the subject of litigation even if also acting under that subsection for another party in the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, the Opposition amendment would have the effect of requiring an Australian Government Solicitor (AGS) officer, who is asked by one client for advice on an issue that involves another entity for which the AGS may act, to consider whether the issue might be expected to give rise to litigation. It would not suffice for him or her to confine himself or herself to the content of the request for advice and conclude that as he or she simply has no means of forming a reasonable opinion on the prospect of litigation the situation is one which is not reasonably expected to give rise to litigation. The officer concerned would be obliged to make some inquiry as to the prospects of litigation and would need for this purpose perhaps to consult both the client and the other possible party or parties. For each of those consulted the issue would turn primarily on the, as yet, undetermined content of the advice to be given. Furthermore, the issue of whether to litigate an issue arising between Commonwealth agencies would commonly not be decided without prime ministerial consultation.

I believe that the sort of simplification of the situation, as attempted to be achieved by the Government amendment, ought to be accepted. I believe that the Opposition amendment would be extremely difficult actually to operate. But, as I have said, I think that we have already had some experience in another jurisdiction, in New South Wales, where a similar provision to that which is proposed has been operating successfully for two years. I believe that in that situation the Committee could feel able to accept the Government amendment and reject that proposed by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposition that the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) puts seems to us to be a reasonable one. The difficulty I have with the Opposition's amendment is identical to one of the reasons raised by the Government; that is, the difficulty of being able to ascertain whether or not something may give rise to litigation. Those types of circumstances certainly would not be known to the officer and, in some circumstances, could very well be a delicate matter that resides in some other area. Senator Hill, quite rightly, proposes to substitute the words `are not reasonably expected to give rise to litigation'. That, as it were, softens the blow and suggests, to all intents and purposes, a thorough and conscientious investigation. The Minister does raise a rather intriguing idea that the matter becomes a conundrum inasmuch as what might give rise to litigation might actually depend on the advice which is being asked about in the first place. That would be an impossible situation to disentangle. I think that it might be best, therefore, to stay with the Government's proposition, the more restricted and certainly definite context, because we know whether the litigation is under way. We should trial that exercise. The proposition put forward by Senator Hill might make it more restricted. It might not turn up even in the New South Wales system, which the Minister has referred to, or even under this system. I think that it might have been more beneficial to do it in the way that Senator Hill has suggested. The difficulty that has been raised is sufficient to indicate that we should not go down that path and that we should stay with the certainty of at least knowing about the matter which is being litigated.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (Senator Hill's) negatived.
Amendment (Senator Tate's) agreed to.
Clauses 29 to 43-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 44 (Who may exercise authority conferred by warrant).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Page 15, clause 44, proposed paragraph 55 (5) (b), line 16, leave out ``maintenance, testing or use'', insert ``maintenance and testing''.

We are now dealing with telecommunication interceptions as opposed to listening devices and my amendment is in similar terms to one I recently lost in relation to listening devices. Therefore, I must say that I do not launch into this with great confidence. Nevertheless, whilst I have great respect for Senator Macklin, I think that he did misinterpret the technical assistance provisions of the previous debate. What we are doing here is defining what amounts to technical assistance. Once we have so defined that expression, then we give that power to designated technical officers. It is so defined by this provision to include use. Therefore, I stand by the position that I argued earlier that by virtue of this definitional provision--

TALK.START.PARA: —It has to be assistance.

—No; the technical assistance we are speaking about is having the capacity to do this work. Technical officers can only conduct technical assistance. Technical assistance is defined by the Government's provision to include use. We would like to presume that the Government and the police officers will not utilise the provisions in that way, but I do not think that as a legislature we should so assume and, therefore, it is our responsibility to legislate language that is unambiguous and in this instance there should not be a confusion that would allow in our view-on a strict reading of this language-a technical officer to carry out the function or operation of the telecommunication interception device which should be reserved for those designated police officers who have that responsibility. Therefore, my amendment is to remove the words `or use'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the time-honoured manner, and with great respect to Senator Hill, I think the suggestion that we should completely redefine the word `assistance' is not on. It is assistance with use. What has occurred in the last amendment occurs here. Which button should be pushed? Having been confronted with this huge array of buttons, a person wants to know which button to push to get the silly thing started to actually record. In one part of Senator Hill's speech he spoke about technical officers using the equipment. This is not a definition of technical officers; it is, in fact, a definition of technical assistance. It still has to be assistance. A person cannot in any way operate in an assisting fashion if he takes over the role of the operator; he has to assist. A person could be sitting in this desk with a warrant and next to him could be a person with technical assistance showing him which button to push. That would be technical assistance. It would be perfectly legitimate under the Act to sit in the back of a car doing a mobile surveillance exercise. I do not think that any of the people who have a warrant to undertake these exercises ought to have any understanding of how the machinery works. The guts of the matter is that they ought to be able to seek technical assistance with maintenance and testing.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 15, clause 44, proposed subsection 55 (6), lines 19 and 20, leave out ``, or classes of persons.''.
This is my last amendment and last effort with this Bill. Subclause 6 provides:

The Commissioner of Police or a person who is an approving officer under subsection (3) may, in writing, declare persons, or classes of persons, to be designated technical officers for the purposes of subsection (4).

We argue that it is inappropriate to describe a group of persons in those general terms. They should be named before they are given this power, this authority. There is no reason at all why the Commissioner of Police cannot so specify the persons, why he should take the short cut, the easy option, of simply designating a class of persons which presumably would be those who are designated officers with whatever grade of technical experience. We do not think that that short cut is appropriate in these circumstances and would require the commissioner or the approving officer to specify those who have been given this power and responsibility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government cannot accept this amendment as it would create particular difficulties. I emphasise that the person to be designated as a technical officer is so designated by the Commissioner under section 12e, to be found on page 4 of the circulated Government amendments. It cannot be emphasised enough that the technical officer is a member of the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and is, under the unified workforce concept, working alongside and part of the team which constitutes the Australian Federal Police. Nevertheless, it remains true that the execution of the warrant can only be undertaken by the sworn police member, but the designated technical officer is as much a member of the AFP as is that sworn police member.

SPEECH.PARA: There need not be the sort of concern which seems to underlie Senator Hill's amendment that would lead one to have to specify each technical officer who might be involved in ensuring that the equipment operates successfully. I believe that it will cause some difficulties in identifying those technical officers who might be available at any one time, perhaps on short notice, to repair or ensure that the listening device is working as it ought to. I suppose that can be overcome one way or another. I believe that it is an unnecessary amendment, and I ask the Committee not to accept it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Australian Democrats will support Senator Hill's amendment. I acknowledge the point raised by the Minister that this amendment will make things more difficult. However, one of the advantages of Senator Hill's amendment is that it makes things more definite. The Government's philosophy throughout this exercise has been to make things definite, predictable and understandable. I hoped that we would not go to the other extreme and have a warrant with a large number of names on it, hoping to catch everybody who may attend as a technical assistant. I suppose that is legally possible but it certainly would be an abuse of what I hope the Committee is about, that is, knowing quite definitely and in writing-after all, the Government has not sought this information verbally; it has sought to have the information in writing-the names of the people involved. That would provide, in terms of litigation that may arise, a certainty that would be useful. Merely to say `any classes of persons' would create a formality about the warrant which I believe would make a farce of the rest of the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I accept that it is a difficulty, and that it is a technical problem that the Commissioner will have to face, but I believe that we ought to have in writing the names of the people who are involved, in the same way as we have the names of the people who are involved as principals in the operation of this exercise.
Amendment agreed to.
Amendment (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
(5) Page 15, clause 44, lines 22 to 24, leave out proposed subsection (7), insert the following subsections:
`` `(7) A person may not be made the subject of a declaration under subsection (6) unless the person is a staff member within the meaning of the Australian Federal Police Act 1979.
`(8) A person who is a designated technical officer stops being a designated technical officer if the persons stops being a staff member within the meaning of that Act.'.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate to the Committee that I will not be proceeding with amendment No. 6 which has been circulated in my name.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 reported without amendment, and Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Tate) read a third time.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That intervening business be postponed till after consideration of the General Business Orders of the Day relating to the Australian Commonwealth Games team.
Debate resumed, on motion by Senator Crichton-Browne:
That the Senate-
(a) notes:
(i) the decision by the Australian Commonwealth Games Association (ACGA) to refuse to allow Athletics Australia to increase the size of the Australian track and field team from 70 to 85 members,
(ii) that the maximum allowable size under the Commonwealth Games rules of the Australian athletic team is 118,
(iii) that each of the 85 athletes selected has performed to a level which, based on the last Commonwealth Games, would qualify them for the finals at the Auckland Games,

(iv) that the ACGA has acknowledged that there is no financial impediment to a team of 85 athletes competing, that adequate accommodation within the Commonwealth Village at Auckland is available and that uniforms and competition uniforms are available for 85 athletes,
(v) that, notwithstanding the great travel distances involved, the Canadians and English are each sending track and field teams with in excess of 110 members,
(vi) that the decision not to increase the team size to 85 athletes is a procedural matter, and
(vii) that there is no practical reason why these 15 young Australian athletes should not be given an opportunity to represent their country; and
(b) calls upon:
(i) the ACGA to reverse its decision and allow these athletes an opportunity to represent Australia, and
(ii) the Government to convey to the ACGA the view that the 85 qualifying Australian track and field athletes be allowed to compete in the Auckland Commonwealth Games.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I thank Senator Crichton-Browne and the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lewis interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a humble person by nature.
—Can Hansard record `Laughter from Opposition benches'?

—I am sure Hansard will manage. As honourable senators would be aware, I spent quite some considerable time today in conference with officials from Athletics Australia and the Australian Commonwealth Games Association to try to reach a settlement of this dispute. The important thing to note about this dispute in the last few weeks is that there are many things, of which I am aware, that I have not made public and have quite deliberately not done so because I sought a solution. I never sought simply to take sides or to try, as the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, to make decisions which, quite properly, belong with the sporting groups themselves. Today it has been agreed that Mr John Coates, one of the foremost sporting administrators in the country-he managed the last Olympic Games team, is the chairman of the selection review panel of the Australian Olympic Federation, has had a long and distinguished career as an administrator in rowing and was also vice-chairman of the Sports Commission; he has a pretty impressive line of credits to his name-should step in and settle some real questions that have been raised about the 85 athletes and whether or not all 85 of them ought to be going to the Commonwealth Games.

SPEECH.PARA: I said when speaking to the motion this morning that it would be inappropriate for and remiss of the Senate, unaware as honourable senators must be of some of the goings on in this dispute in the last few weeks, let alone the selection criteria which need to be met for these athletes to go, to make a decision. I put it to the Senate that as we now have agreement between the parties, we have an expert in the field of selection and management of sporting teams-I might say the foremost expert in this field in the country-now arbitrating upon this decision in the certain knowledge that his decision will be accepted by both sides, why do we need to pass any resolution of this kind? The reality is that Mr Coates could recommend 40, 50, 60 or 85 athletes. It will be up to him, as he talks to Athletics Australia, to go through the records of the athletes, to go through the selection criteria, and then make a recommendation to the Commonwealth Games Association. Naturally enough, it is in the position of okaying the teams, so a document will have to be produced for it, and that is proper. But it has indicated-and has said so publicly today-that it will accept his recommendation.

In the light of all that, any statement here that says `We accept the 85' really is the height of folly. It may be that the 85 athletes go, and it is certainly true that I and a number of others have kept out of the public arena a great many things that have happened in this area in the last few weeks, because to canvass them then-indeed, to canvass them now-would only have exacerbated a situation which I have spent a great deal of time and effort today sorting out. It would give me a thrill in some respects to stand up and go through some of these arguments, but it should be enough for honourable senators to know, as is acknowledged by Athletics Australia as well as the Commonwealth Games Association, that selection criteria certainly have been an issue in the last few weeks. Obviously, when one gets into personal disputes, it is all about who said what to whom, on what day, was there a telephone hook-up or not, who said there should and should not be, et cetera, but behind those sorts of spats real questions have been raised, and I think today I came up with the only real way of resolving that, short of the continuation of a brawl that is doing Australian sport great harm.

Having managed to get the agreement of the Commonwealth Games Association and Athletics Australia to this process, I think it would be much more appropriate for the Senate to defeat Senator Crichton-Browne's motion and endorse what has been done today. That is the only course of action that makes sense for the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I raise a couple of points in closing the debate on my motion. The first is that I did not have an opportunity to respond this morning, but I want to say that I find it offensive for Senator Richardson to suggest that he is the only one who has any knowledge of these things. I think there is a touch of irony about the portly and corpulent Senator Richardson telling us that he is the expert on sport in this country or that he is the font of all wisdom. Senator Richardson said at his press conference that the Senate does not select the team. This motion does not seek to select the team; it simply expresses a view about a whole range of things. No doubt when the team comes back with gold medals the Government will be first on its feet moving motions congratulating the athletes on their endeavours.
—It will be a race with you.

—I can assure Senator Richardson there will be no race with us. The truth is that this Senate is simply expressing a point of view, which is that 85 young Australian athletes, both men and women, have had to fulfil criteria set down for them by Athletics Australia, the body that controls track and field events for the Commonwealth Games. It has selected 85 athletes. Athletics Australia looked at the performance at the last Commonwealth Games of each one of those athletes and used that as its criterion to decide that they would have qualified for the finals. In fact, it would go further than that and say that on the best performances thus far of the athletes they are capable of qualifying for the finals of these Commonwealth Games.
—Edinburgh was boycotted by the blacks.
—I said that its assessment is that the athletes would qualify for the finals of these Games. In each case, their best performance puts them in the top eight.
—It isn't even the assessment of everyone in athletics.

—I can only tell it as it is. I can think of no more cruel fate than for 85 young men and women, having been told that they are going to the Commonwealth Games, now to find that they are going to be culled and some kid is going to have to hand back his blazer as a result of some bureaucratic mess, some disagreement between Athletics Australia and the Australian Commonwealth Games Association. It has never been publicly suggested before, to my knowledge, that anything has been wrong with the selection criteria of Athletics Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Let it be understood that each sport has its own panel of selectors. The Australian Bowls Council selects its own bowlers; badminton's governing body selects its own badminton players; the swimming federation selects its own swimmers; and Athletics Australia selects its own athletes, and that is what it has done. It is the first time that the question of selection has been raised publicly, and it would be a bitter disappointment, of course, to any kid now to be denied a place. To my knowledge, there has been no question about the selection procedures for any other team. If my memory serves me correctly, every other team will have filled its quota. In the case of athletics, Athletics Australia is entitled to fill 118 positions, and it has selected but 85 athletes whom it has judged fill the criteria. It will not serve any purpose to explain why it originally selected 70, but it was in part thanks to the help of the drugs offensive funding that these kids were able to produce performances which raised the number of those fit to be in the category.

I simply conclude by saying that it would be heartbreaking now to dismiss any of these athletes, who on their ability have been selected by the panel of selectors given the responsibility by the Commonwealth Games Association to select the track and field team. The Senate is simply expressing the point of view that those young men and women, having been selected, ought now to be entitled to represent their country in Auckland.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Crichton-Browne's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1989PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 May and 21 November, on motion by Senators Walsh and Bolkus:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is now dealing with a package of three primary industries Bills which the Government has programmed as absolutely essential for passage this session. The first Bill, the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, was in fact introduced into the House of Representatives on 8 March and is an omnibus Bill which amends 10 Acts and repeals 13 within the primary industries and energy portfolio. The second Bill, the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989, is also an omnibus Bill which seeks to amend 11 Acts and repeal four Acts within the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio. This third Bill, the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Bill 1989, which was introduced into the other place on 4 October of this year, proposes to establish research and development corporations in respect of primary industries, including energy, replacing the present research councils and committees which administer the allocation of research and development program funds.

SPEECH.PARA: We support the thrust of these Bills as far as they go. In particular, we support the removal of redundant legislation and the improvements in funding of primary industries research and development to increase the economic, environmental and social benefits to the rural and wider community. That is consistent with the aims of the coalition's Economic Action Plan.

Australia is first and foremost a trading nation. The living standards of all Australians depend on our success in world markets across the board-agricultural and mineral products, manufactures and services. These Bills address some of these concerns. To develop new products and diversify markets we must ensure that our major export industries are as competitive and innovative as possible in world terms. We must come up with new and better products and concentrate on quality. The decisions to corporatise councils and increase involvement in the determination of long-term research and development strategies and facilitate the commercial exploitation of the results of research and development efforts is a step in the right direction.

Even though on the farm or in the mine we rank amongst the most competitive producers in the world, we often pay away much of that competitive advantage as we move products via domestic transportation, especially road and rail, clear products across the waterfront or put them on a coastal ship. This is due to the significant cost inefficiencies in those infrastructure industries. We wish that the Government would turn its mind to reform of those infrastructure industries. That is a nettle that the Government simply refuses to grasp. The problem, of course, is the relationship between the trade union movement and the Hawke-Keating Government. Nevertheless, the Government seems to be prepared to grasp some nettles in relation to primary production. Our producers have found themselves having to operate with excessively high interest rates, volatile exchange rates and other disadvantages due to labour market costs and practices. The coal industry is particularly exposed and, in addition, has to compete in a highly competitive and cut-throat international market.

The third Bill of this package is complex. It is deficient in some areas and it imposes on the coal industry an unwanted Coal Industry Research and Development Corporation. I will be moving a series of amendments to meet industry concerns and to clarify the intent of the legislation. Concerned industry and my colleagues in the other place have engaged in protracted discussions with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) in an endeavour to correct the deficiencies in the research and development Bill. Counsel spent some 2 1/2 days preparing our amendments, which industry perceives as essential. I have been told that the Minister recognises the justification for these amendments but has been unable to persuade his ministerial colleagues to accept them.

The first in the package is the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 which, as I said, is an omnibus Bill designed to make a number of amendments to existing legislation and to repeal outdated and unused legislation. The six related petroleum (submerged lands) Acts are amended so as to allow for the determination of fees and securities for petroleum exploration by way of regulation rather than by amendment of the principal Act. The amendments incorporate what are called Henry VIII clauses that will permit a fee to be set by regulation without an upper limit being provided in the Act. The Minister claims that the changes will allow for timely adjustment of fees to more closely reflect actual administrative costs. With the high inflation generated by this Government's policies-in particular, its accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions-the Minister's response to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee's criticisms of this clause is understandable. He said:

Departments should be able to set a level of fees which allows sufficient flexibility to ensure that Parliamentary scrutiny is maintained without the necessity of fees being amended at too frequent intervals.

That was a predictable but unsatisfactory response by the Minister. The Committee said, rightly, that it was `of the opinion that the inclusion of maximum fees in a Bill need not involve the lengthy period envisioned by the Minister, and that it is possible to include appropriate formulae in legislation to reflect changes in administrative costs over time'. It should not be beyond the wit of the Minister and his Department to devise a legislative measure to cover the Committee's concerns rather than using the repugnant Henry VIII clause.

This Government and these Ministers do not seem to understand our objection that the Parliament cannot amend a regulation-it can only disallow it. By adopting this form, the Government puts the Parliament in a position where ultimately it will have only one choice-accept or reject the Government's regulation. The Parliament will not be allowed to amend it. Let me explain this by giving a practical example which even members of the Australian Labor Party might understand. When we were in government I recall Senator Cavanagh coming to me about a proposed change to workers compensation legislation whereby the amount of compensation provided for, say, a broken leg or an amputated finger, or whatever it was, was to be determined by regulation. Senator Cavanagh pointed out to me that that meant that if, for example, the compensation for the particular injury was increased to, say, $10,000 from $8,000 and the Senate was of the view that $10,000 was not adequate, the Senate would not be able to amend the regulation to increase the amount from $10,000 to, say, $12,000. All the Senate could do would be to reject the regulation which increased the amount from $8,000 to $10,000. Of course, that would mean that the compensation would go back to $8,000, which would be directly contrary to what the Senate wanted to do.

That is the objection which the Parliament has to putting these sorts of things into regulations instead of into a Bill. This practice takes away the opportunity of the Parliament to vary the figure in accordance with what the Parliament thinks is proper and leaves the Parliament in a position where all it can do is reject the regulation rather than vary it. That is our objection to this proposal.

The only significant change made in this Bill is to the Plant Variety Rights Act 1987. The present Act does not recognise the practical difference between propagation from seed and the faster process of asexual reproduction. Asexual reproduction of plants can take place from either cuttings or tissue culture, and reproduction is much faster via this method than it is through the sexual propagation of plants from seed. At the moment, people can buy a few protected plants and asexually propagate dozens or even hundreds of plants in a short time. While these cannot be sold, what they produce-their flowers and fruit-can be. We support this amendment which protects the holders of plant rights by giving them sole rights to asexual propagate their plants themselves or license others to do so for the purpose of using the produce commercially.

This does not affect persons who want to asexually propagate plants for their own use, but will prevent the sale of any of the plants' produce. In relation to the first Bill, the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, I move:

At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate is of the view that the bill should be amended to ensure that the fees and securities to be prescribed by regulations in respect of petroleum exploration activities should not exceed the relevant minimum administrative costs incurred by the Commonwealth, the States or the Northern Territory in carrying out their respective obligations under the legislation''.

The second Bill establishes a wool research and development council by making amendments to the Wool Marketing Act 1987 and makes minor amendments to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation Act to allow the Corporation to invest surplus money. The way the honey levy is collected is simplified by the Bill. Membership of the Soil Conservation Council is increased from seven to 12. The number of forms involved in various grain levies is reduced from 20 to four. An amendment allows the research component of funds raised by the wheat levy to be transferred to the Wheat Research Trust Fund. The Bass Strait freight adjustment levy Acts which were terminated in 1987 are repealed.

We also support this Bill in which the Government has recognised that the wool industry, unlike other industries, did not want a research and development corporation but a council under the umbrella of the Australian Wool Corporation. This year some $56m will be spent on wool research and development, making it the largest rural industry fund. The responsible Department is to be complimented on reducing the number of forms involved in various grain levies from 20 to four. That example should be taken on board by all departments.

The third Bill, the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Bill 1989 is the most complex. The main thrust of this Bill is supported by the coalition as it allows the current research councils and committees to become research and development corporations and provides for the funding and administration of research and development into primary industries. Rural industry research funds provide for government and private sector involvement in financing industry-specific agricultural research and development and for private sector participation in determining priorities for that expenditure. These funds receive income from levies imposed on commodities and from Commonwealth matching contributions. The corporations will have wide powers to apply for patents, establish committees, employ staff and set employment conditions, charge for services, enter into joint ventures on research and development, acquire property, form companies, act as trustee and accept gifts and borrow money with the written approval of the Minister.

Primary industry organisations generally favour a corporation instead of a council because of these powers. They say that councils are handicapped by having to observe public service rates of pay and conditions of employment. As a corporation they will be free to employ people on contracts for the term of a particular piece of research. That is sensible and in accord with the coalition's industrial relations policy. We are glad to see that the Government now recognises the merits of that policy.

Similar research and development corporations have already been established for the meat and horticulture industries. The dairy industry was inspired by the better research program targeting and control in the meat and livestock industries with the creation of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation and lobbied the Government to extend the concept. The wool industry, on the other hand, opted for a council under the umbrella of the Australian Wool Corporation and this is established in the previous Bill, that is, the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3). Initially the research and development corporations to be established on 1 July 1990 include dairy, grain, coal, natural resources and energy. A rural research and development corporation will also be established to replace the Australian Special Rural Research Council which looks after smaller industries. Each corporation must establish a five-year plan and have it approved by the Minister. The corporations will be responsible to the Minister to see that the plan is carried out. A major objective, which has our support, is the removal of duplication and the intent that corporations should develop a close liaison with each other to ensure this. For example, many areas of soil research will have benefits for several of the corporations and could be jointly funded.

The coalition parties are proposing a number of amendments. The Australian Dairy Industry Conference (ADIC) seeks an amendment to allow contributions from dairy factories to be considered as dairy industry money for the purpose of attracting the dollar for dollar Commonwealth finance. The ADIC claims this would be fairer than the levy on all milk because much of the research favours manufactured products and the milk supplied by many farmers is used only for liquid milk and is not used for dairy products. It would also ensure commercial involvement with the research and development corporation and close involvement between the dairy companies and the corporation. At the moment dairy farmers are contributing about 0.2 per cent of the value of their product and the Government is prepared to match dollar for dollar up to 0.5 per cent. It will take a few years for the dairy program to reach this target. Because the vast majority of the dairy companies are cooperatives it could be argued that money from them for research would actually be grower money that these factories would contribute.

There is a precedent in the horticultural legislation which allows contributions from companies. However, the Government argues this was a very special deal to try to attract the many small industries to join the horticultural research effort. The Government also claims that many companies would be eligible for the Government 150 per cent tax write-off for research and development and should not get any further assistance. Our amendment specifically addresses this problem and precludes double dipping. We also want to ensure that the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research Development Corporation debacle over annual meetings is not repeated, that is, to ensure research corporations are not forced to hold annual meetings when there is no business to conduct or the business of the meeting could be done in writing at a considerable saving in costs. Research and development corporations will be accountable to those who provide the funds and they will be required to table an annual report in Parliament. Either an annual report or meeting will be provided to the industry.

Distinct from the corporatisation program envisaged for the rural industries, the intent is also to corporatise the operations of the national energy research development and demonstration program which is currently overseen by the National Energy Research Development and Demonstration Council. Currently the National Energy Research and Development Demonstration Council carries out research into energy related matters as well as coal research. Coal related research is funded primarily by way of a compulsory levy, known as the coal production excise, at a levy rate of 5c per tonne of black coal. Funds spent by the Council on coal research beyond the amount of the industry levy are drawn from the coal industry trust fund, which is itself the product of accumulated coal industry excise contributions. The Council's other energy related research is funded by the Government.

The corporation program seeks to split the Council into two distinct corporate research and development corporations: the National Energy Research and Development Corporation, which I will call the energy corporation, and the Coal Industry Research and Development Corporation, which I will call the coal corporation. We support the coal industry's view that the proposed coal corporation is unnecessary. The coal corporation will be funded only by way of the coal excise, a levy on the industry. There will be no taxpayers' funds involved. The coal industry trust account will be transferred to the energy corporation. Funding arrangements are to be reviewed after the close of the 1992-93 financial year. Specific funding arrangements are not dealt with in the legislation, which is of a generic, umbrella type. The Department, however, has confirmed repeatedly that no appropriations will be used to underwrite or contribute to the Coal Industry Research and Development Corporation. The coal industry spends millions of dollars on independent research each year and such research is essential if it is to remain competitive and retain and expand its overseas markets. This industry knows what it is doing. If no taxpayers' funds are to be put into its research efforts, there is no need for its research to be overseen by some government bureaucracy. Quite simply, the Government should keep out of it. The industry, which is perceived as already suffering an excessive degree of Commonwealth intervention, cannot conceive how the Coal Industry Research and Development Corporation could add to the industry's efficiencies or the urgent need for deregulation in the industry.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the sitting of the Senate was suspended for dinner I was addressing the third Bill in this package of Bills-the Bill which deals with research and development corporations. In particular, I was addressing the proposed Research and Development Corporation for the coal mining industry. I was pointing out that no taxpayers' funds are involved.

SPEECH.PARA: The coal mining industry knows what it is doing. It spends an enormous amount of money on research each year. The coalition parties simply say: Why is this Government imposing upon the coal industry a research body which it simply does not want and which this Government is requiring the coal industry to fund? Is the Government saying that the coal industry is not spending enough money on research? Is the Government saying that its research efforts are not adequate? Is the Government saying that it needs to be directed in some way by the Government? I put it to the Senate that that would be a nonsense. The industry knows what it needs to do. It is a successful industry. It is out there in a cutthroat world market and the capital expenditure involved is enormous. Quite simply, the Government should keep out of it.

As I have mentioned, this industry is already perceived as suffering from an excessive degree of Commonwealth intervention.
