One could not conceive of how the new Coal Industry Research and Development Corporation could add to industry efficiencies or fulfil the urgent need for deregulation of the industry. The coal industry wishes to model its research efforts on the model used by the minerals sector, which carries out an ambitious research program through the Australian Minerals Industry Research Association, which body acts as a broker for the minerals sector and which has facilitated an active research and development program, spending some $7m to $10m per annum, in addition to private sector research of about $15m. That is the sort of model that the coal industry wishes to adopt. The return on the dollar in private sector research and development is much greater than that which is circulated through a bureaucratic network, such as the proposed Coal Industry Research and Development Corporation.

The coalition's resources and energy policy supports the present national energy research, development and demonstration program and it follows that we support the establishment of the proposed National Energy Research and Development Corporation but not, as I have said, the establishment of the Coal Industry Research and Development Corporation, which appears to us to be wasteful and bureaucratic and, at best, would duplicate much of the work already being carried out by the coal industry.

The reason for the Government pressing ahead with the Coal Industry Research and Development Corporation in the face of industry opposition is difficult to understand. The effectiveness of the current national energy research, development and demonstration program is under review and a report is expected in April 1990. The Industry Commission has under way an inquiry into mining and minerals processing which will report in February 1991. Both of these reviews will look at the coal industry's research and development effort. The establishment of another public research institution before the findings of these inquiries is simply not sustainable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this cognate debate on three pieces of primary industry and energy legislation, I will concentrate my remarks on what is really the major Bill in this package, the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Bill 1989, but just preface those remarks by saying that the Australian Democrats will not be supporting the Opposition's second reading amendment to the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), the first Bill in this package.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats commend the Government for initiating the further restructuring of primary industries and energy research. Australia compares poorly in general terms with other countries in its level of investment in research and development, with the exception of expenditure on agricultural research and development, which compares more than favourably with our overseas counterparts. Under these new arrangements, this tradition will be enhanced by building and expanding the efforts undertaken by the research and development councils formed under the Rural Industries Research Act 1985 to administer the rural industry research funds. This Bill proposes to establish research and development corporations, and a rural industries research and development corporation, to provide for funding and administration of research and development into agricultural industries and energy.

The present research councils and committees will be replaced by the R & D Corporations with their much wider commercial powers. Their objective will be to improve the funding of primary industries in order to bring about a more efficient and effective research and development effort to enable this sector, long established as a major force in Australia's economic picture, to continue to improve and expand and remain on a par with our competitors in other countries.

The Democrats believe that an important aspect of these new arrangements will be the facilitation of collaboration between corporations. This will create opportunities for wider dissemination of information and activity leading to improvements in the industry as a whole. Soil research is an area that comes very quickly to mind as being likely to benefit from this new form of arrangement. We believe it is important in the area of land degradation and in a number of other areas-in general, perhaps, I would term it as in the area of sustainable agriculture-to move away from single industry research into cross-commodity research. Questions of monoculture and its impact on our fragile resource base can and, we hope, will be addressed more readily under this sort of system.

While we approach the major purpose of this Bill with general support and are pleased that the Government has moved to initiate a restructuring of the R & D effort in the primary industries area, we are concerned at the apparent reluctance on the part of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) to take on board some concerns that are fairly insignificant in terms of the Government's overall purpose but are very important from the industries' point of view.

In his second reading speech the Minister placed considerable emphasis on the importance that he places on accountability of the corporations to both government and industry-a sentiment that we wholeheartedly endorse. However, it is clear that industry is of the opinion that the Bill does not go far enough in this direction. The dairy and grains industries, in particular, and the National Farmers Federation as the umbrella body, have raised a number of matters with both the Opposition and the Australian Democrats, of which the Minister is also aware. As a result amendments will be introduced by both the Opposition and the Democrats in the committee stage designed to address the industries' concerns, generally to strengthen the requirements for accountability to and consultation with industry by the research and development corporations. The Australian Democrats will be supporting most but not all of those amendments, and I will comment further about that in the committee stage. Those amendments which have the emphasis of strengthening accountability and consultation processes have our support.

There are a few points that I would like to make about research and development in general, along with some other concerns that the Democrats have in relation to this particular Bill. At the National Agricultural Outlook Conference held at the beginning of this year the major contribution made by research in improving on-farm efficiency and hence overall agricultural productivity growth over the last 20 years was properly highlighted. However, Tony Gregson from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) pointed out that:

These productivity gains have to be weighed against the negative impacts of land degradation, including increasing soil acidity and salinity, and the general decline in the social fabric of the smaller country communities.

Those are issues which the Democrats address on a regular basis in this place. As I have said already, we believe that the new structure for research and development provides the opportunity for action across commodity groups which will be very important in looking at both the ecological and social effects of some aspects of our agricultural development in the past and will take us into a future which will be productive and economically, ecologically and socially sustainable.

It is a feature of our agricultural and rural scene that the problems of rural communities continue to increase as the problems found on the farms increase. That is a flow-on from an increased efficiency, and increased sensitivity in the production in this country and an increased diversity. As we look to markets overseas, which we must and which the primary industry sector does, we must also always have as an emphasis an increase in diversity so that we are looking at ranges of new products so that we can fill market niches when they occur. It will not surprise anyone in the Senate to hear me say on behalf of the Australian Democrats that we hope a clear focus along with a cross-commodity approach in these new research and development corporations and under these new arrangements should be one on the development of sustainable agriculture, in particular on a reduced reliance on chemical production, a sensitivity about the problems of monoculture and, in general, some reasonably significant changes that could be of enormous benefit to us in this country particularly in carving out some market niches in the area of clean food for the rest of the world.

For several years the Democrats have been pressing successive governments to take urgent, comprehensive and effective action on the issue of land degradation. We have a strong and ongoing commitment to the environment. We recognise that this is by far the most serious of Australia's many environmental problems; yet, we still have a shortage of soil scientists. I must say that in my work toward sustainable agriculture I have found that as a group soil scientists are very sensitive to the needs in that area. I am often disturbed that in the public debate soil erosion seems to be the key focus. When people think about land degradation, they tend to see soil erosion-gullies rippling across paddocks and dust storms coming over cities in dry summers. I think we need to remind ourselves that land degradation goes further than that.

The next problem that people think of is salinity. This is another area of land degradation which is clearly visible. People can go to areas which, regrettably, are increasing in this country and see salinity and its results. Leaving those two aspects aside, there are two other serious issues. Loss of nutrients in the soil, which reduces the fertility and therefore the productivity of the soil, is an issue in land degradation which is not immediately obvious. It is not a gripping issue for the general public and, I suggest, to many politicians and others in the community. Many people do not even consider it as an aspect of land degradation; yet it is a growing problem, one which has been brought about by a range of practices. Research and development in this area is enormously important. We must recognise the problem and then attempt to do something about it. It may well mean that there will have to be some quite dramatic changes in the systems of farming that we use in this country. Changes will have to take place and, with a good body of research and development behind us, we will be much better placed to make them.

The other area is the pollution of our soil which is caused mainly by chemicals. Again, that is an area of land degradation which is not obvious to the eye. It is obvious to the farmer whose farm may be quarantined, and it is obvious to the farmer who cannot produce certain products that he might have been able to produce otherwise. I raise those matters in this debate because one often hears people say, `We have beaten the land degradation problem on our farm or district because we do contour ploughing and have put in some drainage'.

TALK.START.PARA: —And strip cropping.

—Yes, I am aware that certain honourable senators from New South Wales involve themselves in strip cropping, a very basic farming technique which is good for the land. But often people say, `We are doing this so we are stopping gullies being formed and water and wind erosion.' They may even acknowledge some of the salinity problems which, as I say, are very obvious, and look at some of the new techniques of layout and changes in irrigation. They may even say, `We are planting lots of trees on the watersheds, therefore, we are beating salinity and that is all we really need to do.' But we must address these hidden problems of loss of nutrients and pollution of the soil. I commend these problems to the new research and development corporations, and call on them to use the facility they will have under this legislation to work together across commodity groups.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, we have a shortage of soil scientists, and that needs to be looked at. We commend the Federal Government, of course, for its $320m funding package for the decade of land care. But we are disturbed because we believe that the Government has abrogated its leadership responsibility by not moving for uniform model soil conservation legislation for adoption by the States. We believe that the Government is walking away from looking seriously at a national assessment of land capability to meet the first requirement of the national soil conservation program. We also want the Federal Government to provide assistance to farmers in the task of preventing and alleviating land degradation in all of its forms. With a shortage of soil scientists, that is a matter of concern to us.

Another matter of concern, about which I have been reminded in my discussions with representatives of the dairy industry, is the constraints being placed on rural research and development because of the lack of an adequate basic research infrastructure in this country. There has been a broad debate in recent times about our failure in this country to really meet our broad research needs. I alluded to that at the beginning of my remarks. While rural research has led out front, this sector suffers as a result of the lack of basic research support in the general sense that basic scientific research-which very often does not appear to come up with anything that is concrete and significant in the short term-is very important. It is from a strong support for that kind of research that we could expect the number of soil scientists to grow.

Problems in the CSIRO, for instance, which I will not canvass at this point, are the sorts of things I am talking about here. As well, universities and other research institutions are scraping the bottom of the barrel in order to be able to continue in basic research. It has been said, and I agree, that the major resource in research is the minds of research scientists. If we do not keep our scientists, we certainly do not keep their minds. Again, Tony Gregson, at the National Agricultural Outlook Conference, said:

Our rural resource base is fragile and easily degraded; unless we develop land use systems and farming practices which restore and sustain the ability to produce, we will lose our capacity to be an efficient long-term earner of export income. Yet there is now a lack of soil chemists and scientists with an understanding of the physical characteristics of soils.

That is a major concern, as I have said, which we draw attention to in this debate. We need to assure that research scientists are being trained in all appropriate areas. There are many areas of severe shortage. We need to encourage students by offering adequate incentives to take up careers in agricultural science, in particular.

Another concern which has been raised by the National Farmers Federation, and which was alluded to by the shadow Minister for primary industry, Mr Lloyd, during the debate in the other chamber, is the question of extension services. That matter is, of course, raised in this legislation, and I know the Government has some concerns about that as well. State governments, and through them their State departments of agriculture, are in many cases reducing their extension services. States, of course, have had severe funding cuts in recent years as part of the economic constraints which have been placed upon all of us in order that the Government should satisfy the international money markets with a $9 billion-plus surplus. In some ways one might sympathise with the States, as one of their economies has been to cut back extension services.

The National Farmers Federation fears that under the existing provisions in this legislation corporations will be turned into both research and development and extension corporations. The National Farmers Federation would have liked an amendment to restrict that extension facility only to research which was funded by a particular research and development corporation. This is not coming forward from the Opposition because it believes it might be too restrictive and, indeed, there is an argument that extension is a proper end product and involvement in research and development. It is important, I think, to say that the funding which is available by virtue of the process of this newly established corporation system should not be, shall I say, unnecessarily and inappropriately syphoned off into extension work. There has not been unanimous support for amending the legislation in this area across commodity groups, again because there is an appropriate role for extension. We are simply saying that that ought to be limited.

I have been concerned in my own State of Victoria to discover that many of the extension services which would normally have been provided by our State Department of Agriculture are now being provided by the commercial sector, by commercial firms supplying that input. I am concerned about that because of the major agribusiness players such as Elders IXL Ltd, to name just one-but a major one. It does seem to us that all too often the pattern that we have seen in the rural sector is followed, where the major base of information comes from the commercial operation whose major concern is its own profitability, to sell its own product. Clearly, it is not going to advise farmers against using its product whether or not it believes it is the appropriate thing. Some of the issues of soil pollution, of inappropriate use of land and inappropriate inputs in agriculture, stem from that kind of failure to provide a whole range of options and alternatives to farmers through State funded and, indeed, federally funded extension services.

I have often said in this place that one of the major areas of neglect is in providing producers with information on alternative low or non-chemical production or organic farming. This is still not happening. However, there are developments in that direction which do please us. We do not believe that under this legislation extension services should be provided at the expense of the research and development role of these corporations.

I would like to make just a few comments, finally, on the dairy industry. It has requested the support of the Australian Democrats to amend the Bill to permit direct contributions to the Dairy Research and Development Corporation via cooperative companies of the dairy industry to be matched by the Commonwealth on a dollar for dollar basis. There is a perception within the dairy industry that research and development has focused to date on on-farm production research while programs for the manufacturing sector of the industry have lacked commercial relevance, particularly with regard to the development of new products. The Australian Dairy Industry Conference believes that this type of research is best undertaken in collaboration with the cooperative companies-the commercial arm of the dairy industry-and is more appropriately funded through direct contributions to research and development corporations than through a levy on milk. As Senator Lewis has already said many milk producers are producing whole milk products and others are producing for the manufacturing sector. I agree that a levy on milk is not an appropriate mechanism.

We understand the industry's interest in moving in this direction. We are supported by the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation precedent and, indeed, by our knowledge and my understanding, personally having lived in a dairy area for many years, of the nature of that industry. We do not believe that the Government's fears of this being a backdoor way of getting more funding and of keeping the grower contribution low are well founded. The growers are the cooperatives; the cooperatives are the growers-the producers in this case. We believe that it is and will be producer money. The dairy industry faces strong overseas competition and needs to get a competitive edge internationally, particularly because of our closer economic relations with New Zealand.

The short to medium term outlook for the dairy industry is good. Increased prices in Australia emanating from improved international prices are expected to lead to higher milk production until about 1991-92. However, the long term outlook for the dairy industry in Australia is uncertain. Clearly, from 1 July 1990 there will be increased competition from New Zealand. The domestic price support under the Kerin plan will end on 1 July 1992. Beyond 1992, because of the cessation of price support and the possibility of reduced world prices due to increasing self-sufficiency in importing countries and supply response in major producing companies, the Australian dairy industry could experience a downturn in prices. Returns to farmers are likely to be reduced and major structural adjustments are expected to occur in the industry as a result. We believe that this major change to the legislation on behalf of the dairy industry is quite warranted in this particular case.

As I have said, there will be a number of amendments in the committee stage. I do not want to hold the Senate up in the second reading debate for too much longer. I simply say that my colleague Senator Coulter will be moving an amendment to the definition section of the legislation. We and the Opposition will have a number of additional amendments in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this debate involving three pieces of legislation-the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) and the Primary Industries and energy Research and Development Bill-affecting primary industry. As previous speakers have outlined the key elements in these Bills, I do not intend to cover all three. Senator Austin Lewis led the debate for the Opposition. He very succinctly stated the case.
—I must have missed it.

—The Minister had better keep quiet. I think that he is in enough trouble as it is with the Acting Deputy President, who had the Minister for breakfast during Question Time and the debates that took place today. I would like to address some remarks to the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989. This is an omnibus Bill which amends a number of existing Acts. It will also establish a Wool Research and Development Council. The significant points in this legislation relate to arrangements that affect wool marketing.

SPEECH.PARA: The wool industry knows only too well the effect of market forces. Last year wool growers were the envy of the rural sector. Record wool prices resulted in record ewe prices. At a sale in Hay last year I saw ewes bringing $130 a head, which I believe is a record for ewe prices. The value of wool produced in this country went up by some 30 per cent last year. Countries such as Japan, China and Russia could not get enough of our product, and they were prepared to pay for it. But this year the story has reversed. The international markets have changed. China has withdrawn from the market, and Japan, once an on-seller to China, has reduced its purchases along with other countries. The removal of China from the market is significant, as China had become Australia's second largest buyer. As a consequence, the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) has had to come in and buy. Confidence has gone out of the market and the effects are felt all along the line, right down to the saleyards. Sheep that were worth big money last year have been discounted by 50 per cent or more this year. The AWC has been forced to acquire one million bales, while there were around 9,200 bales in stock from July 1988. This stockpile could easily reach two million bales before the season is finished. However, woolgrowers will be safeguarded because of the floor price scheme. It is, nevertheless, a worrying time for all the wool producers in Australia. This sort of market fluctuation has affected agriculture for years and it will continue to do so. It is for this reason that primary industry will always need to be treated differently from other industries in legislation. Senator Panizza will talk about the wheat industry later in this debate. I hope that people realise that the wheat industry and all primary industries are different from other industries in Australia.

Our national woolclip last financial year was a record 882 million kilograms. It was up 41 million kilos on last year. Despite the increase in production, grower returns have not increased comparatively. Last year our wool exports were worth nearly $6 billion. I mention these figures because the industry is of vital significance to Australia. Its historical importance should also be remembered. In wool, Australia has no peers. We grow wool better than anyone else in the world, something that we should be proud of. The expression that `Australia rides on the sheep's back' was once said with pride. Despite this Government's best intentions to prop up every other sector of the economy, Australia is still riding on the sheep's back. In years to come we will be grateful that we have that industry to support us.

Research and development in the wool industry are key parts of the Australian Wool Corporation's activities. While other industries have corporations, the wool industry decided that it wanted to keep research under the umbrella of the AWC. It is for this reason that, while the Council has been up and running, legislation putting it in place is only now coming through the Senate. The legislation we have before us is a compromise between industry and government. The industry has a great record in research. I note from this year's AWC annual report that the industry's research and development program falls into five main objectives. They are: to increase demand for wool through new products and processes; to increase the efficiency of raw wool marketing; to increase the efficiency of sustainable raw wool production; to determine the impact of the internal and external environment on the industry; and the efficient management of the wool research development program.

The work being undertaken for the wool industry by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation was discussed in the report of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare on sheep husbandry, of which I was a part. During inspections with that Committee, I had the pleasure of viewing progress being done in biological shearing and robotic shearing, and I had the opportunity to review the research into parasites, genetic engineering and other nutritional and environmental research. In fact, Mr Acting Deputy President, I had a look at robotic shearing in your fair State of Western Australia, as I had a look at robotic shearing in South Australia. It is quite an experience to see something being done that is well ahead of its time.

The money contributed by taxpayers and wool growers is being well spent. It is significant, I remind honourable senators, that Australia's wool industry earns us $6 billion a year in valuable export dollars. It is very good to see over on the other side of the chamber tonight Senator McKiernan who I know has had a little bit to do with the resource sector, and he is an expert in some, but not all, of those fields. Of course, he did a little bit of damage in his time in the resource sector, but we will not go into that here tonight. Returning to the subject of wool, the Government gives $25m to wool promotion, and that is the only direct assistance it provides outside its dollar for dollar assistance. The Government has said that it will review this in three years time. My guess is that if the Australian public is silly enough to let the Australian Labor Party still be on the government benches at that time, the wool industry will be saying goodbye to their wool promotion support. I guarantee that the Australian people are not that silly and will make sure that we are on the government benches at that time so that this wonderful industry to Australia, the wool industry, is sustained in a manner which will give us all the standard of living we have now.

At the same time, the Government has handed over $39m-that is, $13m a year over the next three years- to Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd. Honourable senators on the other side of the chamber should go and have their photographs taken. The Government is handing over $13m a year to Kodak, a company that has annual exports of $200m to $250m a year. Is it not amazing that the Government is giving that hand-out to Kodak? I forgot to mention that Kodak is situated in the political seat of the person I watched on television tonight playing golf whose ball went into a couple of bunkers. It is in the electorate of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). He went from one bunker to the other, and that is what this Government is doing at the moment: it is going from one bunker into the other bunker. In the end, the fascinating thing was-and Senator McKiernan saw this on television-that the Prime Minister, after he had put his second shot out of the bunker into the lip of the bunker, went and picked up his ball and took his bat home. The Government deserves to be indicted for what it is doing for companies like Kodak, when it is not doing anything to help very vital industries such us the primary industries.

The wool industry deserves better than this double standard that the Government is giving it. The industry is not only in some difficulty with its wool. The live sheep trade is also experiencing some difficulties. My colleague Senator Panizza has brought to the attention of the Senate on numerous occasions the problems associated with the live sheep trade in the Middle East at the moment. I do not want to comment too much on this at the moment, because I appreciate the sensitivity of the discussions that are presently taking place, but the endeavour of this Government in this area has not been as good as it could have been. The Government does a fair bit for Kodak and the like! I do not know why the Government has to give assistance to a company which is situated in the Prime Minister's seat. If the Prime Minister is in the bunker, obviously he is in a bit of trouble, but I do not know why the Government has to give so much to that industry in that electorate. I would have thought that the Prime Minister would have felt quite secure in that safe Labor seat. I trust that the Government recognises the importance of the live sheep trade not just to Australia generally but also to the sheep producers. The Middle East trade provides a valuable market for mutton and we cannot afford to lose it; nor can Australia afford to be blackmailed.

There are other important matters covered in this package of legislation, but the only issue I wish to raise concerns the coal industry and its views on the establishment of the Coal Industry Research and Development Corporation (CIRDC). This would replace the present research council and the committees operating the Coal Research Trust Account and part of the national energy research development and demonstration program. No public funding is involved in the CIRDC and therefore the industry argues that it should administer its own research funding. It claims that the Government's program has high administration costs and a lack of application of practical research. The industry presently pays about $10m a year to the Government in the form of a coal research levy. Until now this has been administered totally by the Government. In addition, the industry itself spends about $15m on private research. The existing fund has a deficit of over $13m, for which the Government does not intend to accept liability. The industry, somewhat understandably, believes that the liabilities created under the Government's administration ought not to be transferred to the new fund. In other words, the Government should carry the load.

The research and development Bill also covers dairy, grain, natural resources and energy-indeed, all other primary industry and energy areas in which the industry decides that it wants a corporation. Generally speaking, the various commodity groups prefer a corporation to a council because of the wider powers attached to a corporation. The exception to which I have already referred is the Australian Wool Corporation. Amendments will be moved by Senator Lewis in the Committee of the whole later in this debate. Essentially, the Opposition has no disagreement with these Bills. However, I draw the attention of the Senate to the inconsistent attitude of the Government to rural industry generally. When one considers the vital contribution it makes to the economic welfare of every Australian, the Government treats the farmer, the person who produces this export income, in a most off-hand manner.

TALK.START.PARA: —They hate the farmer.

—One wonders whether they do love the farmers. I do not know whether they hate the farmers, but they obviously have shown them scant regard in the time that they have been in Government in the last six years. As a person who lives on the land, I can assure honourable senators that it has been a pretty hard row to hoe in the last few years under this Government. I believe that this is in part the fault of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), who is obviously tired of being rolled by his Cabinet colleagues and who is now set on a collision course with the greenie guru, Senator Richardson, who is sitting on the opposite side of the House tonight. I hope Senator Richardson realises what happens when productive resources are locked up in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said numerous times before, production and protection should go hand in hand. We cannot lock up all our natural resources in this country, as the Minister is intending to do with some of his cohorts at this stage, and I believe that should go on the record. I believe in looking after the environment, but in no way can this country afford what the Minister plans. Even the babies are crying in the gallery. They are worried about the locking up of our resources by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Regardless of who wins this fight between the greenie guru and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the loser under this Government has always been and always will be the rural sector. I want to talk about interest rates, the real killer for primary industry.
Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that people are listening to this tonight because Senator Richardson just laughed when I said interest rates were a killer for primary industry. So did Senator McKiernan.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. Senator Brownhill is deliberately misrepresenting. At the conclusion of the debate I will seek to clear up the misrepresentation.
—There is no point of order.
—Obviously what could have been a smile that turned into a laugh has been misinterpreted by me. On the point of order--
—Senator Brownhill, I have ruled that there is no point of order.

—Interest rates are a real killer for primary industry which is always the price taker and not the price maker. Inflation is another big killer for primary industries, whether one is a wheat grower, a wool grower or in any other part of this sector. This Government talks about an inflation rate of 8 per cent, which is twice that of our trading partners. I would like to tell the Government, and put on record again, that the input increases, as distinct from the inflation rate, for the primary industry sector are well in excess of 10 per cent in the last 12 months. How can primary industries exist with high interest rates and with an increase in their running costs in excess of 10 per cent when they are competing with the rest of the world?

SPEECH.PARA: We support these Bills to which Senator Lewis will move amendments. But we ask the Government to recognise the input of the farming community and do things right. There needs to be lower interest rates, the curbing of inflation and a true recognition of our export producers who give everyone in this country a standard of living which we hope to maintain in the future as opposed to going down the path of some Third World countries, where this Government is now leading us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: -Tonight the Senate is debating the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989 and the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Bill 1989. This series of primary industry and energy Bills allows for a wide-ranging debate and gives the opportunity for honourable senators to address a number of issues that concern primary and rural industries. I acknowledge Mitch Hook from the Grain Growers Council of Australia, who is in the gallery tonight showing an interest in these primary industry Bills. I am sure that people out in the primary industry areas would welcome his being here taking an interest in what is happening to his industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to address a problem that is facing many smaller primary and farming industries-that is, the primary products that are entering Australia's domestic market under various types of government subsidies. These products are generally imported into Australia and marketed directly to manufacturing industry, or are brought in by the large grocery chains under home brand or generic labels. This is massively affecting the horticultural industry. No matter how these products are marketed in Australia they will cause, and are causing, havoc to the Australian small farmer. These products generally do not have to meet the strict health and hygiene standards rightly applied to Australian grown and processed products. The overseas products are able to be grown by farmers who use fertilisers and insecticides that would not meet environmental, health and hygiene standards in this country. I am glad the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) is in the chamber to listen to my contribution to the debate. The ironic part is that Australian farmers have to use expensive imported fertilisers, insecticides and other farming goods that have heavy tariff protection to grow, process and market Australian products. These products then have to compete against imported products that are heavily subsidised by governments on their own domestic market. Over the last 10 years we have seen huge levels of imported products on the shelves of our grocery stores. The major grocery chains have been importing and selling under generic labels goods such as jam, rice, apricots, sultanas, raisins, currants, canned pineapple, tomatoes and deciduous fruits, just to name a few.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you been shopping, Senator Boswell?

—Yes, I have. These products are grown, processed, canned and exported from low cost countries. The bottom line is that they offer a high profit margin to the grocery chain. The products are marketed under brands such as Black and White, Blue and White or Home Brand, depending on the grocery chain. Home Brand in itself is a contradiction in terms, implying that the contents are grown at home, presumably in Australia, which is not always the case. The generic label products compete against our home-grown products. They are not always superior products and generally are inferior products. The country of origin is not marked predominantly on the can or the package. There is really no comparison between the high grade Australian products and the cheaper imports.

SPEECH.PARA: No-one on my side of politics objects to a profit motive. If the chains find it in their best interests to promote overseas products that is a commercial decision that they make in the interests of their shareholders. No-one on this side of the House has any objection to that. But an absolute essential requirement is that the country of origin is predominantly displayed on the can so that consumers do not get confused but are able to make a decision as to the purchases they make, whether of an imported product or a product from Australia. If they wish to buy a cheap imported product because of a lower price that is a decision they are able to make without being led to believe that it is a local product. At present the maximum requirement for labelling height is 1.5 millimetres, which is slightly bigger than a pinhead. I debated this issue with Senator Bolkus and received assurances that he would take this matter on board. I believe that there is an Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) report coming out in February. If Senator Bolkus's assurances have any validity--

TALK.START.PARA: —They have a great deal.

—I am sure they do. I think that Senator Bolkus is an honourable man. If Senator Bolkus has taken this on board I presume that that point will be picked up in the IAC report. I go on record to thank Senator Bolkus on behalf of Australian farmers for the assurances that he has given.

SPEECH.PARA: While neither I nor anyone else can object to imported primary products entering Australia in a free market-I have no objection to that-I do, however, strenuously object to products that receive subsidies from governments overseas unfairly competing against Australian domestic products on our domestic market. Let me state unequivocally that the great majority of farmers support free trade. The National Farmers Federation, the peak body of Australian farmers, is loud in its insistence that Australia pursue a free trade policy. But I believe that a lot of the products that are entering Australia, competing against our home-grown products on our own domestic market, are subsidised.

Australian rural production in 1989-90 was worth $22 billion, with meat and wool accounting for nearly 50 per cent of the total. In 1988-89 rural exports were valued at $17 billion, 73 per cent of total farm production and 43 per cent of the total value of exported commodities. Forty-three per cent of Australian exports are carried by Australia's 145,000 to 150,000 farmers who do more than their share for Australia's economy. Internationally, Australia's rural exporters face a lot of formidable obstacles such as trade barriers, import quotas, quarantine barriers-which are a form of tariff-the European Community's common agricultural policy that has created an oversupply of commodities that are subsidised and then dumped, and the American Farm Bill with its extended credit scheme which subsidises American farm products in the international market.

These are just some of the problems facing Australian farmers in export markets. On the domestic front they work under a centralised wage system. They have to offset the profits gained by being the most efficient farmers in the world against the losses of exporting their products through the most inefficient waterfront in the world. They have to sell their products in a corrupt world market, yet they pay an average of $6,000 per farm for tariffs on farm imports, or $9,000m per year. That is a direct subsidy transfer from the farming and grazing sector to assist Australian manufacturing industry. The average net farm income in Australia is $22,000 a year.

The biggest problem Australian farmers have is the Government's self-inflicted high interest rate policy that has set farmers reeling. We hear of housing interest rates of 17 per cent, which is scandalous, but farmers and small business people are paying up to 23 and 25 per cent and even more than that with added costs. It is making it nearly impossible for anyone to stay on the land. With all these man-made adversities and the natural disasters of drought and flood, as well as low commodity prices, the Australian farmer needs a Victoria Cross and bar just to stay on the land.

The one thing Australian farmers do not need is the increasing trend of subsidised products competing against them in their domestic markets. These subsidies come in various forms. They are hard to detect and, therefore, hard to use as evidence in an anti-dumping case. In the case of the pineapple industry, countries such as Indonesia are offering incentives in the form of subsidised land and subsidised transport. This country is encouraging multinational companies to establish canneries and plantations in sparsely populated areas by offering these incentives. This country's motivation is to obtain hard currency and transfer the population from the densely populated cities to the less populated areas. While the cannery owners are interested in profit, the Government's motivations are quite different.

The example I offer is not particular to Indonesia. A number of other countries, such as Thailand and the Philippines, have also encouraged multinational companies, such as Dole and Del Monte, to establish vertically integrated industries in their countries in return for government offsets. Of course, this is putting a tremendous strain on Queensland's 550 pineapple farmers and the 1,700 process workers employed in the $180m industry at the Golden Circle cannery. Although imports have risen to 21 per cent of the total Australian market, it is difficult to establish and define just what subsidies are offered. Nevertheless, they are subsidies in various forms and they are having a deleterious effect on Australia's horticultural market.

The dairy industry is also suffering from dumped European Economic Community (EEC) products. Already, imported cheese represents 12 per cent of the Australian domestic market. Again, the majority of the cheese is brought in and marketed under generic brands and it is sold by major grocery chains giving maximum mark-ups. The EEC production subsidy on cheddar cheese amounts to $2,264 a tonne.

I reiterate the point I made earlier that the Australian dairy industry is the fourth largest primary industry export earner. It has to export in a corrupt world market. One thing Australia cannot control is the international market but it is another matter for Australia to allow cheese subsidised to the tune of $2,264 a tonne to enter the Australian domestic market. These imports take up not only 12 per cent of the domestic market but also hold prices down and do not allow Australian farmers to get a fair return for their considerable efforts.

The Australian rice industry has lost 20 to 25 per cent of the Australian market to imported rice. Australian rice growers produce 800,000 tonnes of rice a year. Between 80,000 to 100,000 tonnes of rice are consumed domestically and imported rice amounts to 20,000 to 25,000 tonnes of this. Again, this rice is mainly sold through generic brands or in bulk to industrial users. Australia is well able to sell 700,000 tonnes of rice overseas in a heavily subsidised and corrupt world market. The Australian rice grower then has to meet the international market by selling what he can.

We then must ask the question: How is this rice coming in? It is ironical that Australia imported rice from Japan last year-it was only a small quantity-yet the total public cost of the rice subsidy program in Japan is $6 billion a year. It is spent to ensure that the Japanese are self-sufficient in rice production. There is a total embargo on rice imports into Japan. Again, I do not question any country's right to sell into Australia if a product is not subsidised, but it is questionable whether countries can gain cheap access to Australia's domestic rice market without some sort of subsidy.

The Federal Government recently made a decision to lift the quarantine restriction on fresh, chilled and frozen pork and allow the importation of pig meat into Australia. That subject has been aired in the Senate on a number of occasions. But apart from the disease factor that is worrying every pig producer, the Canadian pig producers are subsidised under the Canadian tripartite price support program. The Federal Government and Canadian provincial governments, as well as the pork producers, pay into this scheme, which is triggered if a certain price is not reached. This year the scheme, according to the pork industry, gave subsidies to the Canadian pork producers of between $37 and $41 per animal. The United States Department of Commerce has recognised the subsidised nature of the Canadian product and has levied a countervailing duty of 8.5c per kilo on this imported pork. The United States action was supported by the International Trade Commission in September this year. Yet despite the evidence available that Canadian pork is subsidised and does constitute a disease risk-although Senator Cook has said that it is a limited disease risk-the Government took the decision to allow the import of pig meat into Australia.

Apart from the tripartite price support scheme, there are other State government transport subsidies on grain, tax rebate offset programs and herd improvement rebates that further assist Canadian pig producers. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics has given a top figure of around 17,000 tonnes of pig meat entering Australia per year. Australia's domestic market is around 300,000 tonnes, representing 4.8 million pigs. Seventeen thousand tonnes of pig meat from Canada is the equivalent of 270,000 additional pigs. There is concern in the industry that Canada will only export the more expensive cuts-legs and that type of cut-and this will completely unbalance the Australian market with an excess of leg cuts and will force the price of more expensive cuts down.

Senator Cook wrote a letter to the Australian when he was questioned on this issue, and I agree with him when he said that there is nothing wrong with good healthy competition which encourages cost-efficient production. But that is not the case. The facts are that pig meat is subsidised by the Canadian Federal and State governments. Senator Cook knows it. The United States Government knew it when it granted a countervailing duty of 8.5c a kilo. So why let it into Australia and force the pig producers to sustain injury and then, after they have suffered that injury, make a case for anti-dumping support-in other words, close the pigsty door after the pig has bolted.

The dried fruit industry has also lost a large percentage of its market to imported products. About 11.8 per cent of the market for currants has gone to the imports from Greece. The European Community subsidises that to the extent of $1,000 a tonne. Out of the 4,000 tonnes that is the Australian domestic market, 475 tonnes of imports come from Greece. Last year that figure was 169 tonnes. In percentage terms, it has risen by 181 per cent in one year. Greece, as a member of the European Community, receives production subsidies of $1,000 a tonne as well as processing and storage aid. In contrast, Australian growers' net price is $2,350 a tonne. This year 20 tonnes of imported sultanas came on to the Australian market, an insignificant amount, but no doubt the figure will increase next year if the product receives the same assistance as is provided for currants.

There were 786 tonnes of apricots imported from Turkey to Australia last year. Subsequently, 22.5 per cent of the Australian market of 3,500 tonnes was lost to imports. These imports were packed under generic brands for the major grocery chains and labelled `packed in Australia' for the specified grocery stores. Consumers could be forgiven if they thought these products were a product of Australia, but across the back of the package, stamped on clear cellophane, are the words `product of Turkey'. The Turkish Government assists its farmers by subsidising interest rates to 5 per cent and by devaluing the currency to assist exports.

Canned fruits are also coming into Australia under generic and home brand labels. Seven per cent of Australia's market is imported, mostly from the European Economic Community. These products also receive subsidies for their production and for export. Subsidised farm produce is causing a threat to Australian farmers. Production subsidies are increasing and causing injury to Australia's primary industries. They not only remove market share from farmers and processors, but also hold prices down to that of the subsidised product that is entering the domestic market. In the pineapple industry, growers have not received a price increase for five years and have held the price on the retail shelves for 18 months. Growers and canners know that every time they go for a price increase, they lose their market share to subsidised imported products and therefore they do not want to increase prices. The stage has now been reached that if Australia wants a horticultural industry, we will have to recognise the harm that is being inflicted on the Australian industries before more farmers sell their farms for real estate subdivisions or for golf courses for tourists.

I want to make it quite clear that I am not calling for tariff protection for Australian products. I am not calling for quotas. I recognise that free world trade will assist every farmer in Australia. I am calling for the Government to recognise that the problem facing Australia's primary industries needs addressing, and addressing fast. We have anti-dumping legislation and countervailing duties. But injury has to have taken place before these are triggered. In some cases it is nearly impossible to establish that subsidies have been given by governments because they are hidden and disguised, many in the form of assistance in government services. The Australian Government has extended to 250 days the consideration time for dumping applications. An immense amount can happen in 250 days.

I have said it before and I will say it again: Australian farmers have to compete on a corrupt world market. Surely it is not unreasonable to expect that they can play on a level playing field in their own domestic market. This Government can play a role in levelling the field by insisting on decent labelling on imported products, ensuring that the products are marked in large enough letters to let the purchaser know that the product is imported. The Industries Assistance Commission brought down its interim recommendations on packaging; however, the request that the country of origin be marked in easily identifiable writing was not one of the recommendations. Senator Bolkus has given an assurance that this problem will be addressed in the IAC's final report. That report was originally due to be released in December. I understand that it has now been printed and will be available in February. Hopefully the IAC has responded to Senator Bolkus's assurance in the Senate by including in its report reasonable minimum standards for labelling.

The Government can insist on uniform quality standards. In fact, it must insist on uniform quality standards. It is not good enough to let inferior processed products onto Australia's domestic market to compete against the home grown product in price if it means that the purchaser is buying an inferior, low standard product. The consumers are then turned away from that particular item. Nine times out of ten, they do not even realise it is an imported product. The consumers just do not buy that particular product again, which slows down the sales of Australia's primary products, including the better quality Australian product.

While it is recognised that reviews have to take place and are necessary, the anti-dumping authority requirement to re-apply every three years for continued dumping protection is time consuming, costly and imposes an unnecessary burden that is eventually passed on to the farmer. It is recognised throughout the world that tariff protection on manufactured goods has fallen significantly. However, in contrast, the level of protection in the agricultural sector has remained high and the trend is upwards. A large number of countries have protected their primary industries by grandfather clauses and do not allow Australian entry into their markets, as indicated by a paper on world trade distortions put out by the Australian Industries Development Association research centre. On the other hand, Australia's assistance to agriculture has declined significantly-from 15 per cent in 1986-87 to 9 per cent in 1987-88. This downward trend in agricultural assistance in Australia is continuing. Agricultural protection is an entrenched distortion to world trade which increasingly threatens efficient agricultural producers in Australia.

These are some of the problems that are facing the Australian farming industry at the moment. These are the problems that have to be recognised and taken on board. While I acknowledge-and I have said so a number of times-that we are not calling for quotas or extended tariffs, we are calling for a level playing field for Australia's primary industries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is good to see that Senator Cook, the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), has come into the chamber for at least part of this debate on the most important industry that Australia has ever had and is likely to have for a long time. His presence is preferable to that of the Minister who has vowed to close up resources and has put marginal land on the agenda for closing up also.

SPEECH.PARA: The formalities of the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989 and the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Bill 1989, have already been explained by my colleague, Senator Lewis, who was ably backed up by Senator Brownhill and Senator Boswell. In the short time I have this evening, I would like to address briefly certain points concerning the amendment to the wheat marketing legislation. The Senate may remember that this legislation passed through Parliament around 1 June 1989. Yet, here we are, six months down the track, already having to amend it. We are amending the legislative power which is given to the wheat industry to allocate part of the industry tax to research. Obviously, that was overlooked. The levy has been set at 2 1/2 per cent for this season, of which 0.5 per cent will go to the trust fund. That figure may be changed every year. As I said, this amendment is needed because this provision was not included in the original legislation.

This is probably a good time to review the new Act, as a new delivery season has almost been completed. This legislation made a big change to the old wheat marketing system, which was not accepted too well by growers around Australia. Although being one of those most definitely against the change, in the final analysis I was prepared to support it with my colleagues and see how it operated around Australia. I am prepared to see it given a go, but it is time that we reviewed it to see how it has operated during the first season.

The wheat marketing legislation that was passed earlier this year deregulated the domestic market. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy recommended that each State deregulate its storage, handling and transport systems. Some benefits were to come down the track. First of all there was deregulating the storage, handling and transport systems of each State. As I said, that was recommended in the McColl Royal Commission. Out of all these things, there was to be at least an average saving around Australia of $10 per tonne.

Before the Act was passed growers were to store mandatorily with each State bulk handling authority only where they had the sole rights. Transport, of course, belonged to each State for it to do as it thought fit. Most States around Australia still have, as they certainly had then, a regulated transport system. Queensland was waiting for the States to put these measures into action. Mr Kerin can make sure, in our getting those benefits that were promised-and giving up those other benefits that the growers had; I will mention those later-that we get more back than we are giving up.

Mr Kerin was supposed to see to it that the other States did their part and deregulated transport, handling and storage. Of course, each State had to pass complementary legislation. What happened? Queensland, my State of Western Australia, and South Australia have refused to do this up to date. As Mr Kerin told us, there were to have been changes on the waterfront. There has been nothing whatsoever done on the waterfront up to date. We have been told that the waterfront will cost us $630m over the next umpteen years, so what do we do with it? Nothing has been delivered in this first year.

The State handling authorities and State rail authorities want to keep their own sole authority under the umbrella of the State governments. I believe New South Wales supplied most of the storage facilities and in other States that had their own bulk handling authorities, for example Western Australia, money was raised solely by the growers by way of a revolving toll. They used the excuse that they wanted to keep sole handling authority for those reasons.

Western Australia not only refused to deregulate storage and handling; it also refused to deregulate the transport system. Not only did it refuse to deregulate the transport system, but its bulk handling authority went into a five-year freight contract. Not only did it go into a five-year contract with them, but also it accepted a 5 per cent rise. Everywhere in Australia rail freight charges are dropping. I believe that Victoria dropped its charges by about 17 per cent. No, Western Australia agreed, and its bulk handling authority agreed, to increase rail charges by 5 per cent when they should have been dropping. They signed a contract for five years without going out to see what the market was by throwing a few selected bins open for tender to see what the true cost was. They decided not to do that; they signed a contract that will lock us in for five years at least. I do not know what the other States are doing, but that is the case in Western Australia.

I ask: Where is the micro-economic reform that was promised to us by Mr Kerin when he bulldozed this Bill through last year, and where are the benefits we were supposed to get? Of all those returns we were promised, we have not seen any yet. The fact is that these States have refused to give up regulated transport and have the State handling authorities give up their sole rights. What are they doing? Mr Kerin is blaming the Grains Council of Australia. The Australian tells us what is happening now; it is there for everyone to see. Mr Kerin cannot find any other scapegoat so he is blaming the highest representative body of the wheat growers in Australia because it pointed out to him the problems that would arise in the new Wheat Marketing Act. Mr Kerin did not listen. He was hell-bent on micro-economic reform-micro-economic reform for everyone on the land, but not on the wharf, not in coastal shipping or anything like that that might affect his side of politics. I suggest that instead of blaming the Grains Council of Australia which has done a great job representing the wheatgrowers he should blame himself and find out where he went wrong.

The handling authorities around Australia can still control their own facilities. As is pointed out in an article in the Australian, they make out that someone is trying to take control of the silos. They own them, so how can anyone take control of them? All we want is other players in the bulk handling field so that we can find out what the true handling of wheat is on the open market. No-one will take the silos off the handling authorities to store wool, barley, or whatever. They have been set up for handling the Australian wheat crop and the wheat growers can put in whatever the handling authorities want at any time.

The bulk handling authorities have been long established. I know that Western Australia's cooperative bulk handling was established in 1926, South Australia's was established in 1961, New South Wales's was established in the 1920s, and Victoria's was established in the 1930s. How can the handling authorities say that they cannot compete with a new player coming into the field this year? That is a fallacy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lies.
—Senator McGauran says, `Lies'. That is what it is.
—Who was telling lies?

—The bulk handling authorities are telling lies if they reckon that they cannot compete in the open market with all their debts paid off. They have not built a new silo in Western Australia for at least eight or nine years and they are telling lies if they say that they cannot compete with any new player coming into the field.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, to get this new marketing system going-even I accepted it in the end-wheat growers have lost many priviliges. Something that did not come to light until the last week or so is the fact that a pool did not last for the whole season. Under the old system there was a pool for the whole year. Queensland was the first to deliver to the pool. It used to usually open on 1 November every year and close on 31 October of the following year. Wheat could be delivered to that pool for the entire year, though minimal wheat was delivered after the harvesting season closed.

It is vastly different now. We were told that the Wheat Board could be used as the last resort buyer. But, no, the pool will last only as long as the new Wheat Board thinks fit. It cannot give me an undertaking that it will even last for the harvesting season. Queensland is the first to deliver its harvest; northern New South Wales is next, followed by the northern parts of Western Australia. If there is downward pressure on world wheat prices the Wheat Board can chop the pool off before the wheatgrowers have delivered to the pool for that season. At least if the pool cannot last for the whole year legislation should be enacted so that it remains open for the harvesting season in Australia, which is roughly from 25 October to the end of January. I think that that would cover 99.8 per cent of Australia's harvest. Otherwise we are likely to have three or four pools for the whole season.

Under this system the wheatgrowers of Australia lost the underwriting. The growers are still being underwritten for this season at 90 per cent of gross national product but it will reduce over five years to 80 per cent and then will disappear altogether. We have lost that guarantee. I was not prepared to accept a total loss of the underwriting. I was happy to have underwriting on a one-year basis, rather than on a three-year rotating average. I was not happy to lose it altogether. Underwriting allows the Wheat Board to borrow on the world's financial markets at a preferred interest rate. We have lost that avenue. We have lost the guarantee of payment for wheat delivered to the Wheat Board. The wheat that is sold outside the Wheat Board does not carry a guarantee. I do not mind that either, but we have lost many advantages and rights that we have had since 1947 under the Wheat Marketing Act. Our forefathers fought, from about 1935 onwards, to get a regulated wheat market-it can be better described as an orderly wheat market-without being knocked off all over the world. I am proud to say that my late father was one of the founding members of the wheat growers union of Western Australia. We have lost all these advantages.

We are now waiting for the benefits to flow from Mr Kerin's promises. But where are they? I have not seen any. I have seen only the down side of the present marketing system. I am waiting for the benefits. I am waiting to see the waterfront cleaned up. I am waiting for coastal shipping to be thrown open. But that is not on the Government's agenda. We have been promised things but they are not forthcoming. We were promised that we would be able to sell to whomever we liked and to extract the maximum from the domestic market. I can tell the Senate what we have extracted out of the domestic market. I am in the wheat growing game and I can tell the Senate what is happening in Western Australia. The private wheat buyers-some of whom have set up silos-are offering $10 a tonne for wheat they select, even within Australian standard white wheat (ASW). ASW wheat is wheat that has a protein content of between 8 per cent and 11.5 per cent. Wheat is also graded according to weed contamination and by hectolitre weight. The grade above ASW is high protein (HP) wheat and prime hard wheat.

Private buyers are offering $10 a tonne above the estimated pool return. But for that they want the grower to pay the 2.5 per cent levy. They are selecting their own varieties, even within ASW wheat. Of course, they prefer to get HP wheat for the price of ASW wheat. They are very selective in their buying. They are paying $10 a tonne above the estimated pool price. Any wheat grower in Australia knows that for many years the Wheat Board has been very conservative in setting the estimated pool return. The worst season the Wheat Board ever went through was the 1986-87 season. It turned out in the final analysis that it had overestimated the final pool return by 22c a tonne. That is what the Wheat Board realised under its estimate. The Wheat Board has been very conservative in its estimate in other years. So if the estimate is within the conservative amount of $10 a tonne, which is quite likely, those private buyers are paying no premium. In the final analysis, if I am any judge, those private buyers will be paying less than the pool.

To wind up, I said at the beginning that I did not want this new wheat marketing system. I was glad that the Government at least did not deregulate the export market. In solidarity with my colleagues, I decided finally to support the legislation; I still have an open mind on how this marketing system is going to go. Believe you me, I want to see the system work, but I also want to see some of those advantages that we were promised out of the new marketing Act. It is time that Mr Kerin stopped blaming the Grains Council of Australia and delivered the goods.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills we are debating cognately are the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) and the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Bill. The Bills cover a wide range of primary industries-the tobacco growing industry, the wool industry, the beef industry, the dairy produce industry, the canned fruit industry and the massive coal industry. That is a very broad range of primary industries indeed. Each makes its unique contribution to the export income of Australia and each has its particular concerns and problems; yet, due to this Government's legislative program, we are unable to give due consideration to each industry. We are unable to consider each one of those industries properly and fully outline the effects that these Bills will have on the industries.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's answer to the log-jam of legislation before the Senate is to lump together all the legislation that vaguely seems to be relevant to each other and shove it all through before Christmas. It is worth making the point that it is a sure sign of a very nervous and unsure Government that it keeps us sitting right up to Christmas in the hope of clearing the decks of controversial legislation or simply to get through legislation that should have been in and passed some time ago. The Government is rushing through the legislation so as to be able to clear the decks in the coming months before the election. In the long run, it is no way to run a country. It is the country that suffers in the long run, because it is nothing short of political opportunism.

However, not to be deterred by the lumping together of these many industries in this cognate debate, I will give time to each one in my address. I am pleased to be able to follow the three honourable senators I consider to be the finest advocates of primary industry in this chamber. Senator Boswell, a National Party of Australia senator from Queensland, spoke about the great subsidies that overseas primary industry receives while the Australian industry does not; it must compete on a corrupt world market. Senator Brownhill, a National Party senator from New South Wales, is a great advocate for the wool and sheep industry. Senator Panizza, a Liberal Party senator from Western Australia, outlined his continuing concerns about the wheat industry and the wheat marketing industry legislation.

Before I get into the legislation itself, I pick up from where Senator Panizza left off and speak about the Wheat Marketing Bill. As honourable senators will be aware, the Wheat Marketing Bill passed through the Senate earlier this year with great controversy. The controversy centred around deregulating the domestic wheat market. Rather than going through a long and tortuous debate again, suffice it to say that the Government guaranteed Australian wheat farmers that if they took their medicine, that is, effectively dismantled the Australian Wheat Board, certain benefits would flow from legislation. Those benefits would primarily be in the micro-economic reform area-that is, on the waterfront and in the transport and handling of grain. The news today is that that commitment has not been met. It has been nothing short of a big lie to Australian wheat farmers. They have been dudded.

TALK.START.PARA: —By a Labor government.

—By the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin. There has been no sign of reform on the waterfront and no sign of reform in the handling and transport of grain. Indeed, it has been reported today that three States-Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia-have backed down on the axed recommendations and are seeking to retain control of the grain handling system. Typically, the response by Mr Kerin has been to attack the Grains Council of Australia, the representative of Australian wheat farmers. Mr Kerin has criticised the Australian Grains Council for failing to confirm its position on the right of the Australian Wheat Board to override State grain handling powers, which are written into the Federal legislation. Mr Kerin seems to believe that this endorsement by the Grains Council will somehow shift the States into action. I do not believe it will. He was told that during the wheat debate and he did not listen. He chose simply to lie to and abuse Australian wheat farmers. Every criticism levelled--

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator McGauran should withdraw the reference to lies, which was an unparliamentary reflection upon the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.
—I ask Senator McGauran to withdraw his comment.

—I withdraw my comment, Madam Acting Deputy President, and replace the word with `misrepresentation'. Mr Kerin has grossly misrepresented the position and abused Australian wheat farmers. Every criticism levelled at the Wheat Marketing Act is now becoming a reality. There is no waterfront reform; there is no complementary legislation by the States; there is no guarantee of quality in storage; there is no check and balance on the oligopoly power; and there is still no guarantee that grain merchants will not be able to snooker the export market. Many of the prophecies of the Opposition are now fully fulfilled and all of those prophecies will be fulfilled within five years.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Kerin, as Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, has paraded around for the past seven years of the Hawke Government, asserting his credibility, full of promise. But he has always failed to deliver. It is a case of `Big John's got the light on but no-one is home'. Every time there has been a battle between the environmentalists and the productive sectors of our society and economy, Senator Richardson has rolled Mr Kerin humiliatingly. It is only now and far too late, that Mr Kerin has spoken up. He really has become Barry Jones the Second, a walking zombie, a man with no power and respect in his portfolio any more. If he had any decency he would resign before he is thrown out. He is just holding down the job. I call upon Mr Kerin to defend his position, to defend the Wheat Marketing Act, and to put into place all the guarantees or resign. I quote from today's press release from the Grains Council of Australia to make quite clear that the Grains Council has defended itself in the strongest manner. It represents 45,000 wheat farmers in Australia. The press release states:

The Federal Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr John Kerin, is seeking to use the Grains Council of Australia (GCA) as a scapegoat in his attempts to deliver continued State Rail grain transport monopolies to his union mates, according to Chairman of the Council's Wheat Committee, Mr Donald McGauchie . . . it is clear that the Minister is still reeling from the bucketing the Council gave him this time last year over the deal he struck with the Australian Railways Union.
``It is yet again'', he said ``indicative of this government in full election mode. And'', he said, ``is characteristic of the Hawke Government's inconsistency on microeconomic reform.

Having said that about the wheat industry and shown the seriousness of that charge, I will now address myself to many of the other industries represented in this legislation. Firstly, the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 makes a number of administrative changes. The first one is a proposed amendment to the Plant Variety Rights Act. At the moment, breeders of new plants can claim exclusive rights to sell or license to sell for a period of 20 years. It is somewhat like a patenting of the new plant. However, while that plant is protected, the produce-that is, the flower or fruit-is not, and can not be, sold on. The amendment simply extends the rights of the breeder of the new plant to the plant's produce. This amendment is not challenged but is seen as a proper move to protect the business rights of the breeder or the inventor of the plant. It gives incentive to the innovative botanist.

This Bill also relates to the dairy industry. The change to the Dairy Produce Act simply clarifies the position that all late payers of the milk fat levy will be liable to 20 per cent interest. One of the greatest challenges facing the dairy industry in the 1990s is our closer economic relations with New Zealand. This agreement effectively drops all trade barriers between the two nations. In the area of dairy produce, New Zealand will gain a comparative advantage over Australia's producers as long as the New Zealand Government continues to support the monopoly trader status of the New Zealand Dairy Corporation, as well as extending interest free loans to that Corporation. It is obvious that our dairy farmers have cause for concern. This Government is sitting idly by, espousing the virtues of free trade between the two countries, while New Zealand is arming itself with an obvious advantage.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are doing it all the time.
