—It is doing so all the time, as Senator Boswell interjects. Of course, it is doing so all the time. This is reminiscent of the famous Chamberlain saying `Peace in our time'. The agreement has a clause that allows the Australian Government to act when unfair practices are undertaken and are in conflict with the spirit of the agreement. A vigilant enforcing of this clause is required to protect our dairy industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation before the Senate also deals with the beef industry. The legislation amends the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Act 1964. The amendment will allow the industry to decide which of its accounts it will draw on to pay for the cost of raising and administering this levy. This is a technical alteration giving the industry broader financial power. However, it allows me a moment to mention the most pressing concerns facing the beef industry.

Presently there are many problems in this once relatively stable industry. Firstly, the industry has improved its access into the Japanese market by increasing its quotas but it is equally aware of the increased investment of the Japanese in all stages of beef production in Australia. The Cattle Council of Australia has rightly signalled its concern that market integration by foreign interests can lead to market domination and market manipulation which is not in the interests of the industry or the nation. To this end a policy needs to be introduced that safeguards this extremely important industry from market manipulation. The major safeguard is greater case by case scrutiny of investment proposals. This requires a greater allocation of resources by the Government so as to be able to scrutinise effectively.

It should be stated that foreign investment is welcomed as it benefits the long term expansion of the industry, particularly the feedlot industry. The interests of the Japanese investors in this part of the beef industry have allowed this capital intensive specialised development to get off the ground in Australia where otherwise it may not have. The very risky and volatile meatworks establishments have been given a much needed injection of capital by Japanese investors. Whilst the number of abattoirs with Japanese equity is relatively small they account for a growing share of the total Australian cattle kill-23 per cent of beef and veal exports to Japan. The share of Japanese markets for beef and veal held by Japanese companies, taking into account licence exporters to Japan-that is, trading companies as distinct from the 23 per cent figure from abattoir holdings-is 58 per cent of exports from Australia to Japan. To this point-it is a matter of judgment-that is not a particular unhealthy state. But the Government must pick up the very clear signal.

There is a genuine concern in the whole industry that the Japanese not be allowed to integrate to the point where they will manipulate the saleyard prices of Australian farmers. From reports I have received from delegations that have returned from Japan this integration investment strategy is very much in the minds of those investors. However, in order of priorities foreign investment in the beef industry pales into insignificance when compared to the damaging effects now imposed upon the industry by the unions. The current rolling strikes being waged by the Australian meatworkers union in Victorian abattoirs is preventing the industry from meeting its export commitments and starving this country of valuable export income. Unquestionably, it has badly affected saleyard prices. On average, cow prices have declined 10c to 20c a kilogram and bullock prices 7c to 8c a kilogram.

It is worth outling the cause of this public dispute. It dates back to as long ago as the very bitter Borthwick's abattoir dispute last year. After the resolution of that dispute, which effectively imposed on the union a Federal award over a State award-the Federal award being of lower pay-the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union attempted to avoid any flow-on effects to other abattoirs by running an industrial campaign in an attempt to coerce export and domestic abattoirs into signing their own Victorian meatworks and by-products award, the union's own invention. This union-made award had already been rejected by the Industrial Relations Commission in the Borthwick's case.

R. J. Gilbertson Pty Ltd, G. & K. O'Connor Export Abattoir Pty Ltd, Castricum Brothers Pty Ltd Meat Exporters and McPhee Meats-the four largest abattoirs in the State-decided to take a stand. To the disgrace of the Industrial Relations Commission, the case has taken six months to come before it. Over those six months all four exporters and a number of other abattoirs throughout the State have been plagued by industrial action. In the last five months alone the four major export abattoirs have lost on average 40 out of every 100 working days. The Government should not underestimate the importance of this industrial dispute now going on in Victoria. The dispute has become the Alamo for the industry, an industry that has a work practice record equal to, if not worse than, the waterfront.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who do you cast as General Santa Anna?
—Is the Minister seeking to interject?
—For God's sake, I withdraw my interjection.
—I did not hear it.
—He is a long way back.

—Perhaps one day I will be at the front. Getting back on track, the industry is led by the well-known Victorian unionist, Wally Curran. He is from the school of Tas Bull, Norm Gallagher, John Halfpenny and Laurie Carmichael-the fruit loops. Many family businesses have been sent to the wall in the past by Wally Curran's utterly reckless ways. Many family companies which are suffering as a result of this dispute have told me that they will go to the wall now rather than give in to Wally Curran and his meatworkers. This is the last stand; this is the Alamo. It is essential for the Government to take note of this dispute and intervene in the best way that it can. Regrettably, I am unable to dwell on this matter as there is far more in this legislation that I wish to attend to. Other than the pilots dispute this is the most costly strike in Victoria today, over and above the existing transport strike.

SPEECH.PARA: The next amendment is to the Tobacco Marketing Act 1965. It will change the name of the Tobacco Board to the Australian Tobacco Marketing Advisory Committee. In many respects this seems to be a trivial change, as the dropping of the name Tobacco Board for the Tobacco Marketing Advisory Committee is meant merely to distinguish clearly the Federal body from the State bodies. Technically, I suppose that it is correct, as the Federal body is only a negotiating forum for the setting of the average minimum price and the administrator of the tobacco industry stabilisation plan. In fact, it does not handle the receipt or sale of the product. The industry supplies only the domestic market. In total, the industry stabilisation plan assures Australian growers of up to 57 per cent of the domestic market. To this end, Queensland supplies 58 per cent of the domestic tobacco market.
Senator Boswell interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell may be interested to know-he should cast his eyes south-that Victoria supplies 37 per cent of the domestic market and New South Wales supplies 5 per cent. Tobacco farmers are the epitome of the Australian family farmer. They remind us the most of the benefit of the family farm as both a social and an economic unit. Anyone who travels to the districts of Bright and Myrtleford in Victoria not only will be taken by the very rich countryside but also will notice the relatively small tobacco farms which are all worked by families-in many cases, immigrant families from Italy. This industry and these people are being forgotten as we enter the pious tussle of the for and against tobacco advertising.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills repeal a series of States grants Acts related to the canned fruit industry which I will not read out. Suffice to say that the legislation was introduced to provide assistance to the industry following the United Kingdom's entry into the European Economic Community in the early 1970s; so it goes back that far. Since the entry of the United Kingdom into the Economic Community we have lost 50 per cent of our canned fruit market. But today the industry faces an equally devastating concern-the loss of the $30 million Canadian market. That loss is because of the Canadian-United States free trade agreement which came into effect on 1 January 1989. It gives preference to Californian fruit and removes the old Canadian-Australian agreement that gives preference to Australian fruit. It is essential that pressure be maintained at the highest level on the Canadian Government. That level should not only include the Minister for Trade Negotiations, Mr Duffy, or the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, but should go as high as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). To that end, on 24 October 1989 the Prime Minister issued a statement which goes some way to addressing this very serious concern for the canned fruit industry. In that statement he said:
I have reached agreement with the Prime Minister of Canada, Mr Brian Mulroney, on the resolution of Canada's tariff treatment of Australian canned fruit exports.

Our agreement means the Canadian tariff on Australian canned fruit can be phased down, in the context of the Uruguay Round, to a level which leaves the Australian industry competitive with other exporters. The Australian industry can now have the confidence that the tariff rate it faces will permit it to remain both viable and competitive.

It is a very lofty statement, but its promise has not been delivered yet because the actual settlement of the reduction of tariffs will not be negotiated until the next Uruguay Round, which could be as long as 12 months away, if I am correct. They are lofty words and the Prime Minister will be kept to them, because it is a severe loss to the canned fruit industry. As Senator Boswell indicated in his address to the Senate, when Australia is preaching the level playing field philosophy, it seems that the rest of the world is laughing at us, particularly, the United States, with its export enhancement programs that subsidise its farmers to the tune of $1 billion.

I wish to move on to the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989. This Bill concentrates on changes to the constitution of the Wool Research and Development Council and selection procedures for its members. The wool industry is our most consistent and significant export industry, with exports up to $6 billion last year. However, like so many of our export commodities, the market is on the downturn. Never in Australia's wool industry history has the wool market taken such a steep dive. In the space of six months the number of bales bought by exporters has dropped 40 per cent on last year, while the Wool Corporation has been buying up to 60 per cent of the total offerings to support the floor price. The Corporation's stockpile, as Senator Brownhill pointed out, is at a record 1.8 million bales. The major reason for this stockpiling has been the impact of the political upheavals in China. The turning off of the Chinese tap has resounded not only in Australia but also in many of the Asian countries that supply processed wool and yarn to China from the Australian clip. In all it is estimated that the export income could be down by as much as $2 billion.

Simultaneously, the sheep industry has been dealt a second blow. The Saudi Arabian Government's rejection of vessels carrying Australian sheep has forced Australia to suspend its live sheep exports to this country. The live sheep export trade earns Australia $200m per year. Of that trade, 45 per cent went-we can use the past tense now as it seems almost a lost cause-to Saudi Arabia, our largest importer, with the remainder heading for other Gulf states. It is clear that the sheep industry is not in a very healthy state.

Unquestionably, the primary industry sector is the most efficient and productive in the world. On a world scale, Australia's wool industry is the largest exporter. Australia's beef industry is the second largest exporter. The Australian wheat industry is in the top three of the world's exporters. The total value of farm exports in 1988-89 was $16 billion. Internationally, Australia's rural exporters face formidable obstacles and they always manage to overcome them. The major factor in Australia's primary industry exports losing their competitiveness, other than the tariff barriers put up by the European Community and the quotas by the Japanese and Taiwanese, is the over-valued Australian dollar, which sits at between 78c and 79c to the United States dollar. In the short term a major influence on the exchange rates has been the Government's monetary policy.

Over the past two years the yield on 90-day Treasury notes has risen by about eight percentage points, attracting the inflow of short-term foreign capital-hot money. Thus, monetary policy aimed at slowing demand for imports has also had the conflicting effect not only of lowering the price of Australian imports but also making exports expensive. A lower exchange rate will boost the competitiveness of the export industries. If the rural sector is to compete on world markets, it must have a lower Australian dollar. The Australian dollar is being artificially propped up at unnatural levels and we will not be able to tackle our current account crisis until the Australian dollar is brought down. We need an export-led recovery and our primary industries can maintain competitiveness only with a lower Australian dollar.

I was unable to speak to every industry mentioned in this package of legislation. But I come back to my original point: the Government has put these Bills together cognately-shoved them all together-in many cases irrelevantly, simply to get all the legislation through before Christmas so that it can prepare for the coming election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today's order of business paper for the Senate discloses that Government Business order of the day No. 3 is Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989, and Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Bill 1989-Resumption of second reading debate; that is item No. 3 out of eight items of Government Business which were posted today. As the clock shows five minutes past 10, we have only reached towards the end of the second reading debate of the third item of Government Business today. There is still a very long legislative list for this chamber to address itself to.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I want to move to this legislation. As has been observed by many speakers in this debate, the legislation deals with omnibus Bills, Bills that pick up a series of amendments to Acts covered by the primary industries portfolio allocation. As is usual in Bills in which primary industry matters are proposed, honourable senators invariably choose this occasion to make speeches related to the general field of primary industry but not necessarily directly relevant to the items covered by the legislation. Again, that has been the case tonight. In replying on behalf of the Government I do not intend to reply to those items extraneous to the purposes of these Bills. I simply say to Opposition speakers, `We will meet you sometime in contest over those things with which you hold contrary opinions to us; but this will not be the occasion-our record stands clear'.

To the items that have been raised relevant to the Bills, firstly, I thank the senators who have supported in the main the key thrust of the Government's legislation; that is to say, all senators in the Opposition coalition parties and the Australian Democrats. There have been a number and a complexity, one would say, of amendments. But I make this charitable observation at the beginning of my remarks: those amendments are not to change the thrust of what we are on about here but rather to modify or, in the view of the movers, to better direct those changes that we have taken the initiative to propose.

While there are differences, those differences are at the margin and not at the core. That augurs well for the intention of the Government in the varied fields that these amendments affect. The main thrust of the reservations held by the Opposition was expressed in the speech by the Deputy Leader of the coalition, Senator Austin Lewis, during the second reading debate in which-I paraphrase his remarks-he indicated that what he lamented about these amendments that we were seeking, particularly in respect of research and development, was that they brought an undue intrusion of government bureaucracy into research and development, particularly in the coal area. The honourable senator nods and, therefore, I must have paraphrased accurately. What I can say, with respect to those reservations he has expressed, is that I think they arise from a perceptional fault as to what, in fact, is happening in the coal area. If we were not to pass the Government's amendments here we would revert to a system of funding for research and development out of the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council (NERDDC) round through the coal fund.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wouldn't it deregulate it altogether?

—I am saying that if Senator Lewis were to succeed, that is what would happen. Therefore, he would be inviting a continuation of government involvement through the advisory network of NERDCC in approving funding in this sense. I should perhaps canvass this more at the committee stage, but I will canvass the main points now during my second reading reply. The Bill proposes the establishment of a corporation which would enable the industry to have a majority voice and allocate funds on an industry levy basis so that the industry would then drive the research effort. I submit that would `de-bureaucratise'-if there is such a term-funding for research and development in the coal area.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me refer to another main point that Senator Austin Lewis would dwell on and, doubtless, would put with some force in rebuttal and that is that the coal industry does not want this and that we are imposing something on it which it disdains. I say to that that the Government has had consultations with the Australian coal mining industry. In fact, I have in my notes a letter from Mr J. B. Ritchie, who was, earlier this year, the Executive Director of the Australian Coal Association in which he supports, conceptually, the details of what we are proposing. If I were to be more of a cynic than a charitable person I might say that the Coal Association is not saying that it conceptually opposes the structure we are seeking to legislate for but, rather, it is using the obstruction of the passage of this section of our Bills to negotiate with the Government an input of public moneys to add to its levy monies and so obtain a bigger pool of funds for research and development. I say, `Good luck to it'. That is a manoeuvre that is open to it, but the Commonwealth does not think it is appropriate-particularly given the size of these companies and the 150 per cent tax write-off that they enjoy-to add to that pool. However, what we are proposing-and what I now categorically state-is that these amendments be carried. If they are, we will not act on them until such time as we have had further consultations with the coal industry and obtained agreement that we should proceed with this corporation for the coal industry. I will say more of that later, but I can give that assurance to the Senate. The passage of these provisions would enable us to continue and finalise those consultations and resolve what, I think, is a negotiating stand-off over money rather than a negotiating stand-off rejecting a principle that the Government is seeking to impose.

Finally, before I make an explanation of how I intend to deal with the arguably complex the myriad of amendments which have been put forward, perhaps I should turn to the publication released in May this year by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) and me, as the Minister for Resources, entitled Research, Innovation and Competitiveness. It is from the considerations in this publication that these Bills on research and development spring. If I might assuage the concerns that have been articulated by Senator Austin Lewis by turning to page 80 point 6, `Organisation and Administration of primary and energy industries research and development' and quote the key points. The first two points will only suffice, I think to assuage the concerns that the honourable senator has put. The first point is:
The Government's objective is to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the DPIE research network.
I think there is consensus that that is an ideal objective. More importantly, point two states:

R & D corporations have more flexibility than other forms of administration. Although they will remain accountable to both the Government and industry, they will be autonomous organisations able to vigorously pursue commercial objectives. In so doing they will be able to catalyse their industries to become more innovative and more adaptive.

Much has been said in the second reading debate by several contributors about the need to energise research and development in Australia across the whole range of areas contemplated in this legislation.

I now turn to the first substantive question; that is, Senator Lewis's amendment to the second reading motion. It is not the Government's intention to support this motion. We would ask the Senate to defeat it. In support of why it should be defeated, I advance a number of points. First, this motion was moved in the House of Representatives by the honourable member for Gippsland, Mr McGauran-my shadow, as I understand it-and it was proposed in what I understand to be identical terms as the one that Senator Lewis proposes for the Senate. It was defeated in the House. I ask that it be defeated in here.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not an argument for not supporting it.
—But that is making clear what my intention is in the debate.
—He gets his pictures in the paper though.

—Yes, he was talking about the other Bowie. He lost me when I could not work out who was Jim Bowie and who was Santa Anna in that stand-off. But that is a matter for him to work out, I guess, or for those of us who were listening to his speech to contemplate and conjure up possibilities about. However, returning to what was said in the House, Mr McGauran said that in relation to the whole range of fees under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act, concerning dealings in entitlements and acreage associated with exploration and production off-shore in Australian oil and gas fields, his intention was to ensure that the fees set by regulation:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . do not exceed the minimum administrative costs incurred by the Commonwealth, the States or the Northern Territory-
I interpolate at this point, `nor do we intend them to exceed that'.
in carrying out their respective objectives under the legislation.
I agree to this point. The next words are important:

. . . that the discretionary power vested in the Minister will not become an instrument for raising revenue, nor in any way discourage the petroleum exploration industry from expanding its exploration efforts.

I understand clearly what he means. I think, though, that his concern is wrongly based for the following reasons. First, the Commonwealth is not a beneficiary of these fees; it is merely the agent which collects them and disburses them to the States. We do not earn money out of them. We simply act as a post-box for the States, and the States are the beneficiaries. There is no motive, there is no reason, there is no possible gain to the Commonwealth for charging anything other than the minimum charge that is applicable.

Secondly, if we were to charge more than the minimum charge, properly recoverable, then we would be engaging in an act of taxation. Since we do not have any head of power to engage in such an act of taxation, we would be breaking the law and we would be prosecutable-and so we should be. The Commonwealth, as an agency determined to maintain and keep the law, is not likely to offend in any sense-firstly, because it would be breaking the law and, secondly, it would not gain anything even if it did-in the way in which the amendment contemplates and in the way in which Senator McGauran said it could when he dealt with this matter.

The second point made by Senator Lewis was that he does not have power to vary the regulations and he thinks that it is best to keep the actual amount in the Act so that the Senate can deal with the Act. We want to provide a timely adjustment so that we are not in a situation of retrospectively trying to catch up with costs incurred by the Commonwealth. If we were in that position, the oil companies would benefit. They would have loan of Commonwealth money for the period when the legislature makes the adjustment when, in fact by timely regulation we can do that so that there is not a financial holiday of sorts to oil companies which wish to engage in offshore exploration. From the point of principle no major company of this character should in any way be able to rest financially for a time on the Commonwealth. I, therefore, suggest that the amendment is improper. With those words it is entirely appropriate that we defeat the amendment moved by Senator Austin Lewis, perhaps with one small postscript that, were it to be carried, as well as all the things that I have put, it would impose a huge amount of work and regulation on the Department, which can utilise its resources for more constructive purposes.

Let me now turn to the amendments that we are in almost earnest expectation of dealing with when we move to the committee stage. My view of these amendments falls into three categories which I will categorise for ease of consideration into group A, group B and group C. There is now a fourth category which I will deal with first-what I would call the Asia Dairy-inspired amendments. Over dinner Senator Lewis drew my attention to these amendments and, as I understand it, indicated that he will move them. On behalf of the Government I indicate that we will accept those amendments. We believe that the first set of changes to section 28 are covered by the Act anyway; nonetheless it does not damage or misconstrue the Act in any sense to include them. While we might normally make a pedantic objection, we will not on this occasion; we will accept them. We will also accept the second group of amendments. Subject to the Australian Democrats' view, because I have not had a chance to confer with them, I think that would mean that the amendments would be acceptable to the Senate.

With that explanation I now turn to my A, B and C groups. In group A I have designated amendments that are acceptable to the Government that are being proposed here. They include amendments Nos 5, 6 and 8 relating to the variation of research and development plans. Amendment No. 9 is also acceptable to the Government and relates to consultations with representative organisations. Amendments Nos 13, 15, 16 and 17 are also acceptable and relate to matching industry contributions. Amendment No. 20 is acceptable and relates to transfer of corporation assets, and amendments Nos 21 and 22 with respect to the establishment of research and development corporations are acceptable. The parliamentary draftsman has advised me that while we consider those amendments to be acceptable, in the case of amendments Nos 9, 21 and 22 he wants to improve the wording to make it acceptable in parliamentary or legislative form. The change to the wording is not intended in any way to alter the meaning or intent of the amendments. It is simply a device by the parliamentary draftsman to make those words and changes fit within the parliamentary language and, appropriately, within the terms of the Bill. So amendments Nos 5, 6, 8, 9, 13, 15, 16, 17, 20, 21 and 22 are acceptable. I do not know how we will deal with them at the committee stage, but I hope that we can take them as a block, although they are out of sequence.

Group B is a group of amendments which I understand the Opposition will move and which the Government will not accept. They are amendments Nos 1, 2 and 3 in respect of the Coal Research and Development Corporation, and amendments Nos 18 and 19 with respect to selection criteria. I understand that the Australian Democrats also do not support those amendments. I acknowledge the fact that Senator Janet Powell is nodding, so I assume that there is a majority in this chamber to reject those amendments.

I now turn to amendments in what I term group C. Amendment No. 4 relates to dairy research. There is a significance about that which I will go to in a minute. Amendments 4a, 7 and 10 relate to the research and development plans of these organisations. This group also includes amendments Nos. 11 and 12. The Government would normally oppose those amendments. It thinks they are not really appropriate in this case. We have had discussions on some of the amendments and we think we can tolerate them, so we are not so greatly offended by them that we wish to oppose them, which is, I guess, a backhanded way of saying, `We will accept them under sufferance, but we will accept them nonetheless'. Once they are printed and are law, how we feel about them will only be a matter of interpretation and approach. They will stand in any case. I commend these omnibus Bills to the Senate and ask for their support.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that Senator Lewis's amendment to the motion that the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 be now read a second time be agreed to.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Lewis

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like it recorded that the Australian Democrats have joined with the Government in voting against my amendment. I shall not call for a division.

INTERJECT.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.

Bill agreed to.
PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1989
Bill agreed to.
PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1989

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 4, subclause 4 (1), definition of ``primary industry'', at end of definition, add ``but does not include any field of endeavour whose objective is the production of coal;''.
(2) Page 71, clause 154, lines 16 to 33, leave out the clause.
(3) Pages 72 and 73, subclause 156 (1), line 40 (page 72) to line 4 (page 73), leave out the subclause, insert the following subclause:

``(1) Where a Research Fund is abolished under subsection 152 (1) the Trust Account that, for the purposes of section 62a of the Audit Act 1901, constitutes the Research Fund is to be taken to have been closed under subsection 62a (4) of that Act.''.

These amendments would remove the coal industry research and development corporation. As I have stated, we see no purpose in the establishment of this body. It is not wanted by the industry and does not attract taxpayers' funds. As I understand what the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) said, the Australian Democrats will be joining with the Government in rejecting these amendments. So I indicate at this stage that if, on the call, I see that happen, I will not call for a division, but I would be interested to hear the Minister's explanation as to why he is opposed to these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats do not support these amendments. The coal industry research and development corporation will be reviewed towards the end of 1992 or the beginning of 1993. Should there be fundamental problems with this area of the legislation, obviously it will be possible to review the corporation at that time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since I have been invited to give a view from the Government, I advise that we see the significance of these amendments as not in fact setting up a coal research and development corporation, but rather as putting in place standard arrangements allowing the setting up of such an organisation. We recognise that, while there is a view emanating from the coal industry in opposition to this, it is not a universal view; there are other views as well. Thus we conclude that there is a degree of confusion in the industry about what might apply in the event of such a corporation being established. It is in recognition of that and in the interests of good sober government that we are committed to having further consultations with the industry on whether it will be part of such a research and development corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: If the industry as a whole rejects the proposal, we would not proceed with the establishment of such a corporation. But the Australian Coal Industry Association is a body to which we would look in conducting our consultations. As I said in my second reading speech, although I do not have the letter to hand, the Australian Coal Industry Association sent a letter to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy earlier in the year in which it described, in essence, what is a research and development corporation and said that that is what it would support. However, in later consultations it backed away from that position and, as I said, if I were not so charitable a person and was more a cynic, I might argue that the reason that it has backed away is that it wants the Commonwealth to put funds into such a body so that it is not dependent entirely upon the industry levy.

So I think that the bargaining point is not over the principle of such a body, which is to in fact `debureaucratise'-which I think is Senator Lewis's term-the research and development effort, but is over whether or not--

TALK.START.PARA: —You added the `de' to make it `debureaucratised'.

—Did I? Whatever that terrible word suggests, it is not over that; it is over whether money can be extracted from the Commonwealth. That leads us to believe that we are, by a process of consultation, able to resolve this conflict between the coal industry and the Government. Therefore, we are in full expectation that we could proceed. Again I make the point, as I did in my second reading reply, that if we did not the National Industry Research, Development and Demonstration Council principle would apply and funds would be allocated through that device.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Mr E. Laurie: Death-Senators: Rights-Olympic Games Team-Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Managing Director-Mr I. Causley-Senator Dunn

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do not adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 October 1989 Edward Andrew Hevingham Laurie died. He was the complete man. His spirit was noble; his intellect great; his physical abilities amazing. His career was remarkable in terms of both what he achieved and what he sacrificed because of his beliefs. The pursuit of ideals cost him advancement and office. It brought great good to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Ted Laurie was born in 1912. He had an elite background. His father was a doctor holding an honorary appointment at the Alfred Hospital. His grandfather had been Professor of Philosophy at Melbourne University. His mother had graduated there in arts. In 1924 Ted went to Scotch College. He established a brilliant academic record. He played for the school in cricket, football and tennis. He was captain of the cricket team. In 1930 he became the school's head prefect. Ted attended Melbourne University during the first half of the 1930s. He won blues in football and cricket. He graduated with a Bachelor of Laws degree in 1935. The following year he was admitted to the Victorian Bar.

In 1937 Ted went to work in Queensland. There Brian Fitzpatrick, the historian and civil rights worker, persuaded him to become secretary of the Council for Civil Liberties. He became active in several organisations. In these he met a number of Communists, by whom he was much impressed. In 1939 Ted Laurie joined the Communist Party of Australia. He did so for high motive. His family was altruistic. His mother was a Christian pacifist. His father presented him with a model of the compassionate man. With this background, Ted was moved by the injustice he saw in society. This was accentuated by the Depression in the thirties. Between 1941 and 1945 Ted was in the Army. He served in the Pacific theatre; the Japanese sank a ship he was on in Milne Bay. He was commissioned in the field.

In 1944 he married Bonnie Mackay, the daughter of a journalist whose career included editorship of the Argus, at that time a great Melbourne newspaper. It was a marriage of high success. Bonnie's death in March 1978 was a cruel occasion for Ted. I express my sympathy to their three children, Robin, Bayne and Bill, for the loss they have suffered.

In the post-war period Ted pursued a career which places him amongst the greatest of advocates, no matter where, this in spite of its being forever beset by mainfest prejudice. Happily, this waned in later years as his qualities were more and more appreciated. His application to join the Bar was granted by the Council only after considerable debate. In 1961 the Chief Justice of the Victorian Supreme Court, Sir Edmund Herring, refused him silk on the grounds that the Bolsheviks had killed the Tsar in 1918. Sir Edmund told Ted he could never forgive them for having murdered a relative of the royal family. By 1965 Sir Henry Winneke was Chief Justice of Victoria. He asked Ted why he had not taken silk. When told the reason he was much amused. Ted became a Queen's Counsel soon after. He was a towering silk, practising with great distinction in a number of areas until retiring from the Bar in 1982. Ted had one reader who went on to practise at the bar, Frank Vincent, now Mr Justice Vincent of the Victorian Supreme Court.

The late forties and early fifties were harsh times to take up unpopular causes. Russia first exploded an atom bomb in 1949 and a hydrogen bomb in 1953. In 1949 Tiananmen Square saw Mao Tse Tung announce the success of his revolution. The Korean War broke out in June 1950 and lasted until July 1953. Stalin ruled Russia until March 1953. In January 1950 Alger Hiss was convicted in the United States of perjury and, by inference, of spying. The following month, the Government of the United Kingdom announced that Klaus Fuchs, head of the physics department at the Harwell Atomic Energy Research Establishment, had confessed to passing atomic secrets to Russia. In July 1950 Julius and Ethel Rosenberg were arrested in America for espionage. They were sentenced to death on 5 April 1951 and executed on 19 July 1953. Joseph Raymond McCarthy, the Senator for Wisconsin, was at the height of his power. The Senate did not censure him until December 1954.

On 19 May and 14 June 1949 letters patent of royal commissions were granted to Mr Justice Lowe to inquire into and report upon the origins, aims, objects and funds of the Communist Party in Victoria. Ted appeared for the Communist Party. When he took the brief he knew it would set back his career. His integrity of purpose overrode any concern he had for personal advancement.

On 20 October 1950 Sir William McKell, as Governor-General of Australia, assented to the Communist Party Dissolution Act. It was challenged in the High Court of Australia by the Australian Communist Party and a number of other plaintiffs. The hearing began on 14 November 1950. Ted Laurie again appeared for the Party. The court held that the Commonwealth Government had no power to make the law it purported to. The High Court handed down its decision on 9 March 1951. On 5 July 1951 the Constitution Alteration (Power to Deal with Communists and Communism) Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives by Mr Robert Gordon Menzies, as he then was. This was passed and the referendum held on 22 September 1951. It was rejected by just 50.48 per cent of the voters. Anti-communism was running high.

The decision of the High Court that was handed down on 9 March 1951 and the referendum which was held six months later were crucial to Australia's development as an open, tolerant and democratic society. Freedom of expression, freedom of association and freedom of thought would now be much diminished but for the resolve of Ted and precious few like him. A true democracy guards the rights of the unpopular, especially when under ferocious attack.

In December 1945 the Cain Government passed an Act abolishing the doctrine of common employment. In May 1946 it made extensive amendments to the Workers Compensation Act. In December 1951 the McDonald Government abolished contributory negligence as an absolute defence and made it the basis for apportionment. These changes gave workers the potential to recover better and fairer payments for injuries they suffered in the course of their employment. A small group of lawyers enabled them to realise that potential. The lawyers prepared the cases, defined the issues, gathered the evidence and developed the strategy necessary for the victim of an industrial accident to have a successful outcome. Ted was a leader in this group. His preparation and presentation of common law claims became the model for plaintiffs' counsel. He was a towering jury advocate able to mix logic and emotion in the right proportions. He was a formidable opponent and drew top settlements from apprehensive insurers.

Ted played a central role in the development of industrial law in Australia. He practised in the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration until its effective demise in 1956, then in the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and then in the Australian Industrial Court and the industrial division of the Federal Court of Australia. He appeared regularly in the High Court. His name is spread liberally throughout the reports; his arguments have become precedents in industrial law.

Ted had great loyalty to his Party. His hunger for justice, for what was fair and for what the dignity of people demanded tempered his commitment. Internationally, the dark side of communism was manifest in the 1950s and early 1960s. Soviet troops invaded Hungary in October 1956. The split between China and Russia became public in 1960. At home Ted saw some leaders of the Communist Party use it for personal power and glory. They all served the rank and file who worked hard and deserved better. In 1965 Ted quietly left the organisation.

Ted's high purpose never flagged. It forever remained pertinent to the times. In the 1970s he successfully appeared in equal opportunity cases for women, land right actions for Aboriginals and prosecutions for peaceful protesters. At the end of his career he defended a tragic young man charged with manslaughter. He won an acquittal. Had Ted pursued a course different from the one he did, his pedigree, his qualities of mind, body and spirit would almost certainly have brought him to high office on the Bench or in government. He understood this but never repented of his choice. The living out of his ideals was his great ambition.

Ted was compassionate by nature, generous by instinct and tolerant by conviction. Though there were numerous occasions for it, Ted had an overwhelming lack of hate. His view of the world and the people in it was benign. He felt deeply for anyone who suffered in mind, body or soul. He invariably treated his clients with respect and understanding. His fees were moderate. He gave generously of his time to colleagues who sought his advice. His actions reflected an innate compassion for all people. Ted loved his football, his cricket and his sport in general. He loved the law. He loved his ideals. Most of all he loved his fellows. His life was well spent in their service. On 29 October 1989 a mighty spirit departed this earth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

It is not a matter I do lightly; I would prefer not to do it. Reluctantly I have come to the conclusion that I have little choice but to bring this matter into the open and deal with it. As you will be aware, Mr President, the Australian domestic aviation industry has been involved in a serious dispute since August. It has had devastating effects on Australia's tourism which was our biggest export earner last year. These effects will cost this nation well over $1 billion and will extend for years into the future. Many hundreds, if not thousands, of companies-most of them small and family owned-will go bankrupt, taking with them the life savings of their owners. There will be no climb back to normality after this dispute has been resolved for those people who are innocent victims of the dispute between the airlines and their employees. The effects on the airlines and pilots, serious though they are, are of a lesser magnitude.

SPEECH.PARA: Given these circumstances, circumstances of national importance, it is quite proper for the Senate to be involved, not as a surrogate for the Industrial Relations Commission, for that is not the role of the Parliament, but in being concerned with all the aspects of this unnecessary dispute which are having such a tragic effect on our nation.
