TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, you will note that this letter is now to the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Cooney. A copy was sent to me. We see that Mr Harris has now taken the trouble to read the Hansard in a belated attempt to find out what did happen. He does not say that he was wrong; he does not apologise. In the circumstances they would have been the actions of a reasonable person. He now qualifies his statement about the press. He totally shifts his claims about what happened to Wiltshire. The Hansard transcript proves Harris wrong. He now blames my colleague Senator Brownhill for `casting aspersions on the reputation of Captain David Wiltshire'. Then comes a pathetic and childish attempt to justify his attacks with the statement:

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that Senator MacGibbon was interjecting in support of Senator Brownhill although not reported in the transcript.
The probity and accuracy of Hansard are now impugned.

There are several points that must be made from the Harris letters. The first and most important point is that senators have the right to freedom of speech in the Parliament. The right of freedom of speech in Parliament draws its powers from the Parliamentary Act 1987. This, in turn, derives its powers from section 49 of the Australian Constitution, through that to the House of Commons of the British Parliament and ultimately to the Bill of Rights 1688. As well as conferring clear and specific rights and immunities on senators and members it also covers contempt of the Parliament. Contempt of the Parliament is a criminal offence punishable either by a prison sentence of up to six months or by a fine not exceeding $5,000 for a person, or $25,000 in the case of a corporation. Any attempt to threaten, intimidate or suborn a senator in the exercise of his duties is a contempt of the Parliament.

Secondly, Mr Harris has been proved wrong and has been shown to be careless with the truth in making these attacks. The point must be made that, even if the charges made by Mr Harris were true, senators have the right to go about their duties and to inquire into and investigate matters of national importance with immunity. It is perfectly proper for witnesses to be questioned rigorously and robustly if the occasion warrants it. It may well be that an outcome favourable to the witness can emerge as a result of rigorous questioning when a more benign approach might have caused the opposite to occur.

There is another point to this as well. This behaviour by Mr Harris is distasteful and insulting to me but it is also distasteful and insulting to the Senate. Mr President, in the chamber, you and you able deputies control the standard of debate in accordance with Standing Orders so that decorum prevails. Similarly, in committees, the Chairman, under the same Standing Orders, sees that the meetings or hearings of those committees are conducted with due courtesy. By his letters Mr Harris is attacking Senator Cooney's actions as Chairman as much as he is attacking Senator Brownhill.

I note that this is not the first time Mr Harris has behaved so deplorably. In 1987, one of our colleagues Senator Puplick questioned an official from the Australian Sports Commission at a Senate Estimates committee hearing. Mr Harris, whose position as Chairman of Australian Airlines and the Australian Sports Commission coincides with the tenure of Mr Hawke as Prime Minister, wrote the same sort of letter as he wrote to me threatening Senator Puplick for daring to question one of his officials. Just as Mr Harris wrote to Senator Cooney in an attempt to bring pressure to bear on me, so Mr Harris wrote to Mr John Valder who was then Federal President of the Liberal Party of Australia. He described Senator Puplick's action in the most denigratory of terms and for good measure finished with a threat about the difficulties of obtaining funds for political parties when people, presumably like Senator Puplick, in his opinion prostitute the systems of the Parliament. Senator Puplick dealt with the matter in his usual accomplished way. For those who are interested, pages 1665 to 1668 of the Senate Hansard of 3 November 1987 record this somewhat unequal duel.

I would like to give Mr Harris some further advice. His priorities should be directed to discharging his fiduciary duties as a director of this greatly troubled company, Australian Airlines. It is now in desperate financial straits as a consequence of his failure to take the appropriate actions to resolve this dispute. He is the Chairman. His shareholders, the people of Australia, are greatly displeased at his stewardship. If it is possible for the company to survive-and it is not at all clear that it can-it will take all his concentrated efforts to bring that about.

Neither I nor any senator here will be stood over or deterred from our duty by intimidatory threats such as those made by the Board of Australian Airlines at the behest of its Chairman. I will not be deflected or intimidated from performing my proper public responsibilities. If any further action along the lines I have experienced is taken, it will result in the appropriate action being taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My comments relate to people a little closer to home. I had the dubious distinction of observing, during the dinner break, one of the news bulletins. I noticed the expert on sport in this Parliament, the posturing, portly and corpulent Senator Graeme Richardson, whose claim this morning was that he was the one who knew all about sport, the selection agenda and criteria, and nobody else did.
—He got the gold medal and you got the bronze.

—He got the gold medal, did he? Let us wait and see how many of the 85 athletes that have been selected quite properly on the proper criteria are dropped from the team by Mr John Coates and see what Senator Graeme Richardson has to say about that. Let him tell these athletes personally that as a result of his backroom wheeling and dealing, they have been scrubbed from the team, notwithstanding the fact that they quite properly and legitimately have been selected to represent Australia by the selection panel for their team.

SPEECH.PARA: The comment that Senator Richardson made was that he would rather have Mr John Coates select the team than he would the Senate. That might be the bureaucratic, autocratic way in which this Government and the fixers do business. Perhaps that is symptomatic of the arrogance that they demonstrate towards this chamber. As we all know, the difference is that Mr John Coates represents his own point of view in this case. I shall read part of the resolution carried today:
(vii) that there is no practical reason why these 15 young Australian athletes should not be given an opportunity to represent their country; and-
this is the Senate-
(b) calls upon:
(i) the ACGA to reverse its decision and allow these athletes an opportunity to represent Australia, and
(ii) the Government to convey to the ACGA the view that the 85 qualifying Australian track and field athletes be allowed to compete in the Auckland Commonwealth Games.

That resolution was carried by senators who represent millions of ordinary, decent Australians, who do have a point of view, who do care, who do have an interest, and who will be glued to their television sets cheering along these athletes at Auckland. They will not be down there basking in the reflected glory for crude political purposes, draping themselves all over the nearest successful athlete in pursuit of a few grubby votes. They will be cheering for them as decent Australians who get pleasure in seeing their fellow man succeed.

To suggest that there is something impertinent about the Senate passing a motion calling upon the taxpayer-funded-in part-Australian Commonwealth Games Association to ensure that the 85 athletes retain their selection shrieks of the arrogance of this Government. It is a function of this Senate to respond to, reflect upon and present a whole range of issues, not only of a political nature but also of a social nature. That is exactly what this resolution did, and in spite of the Government it was carried. The resolution sought to express a point of view-a perfectly legitimate point of view.

I would have thought that at the end of the day, Senator Richardson, instead of doing a backdoor deal and making an offer to Athletics Australia that it could not refuse, should have been standing up in the Senate and saying, `look, this Government is of the view that it would be grossly unfair to 15 young dedicated Australian athletes to scrub them out from the team once they have been selected'.

That is the fundamental issue. But no, in the typical way these deals are done by this Government, we are looking for some sort of arrangement that appears to satisfy everybody but in the end achieves other than that which is absolutely desirable. I would have thought that Robert de Castella knew something about sport, something about athletics and made the odd contribution himself-some might say considerably in excess of that of Senator Richardson. Robert de Castella said that to rub out 15 young athletes now is not only to break their soul and their hearts but to break their careers. That was Robert de Castella's modest contribution to this debate. Of course, as is the way these days, the views of the athletes amount to nothing.

Need we go back to the time of Dawn Fraser when she was rubbed out for life because she allegedly climbed a flagpole? Pompous officials strutting around in the green and gold blazers, drinking cocktails, rubbing shoulders with their fellow travellers from overseas as if they had made some contribution to the gold medals, stood in judgment upon the moral and social worth of our athletes. We have now got ourselves into the situation where, because of a sporting imbroglio-a bureaucratic mess-caused by the failure of the officials, the sporting careers of 15 young kids are in jeopardy.

Senator Richardson was impertinent enough to suggest today that nobody else knew the selection criteria. Everybody, except presumably Senator Richardson, knows the criteria. The criteria were set down and 85 athletes met them. Unlike the rest of the sporting teams from Australia going to the Commonwealth Games, I think the athletics team is the only one not taking its full quota-all the bowlers are going; all the badminton players are going; all the swimmers are going. It is only the athletics team that does not have a full quota. It is entitled to have 118 members-the number that the English and the Canadian teams from the other side of the world are taking. Our officials from Athletics Australia judged that 85 athletes would qualify. Qualify for what? In their assessment, those athletes would qualify for the finals of their chosen events at the Commonwealth Games. It seems to me that that is considered to be not good enough, that there has to be a higher achievement before those athletes are judged to be appropriate to represent Australia.

As I contemplate that, I think about the evidence given by some of the best coaches in Australia to the Senate Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts during its Drugs in Sport inquiry. I recall those witnesses saying, `One of the problems is that the level of expectation of Australian athletes is cast so high that they are not on an even playing field; to compete internationally they are given barriers and levels far beyond that of athletes from other nations'. When we are imploring our athletes to stay clean, to run and to compete on merit without artificial aids such as anabolic steroids, we are telling those athletes that they have to be virtually guaranteed a medal before they can qualify to represent this country. If that is not giving a wrong signal to our athletes, what is? I would have thought that being able to qualify for the finals would be an adequate yardstick by absolutely any measure.

I conclude by saying that I hope, notwithstanding what I consider to be a grubby deal, that the 85 athletes go to the Commonwealth Games. I hope the arrangement is the sham it appears to be and that the 85 athletes will go and everybody will save face. The officials from the Australian Commonwealth Games Association can say that justice has been done, the officials representing the Australian athletes can also say justice has been done and, at the end of the day, all the athletes can go.

The worst of all worlds would be to put up this veneer of respectability in terms of making judgments and then, just to show that it is meant to be serious, wipe out a couple of athletes on the way so that everybody can take it seriously. Let us all hope that these officials, and Mr Coates, get the message. Given that there is no financial impediment and no problems with seats on the aircraft, accommodation, competition uniforms, marching uniforms or coaching-in fact, no practical problems at all-I hope that commonsense will prevail and those 15 extra kids will be allowed to compete, in spite of the mess caused by our officials, who wonder why they have got such a rotten reputation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent days there has been a rash of rumours to the effect that the Managing Director of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), Mr David Hill, has been actively engaged in discussions about his future with a view to joining a consortium which might purchase the troubled Seven network from the Qintex group in Australia. If these stories are true, they raise very serious matters of public concern in view of the obvious conflict of interest involved. Therefore, it is essential that Mr Hill should immediately clear the air and make a public statement about his future intentions.

SPEECH.PARA: The position of Managing Director of Australia's premier national broadcaster, the ABC, is one of enormous national and symbolic significance. It is imperative that any incumbent is completely committed to the position which, at any time, involves a range of contentious and complex issues. It would not be possible for the Managing Director properly to discharge his duties if he is actively contemplating a jump into the private sector, presumably in contemplation of a large increase in financial remuneration. There should be no basis for concern on Mr Hill's part that he would not be able to work effectively with an incoming coalition government, but it would certainly be very difficult for Mr Hill to retain his current position while any cloud hangs over his future intentions.

One of the matters that would preoccupy any managing director of the ABC-in particular, Mr Hill, at the present moment-is the difficulties being experienced within Radio Australia both in relation to a number of very significant policy and programming changes, and a forced relocation from the East Burwood site to the south bank of the Yarra-a very pricey piece of real estate, the development costs of which are increasingly providing financial headaches for the ABC. This matter deserves much more public scrutiny than it has received to date. The staff of Radio Australia have been left in a state of great uncertainty in recent months about their future.

The move from the former premises of Radio Australia in Lonsdale Street, Melbourne to the East Burwood site was made some five years ago. A review of Radio Australia was conducted in late 1988 under the chairmanship of Mr Stuart Revell, the assistant managing director. In the course of that review, Mr Revell visited Radio Australia to outline the key objectives of the review. There was no hint at any stage to staff that the issue of the location of Radio Australia would be under consideration.

That review was a very extensive exercise and resulted, finally, in a report made to the board in September this year, but not released in any public form. Again, it would seem that that report made no recommendation in terms of any relocation of Radio Australia from East Burwood to the south bank. Instead, the Board of the ABC seems to have seized on remarks in the report to the effect that Radio Australia felt isolated from the the mainstream of the ABC. The reality is that the overwhelming majority of the staff of Radio Australia feel isolated in terms of a lack of funding and, in particular, the ongoing difficulty that has been experienced in obtaining additional funding for updating transmission facilities. They are also concerned about their distance from the centre of power in Sydney. It is quite another matter to suggest that somehow they have welcomed the move or, indeed, feel that they should be brought together with other ABC Radio facilities.
That is why I have additional concerns about an interview which Mr Hill gave to John Hindle on 3AW Radio Melbourne today. Mr Hill said, when being asked why the move was being made:

We conducted in 1988 and 89 probably the most thorough review of Radio Australia's activities-that is, the ABC conducted the review of its Radio Australia-and I think it is fair to say that it was overwhelmingly a very positive review-because what we looked at were all the things that needed strengthening in Radio Australia: the transmitters, its programs, its news, its current affairs and so on. One of the issues that became abundantly obvious to us, is that at East Burwood-which was a good idea 15 years ago when it was originally planned-has become, and most of the staff agreed in their submissions with us, that is has become a professional and geographically isolated centre.

That series of comments does not seem to accord with any of the facts known to me. One can understand a desire to put a positive public view on what is taking place, but I think Mr Hill's remarks go closer to being a calculated attempt to put a gloss on the actual events. Certainly the remarks suggesting that the staff were the prime movers behind the ABC Board's decision would seem to be completely divorced from reality. Certainly, on the information available to me, it is very much at odds with the facts because the reality is that more than 75 per cent of Radio Australia staff, some 154 persons, signed a petition opposing the move to the south bank.

It is clear, therefore, that far from being a logical conclusion following ongoing study and review the ABC Board's in principle decision to move Radio Australia to the south bank is nothing short of a very recent ad hoc initiative which would seem to be primarily motivated by a desire to salvage the economic viability of the south bank project. If the move to the south bank is part of some longstanding deliberative process, it is very odd that there is no mention of it in the latest ABC annual report in relation to Radio Australia-a report which has been tabled only in recent weeks. If Mr Hill is correct in asserting that the staff are behind his initiatives, again it is passing strange that the Public Service Union has been very critical of the unseemly haste of the ABC's decisions and the lack of consultation with staff and their union. There has certainly been no public explanation to date for what is clearly a very recent decision which inevitably gives rise to concern that the move may well be driven by the financial imperatives occasioned by the Government's high interest rate policies and the difficulties which the ABC is experiencing in affording the south bank project.

I believe, on the information made available to me, that it is simply a cheap shot to suggest, as has been suggested on a number of occasions, that any opposition to the relocation is simply the product of disgruntled and essentially selfish staff who have become used to their comfortable eastern suburbs homes and certainly appreciate their present location. It does not strike me as being the result of any unselfishness that a move-which Mr Hill says was contemplated 15 years ago, which in fact eventuated some five years ago and until only a matter of several months ago was a fait accompli-has not resulted in a significant number of people changing their places of residence, perhaps even their patterns of travel and their general lifestyle because they have become attached to the area. That in itself is in no way sufficient to explain what seems to me to be a foment of discontent about the arbitrary and authoritarian manner in which this move is being imposed upon the staff, like it or not. I think that the public at large is very much entitled to an explanation for what is currently happening in terms of the relocation. Mr Hill in that same radio interview made quite a number of very laudatory comments about the operations of Radio Australia. He stated:
It has been well served. It broadcasts in English and eight other languages around the globe, 24 hours a day, 365 days of the year.
. . . perhaps it's the best example anywhere in Australia of harmonious multiculturalism . . . It's a very effective, and very professional and very credible organisation.
. . . I think as a result of the good people we have in Radio Australia . . . Radio Australia is destined to have an even brighter future than it has had in the past.

Again I think these remarks, which on their face are very laudatory indeed, describe a number of very far-reaching and forcible job relocation decisions which have taken place in recent months. They have also resulted in a very significant restructuring of the programming and direction of focus of Radio Australia to the point that some of the places, such as Japan, which are very much the origin of the correspondence received by Radio Australia are now to be effectively ignored, but that matter is not to be brought to the attention of any of the listeners who might write in inquiring why they are no longer getting any particular mention or expressions of concern for their part of the globe.

I do think that the public is entitled to an explanation not only of why these very significant programming moves are being made but, more importantly, what is driving the relocation. I have been given a copy of a document which is described as a `Planning and Financial Study of Collocation of Radio Australia in Southbank Project'. It does make it clear that the ABC expects to receive something in excess of $11m from the sale of Radio Australia-that is the East Burwood site-which it would then apply in part to reducing the debt burden on the south bank site. The project costs of that south bank site have gone from about $60m less than 12 months ago to some $76m to date if one includes Radio Australia.

The additional project cost to relocate Radio Australia will be about $6 1/2m. It certainly does seem that there has been indecent haste in the making of this decision. It is no doubt a fact that the original decision came about only after quite a considerable degree of agony and forethought. It certainly involved considerable money in building the Radio Australia premises which I am informed certainly meet the requirements of staff and generally do not need any significant upgrading. The relocation to the city will, therefore, not achieve anything further in terms of technical efficiency, but will certainly involve a very high degree of dislocation in staffing terms. The parking spaces, for example, are very confined by the natural boundaries. There seems to be a need for a much greater explanation of why it is that this decision has only very recently been made, based on a study which I am informed took only a couple of weeks to complete, and which proceeded in the face of an almost calculated decision to ignore the concerns of the staff and the union.

On 24 October last, the day before the ABC Board meeting which formalised the in-principle decision to relocate, a well attended meeting of Radio Australia staff unanimously condemned the breaking by Mr Hill of a promise which they assert had been made to an all staff meeting on 29 September that full and extensive discussions with the affected staff and unions would take place before a decision was made. So there is a very high level of concern within Radio Australia, concern which is not likely to go away and which, I think, deserves a much franker explanation than Mr Hill proferred on radio 3AW this afternoon. I hope that, in making clear his future intentions, Mr Hill will accord equal treatment to the likely future aspirations of the staff of Radio Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night during the adjournment debate I was rudely interrupted when Senator Julian McGauran called a quorum. As it was already late, slightly too few senators appeared in the chamber in answer to the call. I commend those who did, not because I imagine that they were interested or supportive of what I had to say but because they were supporting the right of a senator to say what she liked at a time on a sitting day of the Senate that has traditionally been available to Independents, minor party senators and back bench senators of the major parties so that they can speak on matters for which little time is allocated during the business day. The only excuse for Senator McGauran is that a more senior member of the Opposition had set a bad example by a previous quorum call. Why honourable senators would wish to gag debate when they could use the adjournment debate for a ringing refutation is a mystery to me.

SPEECH.PARA: In my remarks last night I had speculated on the motives of the electors of New South Wales who voted for an alternative to the Unsworth Government and who woke up to find themselves under a Murray-Greiner Government. I had touched lightly on some of the characteristics of the large individual who has provided intellectual leadership for the Government of New South Wales. I refer to Mr Murray's view that the greenhouse effect was merely a figment of the imagination of international eminent scientists. I had just begun to look at the activities of Mr Murray's Government on the coast of New South Wales and the revelations of the Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC), particularly on the north coast of the State.

Who did the Independent Commission Against Corruption publicly name as interested parties in these inquiries? It was none other than the mountainous Mr Wal Murray and his good mate and National Party colleague Mr Ian Causley. Did these honourable gentlemen offer to stand down from their sensitive administrative posts while the ICAC's deliberations concerning their activities were under way, as former Premier Neville Wran was required to do when his conduct was the subject of inquiry? Of course not. Not at all. Not only did this pair of sinister rustics stay firmly planted in their plush leather office chairs, but they even took to issuing threats of defamation proceedings against anyone who might suggest that it was a proper thing for them to remove themselves. In this way, Messrs Causley and Murray have been able to stand over and intimidate their critics in the environment movement and elsewhere. That is how government in New South Wales is carried out. Those with the odour of impropriety about them are still treated with all the respect due to Ministers, and they remain in office.

The name of the New South Wales natural resources Minister, Ian Causley, will be well known to honourable senators who have followed the south-east forest debate and to those who have followed the longstanding debate about the siting of a pulp mill in northern New South Wales. Interestingly, in 1974 as an inaugural member of the Clarence Valley Environment Protection Society, Mr Ian Causley no less protested against the plan to site a Japanese pulp mill at Iluka, along with his fellow conservationists at that time. More recently, however, he has changed his tune and has been championing the siting of a pulp mill at Grafton which is to be put there by Daishowa International. He has done this much to the alarm of his voters and to a wide cross-section of local residents and industry leaders. Sawloggers, fishermen, apiarists and tourist-oriented business people have been putting forward many of the same valid objections to this proposal that Mr Causley put forward in 1974.

This is the same man who has brought us the south-east woodchipping war and who would, if allowed, push that dangerous conflict to the point where people are injured or even killed in the worst circumstances. This bluff former cane cutter from the north coast no doubt sees himself out there in the fields swinging his machete. Whether it is sticks of cane or trees or protesters who fall under the blade probably does not matter to Ian Causley. It was this Minister who arrogantly stated in response to the announcement of a joint government biological study of the south-east forests that, no matter what the outcome of the study, the forests would be logged.

This reasonable and fair-thinking Minister of the Crown has let everybody know where he stands on the issue of forestry and the environment. He made his position very clear when he addressed the Timber Development Association in Sydney at the beginning of this year. He said:

Make no mistake about it. Our industry is engaged in a life and death political struggle. For the last 10 or 15 years it has been losing the contest. In the last couple of years it has decided to act decisively to save itself, and this commendable (if belated) survival instinct together with solid political support from this Government gives us a fighting chance. The land-use issue is pure politics. It has almost nothing to do with science. It is a battle with selfish interest groups for the control of resources which belong to the whole community. The fight to save our community's resources from being locked away will be won only by effective political action.
He continued:

This has two aspects. One is reversing the public relations tide which has been running so strongly in favour of the preservationists. The other is to crack political heads. This means telling governments bluntly that industry and workers will not stand idly by and watch their resources base withdrawn for no good reason. It means making political threats and making them good at election time. This is the language spoken by all governments: the language of public opinion directly translated into votes.
He goes on:

This process is hard, it is unpleasant and it involves intense and sustained lobbying. It requires the kind of persistence and dedication demonstrated by our opponents. They are a formidable enemy because they believe they have God on their side-or whatever passes for God these days in the fashionable Balmain terrace.
He concludes:
I look forward to seeing you on the barricades.

Government in the eyes of Ian Causley is not for the people; it is for him and his mates. It is about getting the spoils and taking revenge, making threats and cracking heads. Mr Causley's approach to government is not unlike that of a small town lout looking for someone to bash on a Saturday night. Nothing demonstrates this hooligan mentality better--

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order. I have not taken a point of order up to this point, but when Senator Dunn says that the behaviour of a State Minister is like that of a lout on a Saturday night looking for someone's head to crack, she is going beyond the limits of standing order No. 418.
—Yes. I ask Senator Dunn to withdraw that comment.

—I withdraw the comment, Mr President. To illustrate the general drift of what I have just been saying, I refer to Mr Causley's policy of selling off crown leases and reserves throughout New South Wales. Earlier this year Mr Causley brought in a new Crown Lands Act which is full of fine phrases about assessing social and environmental values of crown lands before they can be disposed of. All of it was made instantly meaningless when the Minister junked the administrative rules for crown lands assessments and arbitrarily decided that lands under some classes of tenure, such as perpetual leases, should be sold. There are over 20,000 perpetual leases in New South Wales. Many would contain significant environmental features and should not be let out of public ownership. A recent case in point was the sale at $1 an acre of an area of rainforest under perpetual lease on the Liverpool Range near Scone.
—Where is the evidence?

—This rainforest is adjacent to the Cedar Brush Nature Reserve which is managed by the National Parks and Wildlife Service and was wanted by the Service as an addition to that reserve. The evidence is there in black and white, and all Senator McGauran has to do is go and check his facts.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that a proper, objective assessment of the circumstances would have confirmed that there was no better use for that crown land than to reserve it under the National Parks and Wildlife Act; but propriety and objectivity appear to be strangers to the New South Wales Government. As if flogging off the public's land at a pittance to mates and supporters is not bad enough, the New South Wales Government now seems to be ready to do the same with the public's water. In New South Wales, ownership of water is vested in the State under the provisions of the Water Administration Act. There is a push, undoubtedly encouraged by the Resources Minister, to privatise rural water and create an enormous asset in the hands of farmers and irrigators.

If this scheme proceeds, the results could be disastrous for the physical and social environment of rural New South Wales. The ability of government to effectively manage the State's river systems could be pre-empted; the question of massive compensation payouts would dominate every management decision and paralyse administration. With the parallel development of transferable water rights, the way would be open for big companies to move in and corner the market in water licences, creating an unknown potential for social injustice and environmental degredation.

What prospect, under such a regime, would there be for realising the fine words and sentiments expressed in the Catchment Management Act 1989, which was passed only last month by the New South Wales Parliament? What hope would there be for improving the water and environmental qualities of the inland river systems when a large part of the water in those systems would be beyond the Government's power to manage, or prohibitively expensive to do so because of the need to compensate the water owner? These questions underscore the hypocrisy of the Greiner-Murray Government.

As if to compound the errors of their National Party friends, the Liberal members of the Greiner-Murray Government have launched a massive sell off of public lands and buildings in urban areas. The Sydney Showground and E. S. Marks Athletics Field, which were first reserved for use of the people as a common in 1811 by Governor Macquarie, are to be sold to developers. These historic public lands-part of the heritage, culture and social life of the people of Sydney-will be put on the block by Nick Greiner's Government as if they meant nothing to the people of New South Wales. Part of the 80-year old Sydney harbourside reserve at Strickland House will also go. Many schools, even those wanted by the community, such as the Cremorne Girls High School, are to be sold off. Indeed, Cremorne Girls High School has already been sold off to a private school.

Corporatisation and management are the `in' words around Sydney's Macquarie Street these days. The Greiner Administration finds its raison d'etre in applying the Harvard Business School management techniques learnt by its Premier. But what does it all mean in the end? One wonders. Look behind the flimsy veneer and we see a bunch of grimy corporate asset strippers going about their work with grim determination. They have no respect for the past and no vision for the future.

Let me conclude this sorry tale with an account of the Greiner-Murray Government's success in precipitating the decline and fall of a once proud organisation, the New South Wales National Parks and Wildlife Service. This is the body that was acknowledged by the well respected International Union for the Conservation of Nature to be manager of one of the five best national parks systems in the world. The Service has the dubious fortune to have as its Minister the Hon. Tim Moore, a former Boy Scout, I believe. Most keen observers agree that Mr Moore would not personally wish to see the demise of the National Parks and Wildlife Service but, whether or not that is the case, he appears to be impotently presiding over that very process.

The rot seems to have started in the first half of this year, when Mr Moore began preparing the ground to sack the Service's director, John Whitehouse. It did not come as a surprise to many people that Mr Moore should want to do this. The able and hard working Mr Whitehouse-more than a match for Mr Moore-was put in charge of the Service by the former Labor Government, appointed in fact by the present Opposition Leader, Mr Carr. There were many in the Greiner-Murray Administration who saw Mr Whitehouse as politically unacceptable and who were determined to get rid of him. Outside the Government there was a more or less constant baying for blood from a group called the Land Conservation Council. This is not a conservation group, as its name might suggest, but an alliance of all the would-be national park plunderers-hard-line miners, loggers, graziers and assorted philistines.

Mr Moore bravely waited for Mr Whitehouse to go away on holidays before making his move. He took advantage of the disaffection expressed by a minority of head office staff of the NPWS to put a team from the Office of Public Management (OPM) into the head office. The OPM report on the NPWS was predictable in its damning indictments of the Service's management and relied on a budget overrun as its main criticism. What was not stressed in the report, of course, was the fact that both the Service and the New South Wales Treasury had failed to predict a dramatic fall off in national park gate takings in the first half of 1989 due to freakish weather conditions which caused it to rain almost every weekend for six months.

Also underplayed was the contribution of the Unsworth Government to the Service's financial and management difficulties, brought about when it forced the organisation to move to Hurstville after a year had gone into planning for a move to an already selected site at Hornsby. This was a shabby political decision from that now invisible man of New South Wales politics, Barrie Unsworth, who hoped to ingratiate himself with his electorate and win a few more votes by delivering to it a captive government department. In the process the organisation was demoralised and sent reeling by the exodus of many of its financial management staff and other vital personnel. The reversal of this rotten decision was in the hands of the incoming Greiner-Murray Administration but it chose to do nothing.

It is arrant nonsense, therefore, for Mr Moore and his colleagues to dress up the sacking of the Service director, a plain political assassination, as a necessary management move. What has been the fate of the National Parks and Wildlife Service since? It has been unrelentingly dismal. Contrary to Mr Moore's assurances that the organisation's staffing level would be maintained, the organisation has been heamorrhaging people. More than 80 staff, or nearly 10 per cent, have resigned since the departure of the Director and have not been replaced. These include some of organisation's most skilled and experienced administrators and managers. Attempts to appoint a replacement director have ended in failure.

Mr Moore has cancelled meetings of his statutory advisory body, the National Parks and Wildlife Service Advisory Council, to spare himself the embarrassment of explaining to its members the debacle which he has, by either intent or incompetence, created. No proposals for new reserves or management plans for existing ones are coming out of the National Parks and Wildlife Service. The organisation is dead in the water.

Even the one measly reserve proposal promised by the Greiner-Murray coalition at the last election, the tiny Wyrrabalong Park on the central coast, seems to have been abandoned. The capacity of the Service to carry out its important nature conservation role, to examine the environmental implications of tourist and other developments, to assess land clearing proposals and proposals to alienate crown lands, to bring a governmental view to logging proposals separate and independent from the Forestry Commission, to investigate and bring forward land reservation proposals and wilderness declarations and to protect wildlife is now vastly reduced and continuing its steep decline.

I suggest that this is exactly the result desired by the Greiner-Murray Government. It may yet preside over the disappearance of the National Parks and Wildlife Service as a separate professional manager of land and resources within the State Government, to the immense satisfaction of the troglodytes of the Land Conservation Council and those like them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I would just like to comment briefly on Senator Dunn's slur upon the Deputy Premier of New South Wales, Wal Murray, and his National Party colleague. It was an unworthy attack and was unfounded in fact. Senator Dunn drew a very long bow that was indicated by the point of order taken by Senator Peter Baume that her comments had gone beyond the pale and were nothing short of a slur upon the Deputy Premier. Senator Dunn's entry into this Parliament should be remembered. She was aptly described, I believe, by the Canberra Times gallery watcher Mr Warden as nothing short of the butcher of a fine senator, Robert Wood. Robert Wood made a great many friends in this Parliament. He had a certain style and many of us warmed to it. But you butchered that man to enter this Parliament in a ruthless attempt for power.
—Order! Senator McGauran, you should address the chair.
—Mr President, through you, I am attempting to describe Senator Dunn as nothing short of the butcher of Robert Wood in her bid--

—Mr President, I wondered whether Senator Dunn might take a point of order but I would like to do so. I believe that the language being used in relation to the honourable senator is quite unparliamentary. It is offensive to describe her as a butcher. Merely to take up a description used previously apparently by a journalist does not make the term any better in its application to an honourable member of this chamber.
—I ask that Senator McGauran withdraw the inference.

—I withdraw the comment but I note that it was made by a Canberra gallery watcher in describing Senator Dunn. Robert Wood was a fine contributor to this Parliament and was a likeable character. I recall his maiden speech quite well. He contributed to many debates in this chamber. But he never went to that level, Senator Dunn, to scrape for votes. We know that you are in a very desperate position in New South Wales. You have gone out on a limb-in fact, you have jumped out of your tree-to appeal to a certain group. Let us remember that you were not elected to this Parliament--
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I think on a previous occasion you instructed the honourable senator to address the Chair.
—Yes, I did ask Senator McGauran to address the Chair and not speak directly to Senator Dunn.

—I think I have made my main point about Senator Dunn's position in this Parliament, replacing Robert Wood, who I believe would never have gone to the level Senator Dunn has in scraping and crawling for votes. He had a certain style about him and he contributed to the debates around this place. It is probably the regret of many that Robert Wood is not in the position of Senator Dunn today except, of course, Fred Nile. I have said that Senator Dunn has drawn a long bow in her attack upon Wal Murray but it has also been said that Senator Dunn is a friend of terrorists.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. That is a totally intolerable statement.
—Order! That statement has to be withdrawn.

—I withdraw that comment. If we draw long bows-and people do say those sorts of things-we get ourselves in that predicament. I do not necessarily accept it and I withdraw it. But it can be and probably has been said. That is the sort of situation one finds oneself in when one enters the slur stakes. I signal to Senator Dunn that her attack upon Wal Murray was unnecessary. I have found it necessary to stand up and defend the Deputy Premier of New South Wales, a National Party colleague. While I withdraw my comment I do not shirk from the meaning behind it.
—Point of order!
—Order! You have to withdraw unconditionally.
—I withdraw unconditionally and sit down at that point.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.37 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 21 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Prime Minister state whether the Governor-General recently received a petition or letter of request from certain Northern Territory Aboriginal elders and others relating to the plebiscite to be conducted in the eastern Arnhem Land area as to whether the Aboriginal people desire a new land council to be formed for the area.
(2) Did the petition or letter allege that fights would take place during polling.
(3) What is the text of the petition and who are the signatories.
(4) What is the nature of the advice provided to His Excellency in relation to the petition, and what Minister or Ministers provided that advice.
(5) Has the petition been, or will it be, considered by the Federal Executive Council.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Governor-General received letters, with petitions attached, seeking the establishment of a new land council in south-east Arnhem Land. The petitions were addressed to the House of Representatives.
(3) This information will be available to the honourable senator when the petitions have been tabled in the House of Representatives.
(4) Those who prepared the petitions have been informed that arrangements will be made for the petitions to be tabled in the House of Representatives. The Governor-General has been advised of this.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 21 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Prime Minister state whether the Governor-General recently received a petition or letter of request from certain Northern Territory Aboriginal elders and others seeking the return to them of a bark painting presented to him in June 1988 and containing material contrary to Aboriginal law.
(2) What are the terms of the petition and who are the signatories.
(3) What is the nature of the advice provided to His Excellency in relation to the petition, and what Minister or Ministers provided that advice.
(4) Has the petition been, or will it be, considered by the Federal Executive Council.

(5) Is the bark painting in question still held in the custody of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs; if so, on what date, and for what reason, was a painting presented to the Prime Minister passed by him into another person's custody.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question;

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Governor-General received a letter dated 3 November 1989 from one Aboriginal elder about the Barunga statement painting presented to me at Barunga in June 1988.

(2) The letter asked that the painting be returned to the writer. Because of the sensitivity of the issue, and requests from Aboriginal people that there be no public discussion, it would not be proper for me to mention the name of the elder concerned.

(3) A meeting of senior Aboriginal people was held at Gan Gan on 16 November at which the painting was discussed. As a result, I was advised that the painting should stay in Canberra. I have informed those who have written to me that I am happy to respect and be guided by the wishes of the Aboriginal people in regard to the painting. The Governor-General has been advised of this.
(5) Yes. The painting was placed in the Minister's custody last year as a consequence of publicity being given to apparent differences of opinion among Aboriginals.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 21 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is Norfolk Island eligible to be included in the Government's $30 million package to assist the tourism industry as a result of the current pilots' dispute;
(2) If not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) While there is no specific allocation for Norfolk Island, it will benefit in general terms from both the international and domestic elements of the tourism recovery package. Norfolk Island will be kept informed on the development of the national advertising campaign which is administered by the Office of Government Information and Advertising (OGIA) and will be offered the opportunity to participate along with the State and Territory Governments. The Norfolk Island Government will also be advised to directly approach the Australian Tourist Commission (ATC), which is handling the international campaign, for possible assistance with their overseas promotions, especially in relation to promotional activities in the New Zealand market.
(2) Refer to (1) above.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Christmas and Cocos (Keeling) Islands: Air Services

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 21 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what date were: (a) expressions of interest; and (b) tenders invited for the operation of combined air services for Christmas and Cocos Islanders and by what process was the successful operator decided.
(2) Did all parties who expressed interest in this operation receive advice of the outcome of their propositions; if so, on what dates, if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Expressions of interest for the long-term charter to the Islands were sought on 31 July and closed on 25 August 1989. The long-term charter arrangement was due to take effect in January 1990.
(1) (b) Tenders were invited on 11 October and closed on 10 November 1989. The evaluation/negotiation stage of the tender process is still proceeding.
(2) All parties will be notified in writing when a final decision is made.
